40394120.review:
I bought this on a whim in a sale and then didn't play it for a little while because looking at the screenshots on the store page didn't make me super enthused for it. I know the description and tags show that it is heavily narrative-based but I just want to emphasise that because if I had seen more narrative screenshots, I probably would have bought and played it sooner.

The things I love the most are the setting and the writing. I don't normally get very enthused about steampunk but I really liked this universe. Part of what can make me iffy about things taking inspiration from the Victoria era is the colonialism, but this game addresses these issues and doesn't just hide them away. The world is full of anti-colonial conflicts, revolutions, and discussion of slavery and you can often talk to characters directly impacted. There are also plenty of women in the world doing non-traditional things (which you can choose to be shocked by, usually). The writing is of a very high quality and the narrative choices frequent (with impacts ranging from minimal/non-existent to huge). I can't even imagine the full extent of the script, although I'm sure it will become apparent if I play it many more times! I really love being Passepartout and I find myself very engaged by the narrative.

If a game is described as 'replayable', it doesn't necessarily mean that I will want to replay it. Well, I've already gone around the world several times now and I know I still have plenty of places to visit and events I'd like to find and read. There are also some situations I'd like to do over because I know I missed out on something the first time. Starting another playthrough (so far, and I think I'm up to....number six?) feels like the start of a new adventure, and not like something you have to slog through just to get this scene or that ending. Each new game feels like an entire story that I'm happy to read from start to finish.

I read a few negative reviews out of interest, because I genuinely couldn't understand how someone could dislike this game, except if they really hated reading. So to address some of the things I saw:
Yes, the controls can sometimes be weird, which is annoying when you're doing something time-dependent. It doesn't happen to me very much, and I assumed it was because I'm using a laptop with a touchpad. After playing for a while, I rarely had any issues.
It's true that you cannot save in order to go back and do an event again, and that sudden unpredictable events can ruin everything you planned, but I like that (and I rather think it's the point). If you're struggling to get a certain outcome in a single event (or you fatally misclicked), you can exit the game before reaching the end of the event and reopen to make your choices again.
(This is just a negative I thought of:) The discussion/generic 'what will you do tonight' parts can get samey, but they're very quick to click through so I don't really mind.

That's it! Extremely high praise from me, and now I want some friends to play it so I can discuss it with them.

40387899.review:
This is an odd little game and it won't be to everyone's taste. 

Think of the "choose your own adventure" books of the 1980's. It's rather like that, except no, you can't cheat and turn the page back if you make a choice which later turns out to be wrong. At least not until the next play through.

It's based on the Jules Verne novel "Around the World in 80 Days" but it is modern steam punk. So expect to be travelling via mechanical birds with pregnant captains. This isn't political correctness gone mad (which I abhor) but a change which allows the game to provide interesting interactions, differing routes and alternative choices.

As you travel as fast as possible, not only must you look after your employer, but try to make trades at the markets to increase your funds (sometimes by a great deal). You may also pick up little jobs in the cities which will increase your funds marginally.

There is a lot of replayability in this purely because of the alternative routes and interactions which you can come across. Not having a certain item with you can make a huge difference to how happy your employer is and therefore how much time you need to take with him, rather than interact with the other characters and gain intelligence about future routes. 

It can be so easy to go swimmingly and then bam, stuck somewhere for four days or have to consider paying thousands to get an earlier transport.

Each play through isn't quick. Yes, you can save mid-run. There is a lot of reading; as I said, it's like the "CYOA" of yore.

It'll likely be you'll be very happy with this or very disatisfied. I wouldn't say it's a "let's play solid for 15 hours" game. Something to dip into. It's not entirely relaxing either, the clock ticks whilst you're at the market, in the bank, exploring and obviously travelling. So don't think you can wander off and leave it.

It's a pretty game, with an interesting premise. The dialogue is good. It's a nicely polished game and while I won't sit at it for days in a row, I dip in and out and don't regret purchasing it.

40375908.review:
[i]80 Days[/i] is a modern take on the text adventure game, with roots that stretch back through 40 years of computer gaming. It's also a love letter to Jules Verne and his fantastic tales of technological marvels in the late 19th century. Unfortunately, it's also a textbook example of SJW politics marring an otherwise superb game. As such, I cannot recommend it to the discerning gamer.

The premise of the game is simple: travel around the world in 80 days or less using planes, trains, automobiles, and all manner of exotic craft. The world of [i]80 Days[/i] is a fantastical alternate reality where steampunk inventions permit voyages under the sea, to the center of the earth, and from the earth to the moon. Quite simply, this is a best written game I have ever played, and it's a good thing, too, because the gameplay is almost entirely text based.

Because there are so many cities to visit and routes to consider as you travel across the globe, every playthrough is unique, and the core gameplay is addictive enough to ensure that you will want to play through a dozen or so times just to sample the well-written and affecting storylines that lie off the beaten path.

But then there's the SJW stuff. To put it simply, the world of [i]80 Days[/i] is absurdly and gratingly egalitarian. Female ship captains, soldiers, and even boiler room attendants litter the world. The game is also annoyingly anti-colonial, envisioning Wakanda-like technologically advanced empires in Subsaharan Africa that are the fear of Western colonial powers. I understand that anything is possible in a fictional game that takes place in an alternate universe, but the distinctive tinge of 21st century social justice feels way out of place in this steampunk universe.

The most egregious deviation is the character of Passepartout, the role that the player assumes. In Verne's novel, Passepartout is the loyal valet to Phileas Fogg, who circumnatigates the globe to win a bet. In [i]80 Days[/i], Passepartout is all of these things, and quite obviously homosexual (or bisexual at the very least). Many paths in the game allude to homosexual attraction between Passepartout and Fogg, while other paths offer opportunities to flirt with male and female (but primarily male) characters. There is also at least one path that leads to a romantic liaison with a male. It's an insult to Verne to mangle his character in such a way, and once again represents an anachronistic, 21st century American view of the world.

With a few judicious edits, [i]80 Days[/i] would earn a strong recommendation from me. Unfortunately, I cannot and will not support developers that shoehorn SJW dogma into their games. Do not buy.

40166938.review:
[quote]TL;DR at the bottom[/quote]

It would seem merely days since I came into the service of Mr. Phileas Fogg, an enigmatical a personage as he is a polished man of the world.

However, I turn to my notes intending an inventory of our recent adventure and find myself overwhelmed by its breadth and scope. Indeed, my mind is already blending facts and dates in a disorderly fashion.

I must not allow the memories to escape me:
How long has it been since I had sex with Death?
And how is it that I met the Creator [u]before[/u] that particular event? 
Did we suffer through many a mutiny, or did we perpetrate them?
After we solved a murder mistery worthy of Sherlock Holmes, did we smack the outlaw into summission... or were those two events unrelated?

Oh, the wonders I saw while my master buried himself into the minutia of his wager! Whole cities unbound from the ground! Automata of all sorts roaming streets! Exiled geniuses to put Tesla and Edison to shame! Nascent revolutions and agonic empires! People both wicked and righteous!

This world is certainly a cacophony of cultures and technological marvels. In trying to catalog it, I've come to the realization that travelling is most deadly to prejudice and bigotry.

What a wondrous time to be alive!

[b]- Jean Passepartout[/b]

[quote][h1]TL;DR[/h1]
Interactive fiction at its best, this game is a gem. Buy it.

PROS
+ Meg Jayanth's worldbuilding and prose are impeccable.
+ Huge replayability: Very large amount of plot twists and subplots that never feel shoehorned.
+ Lots of reading!

CONS
- Mobile UI may feel a little off on PC.
- No follow-up book (as of this writing).
[/quote]


PS: Nevermind my Steam playtime. I must have played 80 Days for over 100 hours on my phone. I bought it also here to support the developers.

40010019.review:
Since I entered in the service of Monsieur Fogg, I got thrown to a Russian prison for a week, almost froze to death, saw wonderous machines, begged for food in the rainforest, followed a caravan two weeks through the desert, met a famous captain and just discoverd a million different ways to travel. So, long story short, I really enjoyed and still occasionally enjoy this game! It is an interactive fiction and as such heavily relies on its story. And this is really the big plus here. The story is funny and exciting and offers so many little site "quests" and optional outcomes. Your job is it to choose a route for your travels, but you also have to manage your money (even in a steam punk version of the late 19th century you still need to pay for your train ticket) and still keep Monsieur amused and happy. It seems a very simple concept, but it just seems to work.

In my opinion, the biggest advantage is its replayability (is that even a word?). Since your possible routes around the world are manifold, you can fail at the first attempt (like me) and still play a completely different story at your second try. The fact that one circumvention of the world does not take you long is an extra plus for me. You don't have to invest days and days in it (but probably can?). 

All and all, I strongly recommend it (as long as you don't hate reading!) and will surely return to it  from time to time. :-)

39887643.review:
喜欢这个游戏，你需要具备下述几点特质。
1.能够接受以英语文本为主要表现方式。这个游戏的本质是互动小说。
2.你能接受蒸汽朋克的近代设定。无论是旅途中的交通工具还是每个城市的一瞥都以黑白剪影的方式表现，城市的剪影往往是城市地标，而一些交通工具很有蒸汽朋克味。文本中也随处可见自动机，机械师和飞艇等等常见的元素。
3.比起游戏方式，你更关注游戏故事；比起较长的一条主线剧情，你不在意较短的多段剧情，像彩蛋一样一点又一点的抛给你；比起世界的改变者，你更愿意做一个观察者：偶尔沉浸入世界中，又在短时间内抽离。
4.在此基础之上，你能接受一些小小的资源分配和收集要素，以及能够接受这些方面失败的挫败感。比如[spoiler]手头资产不够露宿街头，看到福格先生面如死灰的进银行啊[/spoiler]，[spoiler]和一套套装的最后一件失之交臂啊[/spoiler]什么的，[spoiler]因为和人交流时一句话说错被人以“我很讨厌你但我现在要装作礼貌地离开”的姿态打发走啊[strike]这根本不是收集要素[/strike][/spoiler]，有时让人想抓狂。
那么我把这款游戏推荐给你；你喜不喜欢，就要看你和写作者的相性了。
另，建议购买移动端版本，这种游戏还是像读电子小说一样捧着手机更合适，[strike]我只是支持制作组而已[/strike]。

39521381.review:
Clever and creative written! I love the idea of having Passepartout as the main character who organizes the journey and keeps his master alive and afoot. 
This game works quite well as text based adventure, you have to manage money, time and Mr. Foggs Mood while buying and selling trinkets or gathering information to further your journey. The steampunk elements mix very well with political and cultural details and every runthrough of the game is different. I can't wait to discover more! Try the beduin-Expedition into the desert. ;)

But there's one point I don't like: So ok, you organize the travels and there's no savegame to fall back to. Exciting! You never really think about it until... you lose everything over a dialogue you stumble into and can't get out. Anyways, how come Passepartout can lose all the funds in one lonesome exploration of a city? That's just unresponsible of Mr. Fogg to let the servant take all the thousands of pounds with him into the alleys and bazars and opium cafes. A significant loss would be a shock and hinder the gameplay, too, but to have your funds drop from ~7000 to zero in one dialogue is just frustrating and kills the run off. 

As I said, I really like the style, the idea and the creativity of this game and as long as there's so much more to discover I just start a new playthrough when something horrible happens to the two adventurers. :P But to complete a run, in time or not, should be the goal. Not a "let's see how far we get this time around."

39325437.review:
You are Passepartout, French valet of the English gentleman Phileas Fogg. He's just made a tremendously ill-advised bet that he can travel round the world in 80 days, and it's your job to see that he gets there in time without running out of money, contracting a tropical disease or dressing unfashionably.

If you like Sunless Sea, or interactive fiction in general, you'll probably love this. It zips along with energy and excitement, taking you on a whistle-stop adventure around a steampunk Victorian world in about three hours. 

But this is by no means a short game - there's endless replayability. Each city you visit comes with a bevy of decisions: where will you travel next? How many suitcases can you fit on a steam-bicycle? Should you detour to Siberia to sell the items you just picked up and fund your continued travels, or keep going straight on and risk having to wait for the bank to transfer money to you?

The writing is excellent. If you don't like reading, this game probably isn't for you. If you do, you'll be delighted by the brief yet evocative prose that describes each new location you travel to. A lot of locations are merely stopping points where you have a few hours to take in the sights before hopping on an airship to the next place, but sometimes you're pulled into an involved storyline where you have to think about colonialism, slavery and other nasty things of the era. On a whole, the game's tone is optimistic as it shows you a world of mechanical wonders, but it also shows you the price of progress.

There are (I believe) over a hundred locations in the game to travel to, and I've barely scratched the surface after two and a bit playthroughs. If you enjoy interactive narratives, involved decisions and well-drawn characters, I would highly recommend 80 Days!

39277134.review:
Charming, engaging and fun to run through.

The writing in this game is genuinely excellent. The narratives it lays out are interesting, eloquent and sufficiently varied from run to run that it's exciting to go around the world more than once. 80 Days does an astonishing job tying together the decisions made by the player into something cohesive and memorable, and painstaking work must have gone into that.

As for gameplay, it's surprisingly good. You have to choose your route around the world while managing your money and inventory which, while not mechanically astounding, is enough management to make it feel like you're actually steering the game.

Overall this game is excellent, and worth far more than the couple of quid the devs are charging for it.

38868690.review:
REVIEWS DONE QUICK BY MAX TURBO

- Why should you get this?: You're looking for a surprisingly well-written, branching, occasionally emotionally effecting "choose your own adventure" style game that lends itself to playing in short bursts. It also has light management sim elements in it, as you will need to discover the most efficient routes to take around the world, along with buying and selling items to fund your journeys. It also evokes a feel of a fantastic, "bygone" steampunk era remarkably well.

- Why shouldn't you get this?: You dislike reading. There is a ton of reading in this - it's pretty much the main gameplay mechanic, aside from figuring out where and when to leave places from. And speaking of that, I could also see this being stressful to people who don't like to make snap decisions, as you will sometimes need to do as you roll into countries in the nick of time and need to quickly get your bearings to move on to the next area before the local train / car / airship departs.

- Did Max enjoy this?: Yes, very much so. I had heard this game was well written, but I was surprised at how much it ended up digging its narrative hooks into me. I also ended up speaking like an English gentleman for the next couple days, much to the annoyance of everyone around me.

- Similar games to check out: the Sorcery! series, Out There Omega Edition

38783724.review: 80 Days is a rich and clever game. The mechanics are both fun and easy to grasp. The minimalist artwork leaves space to the imagination. Above all, the game just has a near endless replayability: this is not only because you may choose new routes and explore different parts of the globe, but because you can completely change Passe-partout's outlook upon the world he encounters. This is of course due to Meg Jayanth's remarkable writing, which goes from being witty to moving, epic, touching, or very dark. The steam-punk world she conjures surpasses its original material, it's vibrant and smart, making us think about different ways in which history could have played out. It's also a model in making diversity work effortlessly in a game. It could have been easy to make this game done-teaf about colonialism, racism, sexism, etc. or engage in the kind of tokenism all too common in mainstream media. Instead diversity and critique are seamlessly woven into the narrative. An intelligent, enjoyable game through and through.

38706626.review:
A delightful interactive novel that is surprisingly gripping and fast paced, without losing depth. Simple, in a way that really good things are, hiding away a deep layer of complexity under a well-designed and joyful presentation, suffering from a slightly clunky UI and lack of automatic stats. 

After playing it through a couple (of dozen) of times, I can say that I am almost as addicted to this as I was to replaying Fallout 1- in its own way, this is an open world game that adapts to your choices and decisions, with many paths through it, offering almost infinite replaybility due to the number of routes through the world. 

The world itself also bears comparing with Fallout's- an alternate history, set earlier than the 1950's, and during the preparation for the coming apocalypse, caught in the moment between Empire and Modernity with a Steampunk twist worthy of Captain Nemo. It reminds me of the "League of Extraordinary Gentlemen", as written by Alan Moore (NOT the film), and gains by being described, rather than shown, adding to the personal narrative develop. 

It gains depth with every reading and reads like a DIY page turner, growing in every playthrough as plots, twists and characters unlock, enriching the players understanding of the diffeent facets of the world they are traversing by a journey. 

To paraphrase: the game is highly replayable, as the player discovers and creates the world for themselves through meaningful choices and encounters in several short-ish playthroughs, summarised in slides at the end of a run. It combines simple, but effective puzzle, trade and planning mechanics, and a few surprising enconters that unlock over time. It is not, however, for haters of inventory management. Permadeath, executed through the mechanic of eastward-only motion, is a highly effective driver of devision-making.

If I were wishing for more, I would ask for consequences in the world over several playthroughs, such as having characters permanently added to your team in Saville Row, adding perks and bonuses over playthroughs and altering the course of the world as Passepartout and Phileas relive the time loop of 80 days over and over, every time making little changes that add to the whole, which would provide dedicated gamers a definitive endpoint to the narrative you can discover within the game- a big, fat "The End".

38046115.review:
I've just finished my first of undoubtly many trips around the world with this game- it sat unplayed in my Steam library for a long time until I finally gave it a go and - wow. A real underrated gem!

Like the Jules Verne novel, it's a straightforward plot - Phineas Fogg and his valet Passepartout are travelling around the world in 80 days, and it's up to you as his valet Passepartout to plan the journey - whether that's through the frozen wastes of Siberia, the deserts of Africa or the jungles of South America. Along the way you can trade goods to fund your journey, and enjoy some of the beautifully-written, semi-randomised encounters with the people and things along the way. It talks politics. It makes you think about industrialisation, and colonialism, and the spirit of adventure. It makes you fall in love.

It's a game about travel - boats, trains, and airships - and the fantastic wonders of the steampunk world created by the developers. It's not one of those games with long stretches of boring and badly written text - 80 Days is superbly written, and left me hungry for every nugget of adventure - being held up by a bandit in Mexico, drinking coffee with the engineers of Tehran, or riding on the legged leviathan of Agra through the wilds of India. Every city is written with a unique flavour and events, and the writing really makes it come alive.

I've played other text-heavy games where the gameplay is just something to do between bouts of story, but 80 Days is genuinely compelling in its gameplay too. It's great fun to try and pick out a good route, when you're trying to decide whether to spend £1000 on the fast airship or perhaps take that detour to Auckland to sell a special item. It plays out in real-time too - the ticking clock adds urgency to every action. Can you explore the city and do your trading at the market before the autogyro to Panama leaves at 3pm? It's the rare example of gameplay and story intertwined in a comprehensive package.

I've never played anything quite like this. I'm itching to have another go and see all the places I missed along the way - there are more than a hundred cities to visit, and I've only just scratched the surface. I can't recommend it enough.

Pros:

- No direct combat
- Decisions actually matter!

Cons:
- Long playthroughs
- Not much agency as a player

80 Days is a wonderful game! The way the game's story is written makes the player want to keep reading and going forward with the route. However, after several playthroughs, you will find a route which wins 99% of the time. This is okay! There are still very many routes to explore, many of which unlock new stories and dialogue options. While the stated objective is easy enough to complete, there are so many different stories to experience that it will take at least 100 hours of gameplay to experience them all. In conclusion, 80 Days is a wonderful game if you want a game where you will experience lots of storytelling and choices which actually matter.

So beautifully simple that it's almost maddening. 

There are so many possible (and unpredictable) outcomes for your journey that you could spend countless hours trying to get them all, and still miss a great deal. Having said that, a single playthrough is fairly short, and a big advantage of this game is its replayability. 

Set in Jules Verne's story, Around the World in 80 Days, you make the decisions of Passepartout. You can play as a conservative valet; concerned with his fragile master's safey, or you can play as a wild heart, full of wanderlust and a hunger for new adventures. 36690524.review:
A very enjoyable game in which every decision you make is important. You must start and finish in London but what you do in between is completely up to you. You can rush around the world in a couple of weeks or you can take your time, go wherever fate takes you, and use the full 80 days - or more, since the game doesn't end if you miss the deadline. I prefer the latter playstyle myself, since the memorable experiences from this game come from the unexpected turns your adventure takes. As the cliché goes, "it's the journey, not the destination".

It's a fairly casual game, but you do need your wits about you, since the timer doesn't wait for you. In a way, I wish it did, which would make the whole experience feel a little more like turn-based strategy, but that might take away some of the game's intended urgency. My only other criticism is that your conversations with fellow passengers are very shallow and often nonsensical, in stark contrast with the scripted dialogue sequences, which are engaging and well written. Overall, however, I had a lot of fun with it and played through multiple times. Recommended.

35997576.review:
80 days is an Adventure based on Jules Vernes Around the World in 80 Days. I have been a big fan of Verne since I was a kid and have read the book several times so I was really looking forward this game.

As the game description says, the game has a steam punk "twist". It's not entirely out of the blue, given some of the contraptions in the book, let alone Vernes other books. But it seemed more than half the stories and journeys are on those lines and that is a little too much for me. 

That said the characters of Fogg and Passepartout are faithfully recreated and it seems obvious that the games makers where fans. Despite the steam punk aspect, the game does a good job at recreating the feel of the book.

The game is very replayable with many variations and plot twists that are possible each time. The interface is simple and easy to use. The game is very simple- there is an inventory which you can use to buy and sell things but other than that there are no RPG elements or indeed anything to distract from the journey around the world and the choices you make along the way.

I'd say if you like the book or the idea of a simple, casual adventure game then this worth a go. On the other hand if you like the game and haven't yet read the book then you should read it.

35870462.review:
Alle Wege beginnen in London

Was packt ihr in euren Koffer? 
Die gelben Gummistiefel, einen russischen Zugfahrplan oder den Segelhut? Alles hat so seine Vorteile. 
Zu Beginn des Spiels ist allerdings nicht für alles Platz im Koffer. Außerdem muss es schnell gehen, denn Meister Phileas Fogg ist eine heikle Wette eingegangen: In 80 Tagen will er es um die ganze Welt schaffen. Und die Uhr tickt gnadenlos! Zusätzliche Brisanz gewinnt die Reise, weil ein Krieg in Europa  droht und mysteriöse Konkurrenten an der Wette teilnehmen, die sich nicht immer wie Gentlemen benehmen...

Im Jahr 1872 reist ihr also Hals über Kopf von London aus los, wobei ihr zig Möglichkeiten habt, was die Route betrifft. Schon wenn man in Paris landet, ergeben sich viele Wege für das ehrgeizige Duo, wobei man selbst in die Rolle von Foggs französischem Diener Passepartout schlüpft. Der muss nicht nur vieles selbst entscheiden, sondern sich fast mütterlich um seinen Meister kümmern. Phileas verliert nämlich mit der Zeit kostbare Lebenspunkte, wenn die Reise zu strapaziös wird. Also kann man ihn kämmen, füttern oder sich anderweitig bemühen.

Gegen die Zeit, das Geld und die Konkurrenz

Auch die richtige Kleidung kann helfen. Wer auf einer staubigen Wüstenstraße dahinrattert, profitiert von Mütze, Brille & Co. Interessant für Sammler ist, dass es Sets gibt, die meist aus zwei oder drei entsprechenden Kleidungsstücken bestehen. Hat man sie komplett dabei, verliert man weniger Gesundheit oder bekommt ganz neue Optionen in den Dialogen. Aber keine Bange: Es geht nicht um Sammelei und Babysitting, sondern in erster Linie um Erkundung und clevere Planung in einer Parallelwelt, die sich mit einigen technischen und politischen Entwicklungen von unserer unterscheidet – das weckt natürlich auch die erzählerische Neugier.

Hinzu kommt der wirtschaftliche Aspekt: Man startet mit stolzen 5000 Pfund, die zu Beginn noch wie ein Schatz anmuten. Aber je weiter man kommt, desto teurer wird es, denn man kann Reisezeiten über Bestechungen oder horrende Passagekosten einsparen. Um sein Budget wieder zu füllen, sollte man das Gesammelte in den Städten verkaufen. 
Aber Vorsicht: Jeder Gegenstand erzielt nur in zwei, drei Städten wirklich gute Preise – ansonsten muss man ihn verramschen. Manchmal kann sich also ein Umweg lohnen, um statt 10 vielleicht satte 1000 Pfund einzusacken.

Alles in allem ein schönes Spiel was jedoch sehr weit weg ist von der Buchvorlage. Wen das nicht stört schlägt hier zu. Ich würde aber auf ein Sale warten da 10€ meiner Meinung nach zu viel sind.

34787614.review:
An interesting twist on a text-based game, 80 Days makes what many gamers consider to be an outdated gaming style into a viable and entertaining multi-faceted experience!

I thoroughly enjoyed this game. At the end of the day, 80 Days is really just a choose your own adventure game. In many ways it reminds me of playing Oregon Trail on MS-DOS. You are put into the role of a 19th century valet charged with caring for your English overlord in a world filled with automata powered by steam and magical sciences. Expanding on the duties of a valet you are also in a race against the clock to win a wager against your master's antagonists. This is not an action packed RPG by any means, but it is chalkbox full of adventure. The imagery of the story is nearly as inspiring as the Jules Verne novels upon which it is loosely based. Some of the  situations in which you find yourself as a result of your unplanned travel choices are shocking. Now, I have only played through this game thrice. Within a total playtime of about 13 hours, I have enjoyed the feelings of dread, hilarity, frustration, disbelief and anticipation. In some cases, I have experienced several of these emotions in a single round trip. This game has a replayability like few others I have witnessed. Yes, it is a story based game. However, with over 170 cities to visit around the globe, of which each offers  different experiences; one could, in theory, play this game a hundred times and never have the same experience. It's kind of an inspired game when viewed in that light. 

There are some noteworthy developer comments I have for this game as well. I really enjoyed the art and sound in this game. I like that it is not the central focus of the game. The art and sounds are rather used as a supplement to create a starting place for the mind's eye. Akin to reading a book, most of this game takes place in the imagination. The story choices and game art are creating cues for your imagination to paint it's own picture. I like that about this game. It makes me feel like the devs think highly of me. In some games I feel like everything is drawn out for me because they think I'm a moron. All of this, means that this game is not just happening on the screen; some of this game is taking place in your brain. In this way the game reminds me slightly of Dungeons and Dragons. DND: The OG RPG excels at creating its own imagery and leaving you with lasting memories. This game does the same thing. I can remember each one of my round trip adventures in this game. That means the writing is good and the game's environment is conducive to emotional connection. Ultimately that is how we experience any game. And any game that recognizes that connection is bound to be good.

[b]Are you a gambler ?[/b]

Comme son nom l'indique, [i]80 Days[/i] est inspiré de l'oeuvre-phare de Jules Verne. Vous incarnez Jean Passepartout, et êtes chargé d'établir l'itinéraire à suivre afin que votre maître Phileas Fogg remporte son pari.

Un jeu à routes au sens littéral du terme, aussi instructif que divertissant. Stratégie et narration sont habilement combinées (les péripéties et dénouements ont parfois de quoi surprendre !). Le graphisme et la musique sont agréables et parfaitement adaptés à un univers steampunk. Découvrir de nouveaux lieux et personnages est un plaisir, et en plus on révise à fond sa géographie (chose dont je raffole peu d'ordinaire).

J'en profite pour conclure sur un petit conseil littéraire pour les amateurs de J. Verne et ses créations : [i]Les Mystères de Larispem[/i], une saga romanesque dont le premier tome est sorti l'année dernière. Ah oui, et d'ailleurs attendez-vous à une langue très littéraire justement, dans ce jeu : si vous n'êtes pas à l'aise avec l'anglais ou que vous n'avez pas envie de plonger dans un [i]Harrap's[/i] toutes les quatre lignes, passez votre chemin !

34064358.review:
This game is wonderfully well-written and presents an alternate history/steampunk vision of the traditional Around the World in 80 Days myth. Although the visuals and interface are functional at best, their abstract nature leaves most of the imagery up to your imagination. This game is essentially a choose-your-own-adventure novel with good writing. The choices are diverse, and there are light inventory/money management elements that give the gameplay some diversity and agency in choice. However, the real star here is the character imbued in every word, in every scene, in every moment of foreshadowing that suggest, to use the words of the Knight in The Last Crusade, that you have chosen wisely or poorly.

If you enjoy story in games, are willing to invest in creating a world in your mind, and are interested in exploring the world and discovering mysteries and adventures, check it out! You won't regret it.

34062511.review:
80 Days is an interactive "choose your own adventure" type game with a great narrative and fantastic writing. Highly recommended, especially if you loved the original tale. 

Each journey takes about 2 hours (within 80 days) to 3 hours (more than 80 days). While you can always take a break from the game at any city, the story is so engrossing that you would probably complete your playthrough in one sitting. There is high replay value as you explore different routes and choices.

The clock is always ticking so you feel a sense of urgency as you have to decide quickly between visiting the market, exploring the city, or planning your route. Add to that balancing your duties as valet and friend to Fogg without losing your eye on the prize. To win the game, you have to complete the journey within 80 days. However, the journey itself is fun even when you come across obstacles. Get robbed, thrown into jail, or crash your vehicle... This game ruined a perfectly good story to make political statements. The game had a wonderful interface and had a nice atmospheric feel to the entire traveling process, despite being quite minimalistic in graphics. It is like reading a novel with some additional immersion.

I also did not appreciate not having a choice to respond to gay overtures or not in one of the scenes. No matter what choice you picked, it was clear that you had no choice but to be attracted to the man. To me that is akin to non-consensual aggression (mentally forced upon you). If Passepartout was a female character, I'm sure there would be public uproar about normalizing sexual assault and women not being able to say no, but since it is a man, people gloss over it and praise it for being open and with the times. 

The above was simply an example where the author(s) of this game filtered the original novel through our current lens. The story will lose its charm and timelessness as a result, especially once politics, controversies, and pet political agendas change yet again in a few decades or so. 

The game seems glitchy and I am not getting any of the achievements. I will not be playing this again.

[h1]Review :[/h1]
Great little game !

It is a mix between a rogue-like and a "your own adventure" book, so it's mostly text based with little stories well stitched together that make an exciting global story that feels really yours ! (at least for the 2 runs I did :-) )

I was really pleasantly surprised by this game, although it has some small flaws, it is really captivating, thanks to its quality writing and originality.

If its description intrigues you, you should really give it a try, you won't be disappointed if reading triggers your imagination.


[h1]Pros :[/h1]
- Original gameplay : a mix of rogue-like and a "your own adventure" book
- Very stylish visuals and art direction
- There's enough stories to a do at least 3 or 4 runs without too much repetitive feeling
- The different little stories are very well stitched together as well as customized depending of your current run, which makes the whole story flow natural
- Very good writing
- It'll make you (a bit) better at geography as you'll discover many cities that aren't that famous ! :-p


[h1]Cons :[/h1]
- A good part of the game is in realtime, really fast realtime, which gives unnecessary pressure ; some people might get more excited from this, but it'd be nice to be able to turn it off or at least slow it down for a more relaxed and thoughtful mode :)
- gameplay wise, there's a lot of cities that makes little sense (ie: the south part of the globe) ; it'd have been nice that the wager requires to pass through at least 2 cities within a list of 5 created randomly at each game start
- A lot of choices are made without understanding clearly the consequences ; for me, it's alright and it's part of the fun (especially when the sh*it hits the fan ;-) ), but it might annoy people accustomed to more standard games

33552007.review:
I'm only an hour into it but am having so much fun I had to share!  The game looks simple on the surface -- travel around the world in 80 days -- but there is much more to this game.  Juggling suitcases, buying and selling goods, exploring cities, talking with people and learning things, and keeping your master happy are just some of the things you have to do.  Do you travel across Russia?  If so, does the master have cold weather gear?  Do you go south and cross North Africa and risk crossing the desert and, yes, riding a camel?

The interface is incredibly easy to use.  Managing your suitcases and inventory is a simple drag and drop process.  To buy goods, you drag them to your suitcase.  To sell, you drag them out.  Easy as can be.  All of the items have tooltips that shed some light on them -- the value, where they should be sold, and/or how they might help you during your journey.   Your market purchases can impact your travel plans too.  Certain items can be extremely valuable in certain cities.

Using the map is very intuitive.  Your mouse wheel is used to zoom in and out.  Click and drag spins the globe around.  There are also buttons for zooming in and out as well.  

What really hooked me is the "choose your own adventure" aspect to the game.  As you converse with your master, train porters, and people in various cities, you are presented with a few dialog options to choose from.  Each option has pros and cons.  Some will improve your relations with your master.  Some will shed light on travel routes.  Some will tell you little facts about various cities, histories, or travel tips.   As you learn new things, little information boxes appear when you click on each city -- no need to remember stuff or write it down.

I'll update this review when I finish.  I'm in Singapore right now!

33548236.review: [h1]It’s the journey that counts, not the destination[/h1] On my first playthrough, I only arrived in London after 86 days. Game Over. And I had enjoyed every second of the game, even when it became apparent I would not beat the game the first time around. I had been kidnapped by overzealous nuns, and walked on the bottom of the sea. On my second playthrough I failed to solve a murder mystery aboard a boat, but took a big gamble and blew up our airship just before arriving back home in England. But I did arrive in London within 60 days. I can’t wait to see what other adventures are in store. Taking Place in a Cyberpunk version of Jules Verne’s Around the World in Eighty Days, you play as Phileas Fogg’s valet, his personal servant Passepartout. Remarkably well balanced, 80 Days tasks you to both carefully master your master’s finances, his needs and whims, and to keep the end goal in mind. Some of the game’s best moments come from the tensions between these: the player might want to explore a city or move speedily on (all so the master wins his bet), but Phileas Fogg himself might insist on having a proper dinner made ready. Travel is ingenious and goes by airship, submarine, car, and anything in-between. Often there are multiple routes available, with widely diverging prices; you only find out which routes there are by questioning characters during your travels. Which route you take: the expensive, speedy, and experimental one or the slow, safe, and cheap one is up to the player, and their finances. Better not visit the market to sell your belongings if the next train leaves within an hour though. A typical trip round the world can be made within 2 hours. Brilliantly written, and brilliantly crafted. [h1]5/5[/h1]

Inspirado en el libro "La vuelta al mundo en 80 días" de Julio Verne, tenemos una aventura gráfica estilo elige tu propia aventura mezclado con Dónde está Carmen Sandiego. En realidad se nota la influencia literaria ya que es puro texto con ilustraciones de las ciudades que visitamos y las máquinas que usamos para viajar.

Es para leer mucho y está en inglés, te cuenta las historias de tu personaje que es el asistente del señor Fogg, quien decide recorrer el mundo en 80 días. Si no tenés ganas de leer podés responder aleatoriamente las preguntas, que igualmente el juego va a seguir. 33311972.review:
80 Days is a lovely steampunk reimagining of Jules Verne's "Around the World in Eighty Days" as a text adventure combined with a map and a minimal city UI with a few options to choose from whenever you arrive somewhere. The game is full of humour and adventure, and even if the mechanics do not vary much I am finding it quite entertaining and worth the discounted Summer sale price I paid for it.

However, I wish the developers had paid more attention to a few details: the game is never too hard and all in all I find it well balanced, but there are a few hurdles that make it more frustrating rather than adding proper challenge. For example:

- The little maps that show new routes around the world take away A LOT of space in the luggage, and they MUST stay in the luggage otherwise Passpartout and Fogg will forget them. I think they could have had their dedicated space, or take away much less since in reality they are flyers that can be folded and take away virtually no space at all.

- The passage of time isn't always clear or well stated: I lost a lot of days of travel in one city because whenever I went to the bank +2 hours would go away and I would miss my boat. While it does state "+2 hours" when you visit the bank, it doesn't state so when it says "funds available" instead. A warning message from Fogg woulda been nice, since we planned the trip, he knows about it and he is capable of warning about other stuff like the Market.

- During trips Passpartout can speak to people like the ship's captain to learn things such as new routes. It would have been great if it was possible to look at the map while asking for directions, I never remember which city I am interested in! Also it would have been nice to have a list of possible things to do during trips to go back and forth from rather than having them happen in a linear, pre-decided order. I think a hub like the city one would have been great!

- Speaking of city hubs: the art style of this game is very minimal. Why not improve it with something more appealing, such as the beautiful one used in the other Inkle game "Sorcery!"?

- I would have loved to have clearer quest markers and a diary. There are plenty of colorful characters and side-quests mentioned in the adventure, but it's difficult to keep track of all of them. This game could be a wonderful RPG with a lot of replayability if all these things were implemented better!

The game itself is pretty interesting. There is engaging story about journey around the world. The player is bound to read a lot; moreover, it is all about the reading. Hence, this game totally rely on the player’s imagination.

The story is well-rounded, and it has many unexpected twists. Your choices are really matter. Your route could be altered, and in this case you may have several different playthoughs.  

The most irritating things in this game are managing your luggage and planning your route. You should make both duties in real time, and time runs really fast. I had not measured the precise value, but I feel that one hour in game is equal to 5 sec in real time while you perform those actions. In addition, tremendously slow sliding when you look at global map or your inventory could entail that replacing stuff from your fifth suitcase to the first one takes the whole day. 33032840.review:
[i]80 Days[/i] is a flavorful mix of interactive novel and adventure game, based on the famous novel by Jules Verne, but set in an alternate steampunk universe. Every game consists of an attempt to make the journey around the world in 80 days (or less!), but rather than following a fixed itinerary, you get to choose the path to take at every leg of the journey. Not all paths are immediately available to you and it'll take multiple playthroughs to unlock everything -- that's OK, though, because you're almost guaranteed to get something new and interesting on every journey. Maybe you'll get kidnapped while trekking through the jungle. Maybe you'll brave the arctic in a steam contraption and discover a hidden city. Maybe you'll spend your last funds on a rickety airship to Reykjavik, arriving barely in the nick of time to win. Maybe you'll even find love... who knows? 

This is a game for people who like to read. The graphics and sound are fine, but the interesting parts happen in small bits of writing that exercise your imagination. The writing is excellent, painting a recognizable world that's nevertheless much different from our own, with a lot of winks and nudges to both the source material and actual history. Having read [i][url=http://www.gutenberg.org/etext/103]Around the World in Eighty Days[/url][/i] isn't required, but strongly recommended, as you'll miss the chance to have your expectations subverted otherwise. Besides, it's still a really good read.

A warning for people who like their adventures/stories strictly turn based: the game is semi-real time, with time passing at various rates while you're traveling, buying inventory or planning the next leg of your journey. It never becomes a twitch game, but you may miss a connection if you dawdle too long. There's a strong impetus to keep moving forward, which is perfectly in line with the theme of the game, but it may turn some people off. There's no need to regret a missed opportunity too much, though: you can always have another playthrough. A full journey around the world takes only 1-2 hours, depending on how you play it. Most encounters have multiple outcomes, of which you'll see only one in each playthrough. There are achievements for various likely and less likely events; people who like a challenge should enjoy planning for those.

I got this as part of a bundle, but it's absolutely worth money on its own. If you're a fan of the original novel and/or interactive fiction in general, don't hesitate to pick it up on a sale. If you're looking for puzzles or long stories, though, look elsewhere.

It’s great to see something refreshingly original. Loosely based on the book, you play the role of Fogg’s valet; planning the trip, exploring local towns, buying and selling to fund your trip. Plays a bit like an interactive novel and is a great joy to read. My only criticism is that you only know if you’re going to fail towards the end; you either make it in 80 days (4 hours) or you don’t.

Completed in 4 hours (101 days)

Extra
There are SO many different things to see in this game if you take the time. Loads of extra stories and exciting adventures to go on. I visited 25 out of 169 cities and may well come back to play it again to see different stories. I almost made it in 80 days on my first trip, but I failed because the final air trip I needed to take cost £7000 more than I had, so I had to go back the way I came to find a bank, then wait a week to get more funds (I didn’t want to faff around with the markets and more travelling by that stage), then the airship crashed in the sea just outside England. I think the general strategy is that you need to make a lot of money early on in Europe to fund the more exotic locations. Unfortunately I felt rushed throughout, but if you treat it like an exploration game instead of a race, you might actually enjoy it more.

32643864.review:
80 Days is the digital evolution of the "choose your own adventure" books, sprinkled with some nice sense of adventure, none of the frustration, and some resource management.

As Passepartout, you'll have to manage your and Mr. Fogg's journey across the globe in the alloted time (80 days, of course) with a finite set of resources, via decision-making (which city will you travel to? will you wait 2 days until the next train or rent a camel? will you follow that stranger's advice?) in a mostly text format that, rather than cumbersome, becomes like a nice book read. You´ll never have to deal with large walls of text, but instead, the dialogue is well distributed and the relationship between the protagonists keeps it engaging all throughout the journey.

It is a short game, around 2 hours to complete, but the replayability is extremely high, so it is hardly fair to judge its durability on a single run. It is also very fairly priced.

One of those rare mobile games that work just as well on PC and doesn't feel forced or shoehorned. If you want to play something fresh, it is a must-have.

32565403.review:
9.5/10.  The writing is consistently superb, and always leaves you feeling that there is more to explore.

The gameplay is nicely straightforward: it provides a framework for the writing to shine and is compelling enough to want to get good results from story events, but not so demanding that it will make you pass up a 14-day side-journey into the middle of the Arabian desert when you really should be trying to go around the world.

The game is also well-balanced for a variety of playstyles and personalities.  The story events are more realistic along the most logical routes around the world, and more fantastical in areas that are further off the beaten path.  Whether you're the sort of person who wants to take that 14-day journey into desert or not, you're rewarded with an experience that matches your playstyle.  This also gives the game a lot of replay value in choosing new routes and playstyles.

32557663.review:
My go-to game for relaxation and optimism.

A fun, colorful, highly imaginative adventure. In a brave move, the game neatly reimagines the world of Jules Verne's novel "Around the World in Eighty Days" as one filled with exotic steamships, hot air balloons, self-driving motor-carriages, automatons, and more. There are dozens of interesting and unique stories for every leg of your journey. The choices you make not only affect how fast you travel and in what manner, but also let you express different sides of your character (Passepartout's) personality. The writing is robust and quick, while doing a fantastic job of evoking all the adventure and wonder of traveling to new places.

Also, the game is just the right length to be relaxing and satisfying at the same time. It only took me 4 hours to complete one journey, but you're encouraged to replay many times because you can only experience a small part of the game on any one journey. My first journey I explored the southern hemisphere and took many wild chances, some of which caused unfortunate delays and led to Phileas Fogg and I being 15 days late. Next time, I think I'll try to play a more cautious personality and forge our way through cold Russia and the vast northern countries...

32406192.review: An amazing game from Inkle. They had me with the Sorcery! series, and now this! Inkle, can you do wrong? I think, perhaps, not.

32387989.review: Videogames can take you on a thousand different adventures, but few offer the thrill of travel as 80 Days does. It’s a story game adaptation of Around The World In 80 Days, and it’s accordingly full of exciting, exotic locations to visit, with capers to pull, revolutions to incite and derring-do to perform at many of them. Yet it’s in the quiet moments that it best captures the sensation of going on a journey. For me those moments were the mathematician I met, full of hope for the future of her home country, and the air pirate who kidnapped me in northern Europe but then entrusted me with delivering something personal to her. For you, they might be very different – but wherever you go, the appeal is the same. 80 Days is full of romance, and mystery, and intimacy, and a deep, abiding sense of melancholy, because it understands that what make journeys and adventures compelling isn’t only the mutinies you lead, but the people you meet along the way. It is consequently the most human game I’ve ever played.

32369037.review:
菲利亚·福格先生回来了。
“似李，大英格兰第一福格！“作为仆人，外号路路通的若望迎了上去。
“路路通，收拾收拾行李，我们要去环游世界了！“菲利亚先生一边走进门厅一边说着。
“环游世界，先生？”
“当然，我有个80天环游地球的赌约。该出发了。“
“可是，80天...“路路通正要说话，却被菲利亚·福格先生打断了。“是的，80天。如果我们速度快的话，40天都行。“
“那我们先去哪儿呢？”路路通一时说不出话。
“乘[b]水下列车[/b]去巴黎，当然了！“福格笃定地说。

《80 Days》改编自小学生必读经典名著之《八十天环游地球》，后者设定在1872年的伦敦，讲了个菲利亚和路路通两人在80天内环游地球，一路斗智斗勇，最后回到伦敦顺便抱得美人的故事。
而在《80 Days》的世界里，虽然时间依旧是1872年，不过！pang！欢迎来到蒸汽朋克版的1872年！

在这个游戏中，你扮演仆人路路通的角色，一路上需要规划线路，留意开销和保持福格先生身体健康。蒸汽朋克的世界为你提供了包括浮空船、蒸汽火车、移动城市和巨型飞鸟在内的各式交通道具，而整个旅行的过程充满了突发事件——谋杀、起义、逃婚、土匪等等等等，伴随着各式的剧情。
这些剧情有可能只发生在一座城市或者一段路线里，也可能需要你拜访好几座城市才能逐渐推进。在这些事件中，你扮演的路路通需要作出明智的选择，否则很难在80天内环游地球一圈——无论你计划着穿越俄罗斯还是先折到南非的布隆方丹。虽然交通确实挺便利，但是具体的路线仍然需要你通过交谈、购买和探索等方法来得知，有些方法甚至需要你常常打开报纸才能知晓。而因为游戏只有一个自动存档，因此别想着倒回去看看选另一个选项能有啥结果，下周目见吧朋友。
事件本身通常相当精彩，虽然有挺多致敬原著的桥段，但大多数都是贴合着蒸汽朋克的世界来重新设计的，并且充满了转折，相当有趣——比如你可以侦破一起发生在浮空船上的谋杀案，或者和学习机械工程的蒙古公主谈个恋爱——有一整个世界等着你来探索呢。一个周目玩下来——如果你打算在80天内完成的话——最多只能去20多座城市，但这游戏里总共有160多座城市可去哟！重玩性非常强。

推荐给喜欢文字冒险的朋友。不过阅读量比较大，生词多，英语不太好且不愿意查字典的话慎入。

最后，菲利亚先生一行成功在72天的时候回到伦敦，赢下了赌局。
“恭喜您，先生！”报纸上写满了对他的祝贺。
第二天。
“路路通，收拾收拾行李，我们又要去环游世界了！二周目！“
“...Guna!”

32332345.review:
Video Review: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jmnbZH4zI6w

80 Days is an interesting game and I’m not quite sure how to classify it. It’s strikingly similar to the Oregon Trail if you just take out all of the survival mechanics and add a lot more encounters and events that no player will ever experience without playing the game through a dozen times or more.
 
The game is played out by traveling from city to city. In each city you are greeted with an event that allows you to look around the city as you desire and have any number of things happen to you. You can visit the market to buy and sell items, the bank to withdraw cash, and plan the rest of your journey out. While travelling you also encounter similar events and the goal is to circumnavigate the world in 80 days. You have to pick your path and balance your budget while attending to your rich master of whom you play the servant. Collecting certain sets of items along the way will help make your travels easier, but there is one giant flaw to this gameplay. Time ALWAYS moves outside of events. You have no time to leisurely play this game and examine things or get up and get a drink without hitting the escape key. You’re playing a strategy game where you’re on a time crunch and to make the time crunch even worse, you’re given about a minute upon arriving to each city before it’s too late to travel out for the day and now you have to spend money to sleep at the hotel because there is no pause button for time. If you want casual relaxed gameplay this is not the game for you. The events are so long and filled with so much text too that the devs clearly want you to enjoy, but you’ll probably find yourself trying to click through them extremely quickly in-pace with the anxiety-riddled “hurry up or you’ll miss the only train for the next week” gameplay that the rest of the game forces on you. Also, the goal in the game is to spend as little money as whilst circumnavigating. That’s something they don’t actually tell you until you beat the game. So it’s good to know before going in.
 
It’s a very small indie game so I’ve actually already talked about all there is to talk about in it. There’s graphics but they’re just really of a world map. It’s a small game; one you’ll beat in two hours. The intention of the devs is clearly for you to play it multiple times and try different paths around the world. But for me it just wasn’t fun enough for that. I give it a 4/10. It’s below average. Imagine a featureless version of the Oregon Trail that punishes you for every second you spend not traveling. That’s 80 days.

32291635.review: Really interesting story. And also, the gameplay is very impressive.

32279654.review:
A game with steampunk vehicles, reimagined literature, playing the sidekick, a time limit and no killing things at all. I made a huge gamble, even with spending only 10$ on it. That is everything that I would normally hate in a video game, yet I took the chance.

It paid off. I already own a few other games about getting from point A to point B while having adventures, the Curious Expedition and Renowned Explorers, which I have both reviewed before. While unable to reach their greatness of those two games, this is still something I plan to own for years to come, despite the fact I have yet to actually finish the race in 80 days. People who only want games about doing epic things should go elsewhere, but 80 days has walking cities, uprisings to dodge, Fogg's funny social awkquardness and quite a lot of other things that add to its charm. It appeals to the content junkie in me, and the part of me who always has thought the unsung heroes are the most accpmplished. Even the look is sharp, graphic novel-like, despite the lack of animation or voice acting. 

That said, it seems to be lacking in tactical depth and it needs several replays for you to realize what the game's really all about, and really capable of. If you go by first impressions, you will get bored of it quickly, but patience and replays bring out its real spirit. Another minus is that while the game does the book due justice, its seriousness and low stakes might not appeal to younger gamers, though the same traits at least keep away the kind of people who would make fun of it on principal. This game is still good despite being a shallow romp because it defies convention and shows you an indie game can spit in convention's face without resorting to making bashing its own medium its central premise.

32231760.review:
80 Days is entertaining yet smart, funny yet moving short steampunk-esk visual novel with branching story telling and medium replay-ability.

The story is, obviously, the main focus of the game. You are Passepartout, the loyal valet of the British gentleman Phileas Fogg, who intends to travel around the world in 80 days. The story is set in a steampunk version of 1873. 

As Foggs servant you have the task to pick the route and to reach the 80 days deadline, while taking care of your master and your travel funds. Since there are no routes visible in the beginning, you have to find routes by talking to characters and exploring cities. 

One playthrough takes circa two to for hours, however, there are countless possibilities and decisions, meaning every play-through is unique. The game has a rich story with wholesome characters and interesting decisions and turns. Also, the strategic part is well done.Less positively, sometimes you are limited in your decisions, which do not seem to matter from time to time. The game tends to get repetitive at certain points.

Still, 80 days is lovely and entertaining adventure which is certainly worth a try.

32149252.review:
"80 Days" è un'avventura testuale, adattamento del famoso romanzo d'avventura di Jules Verne "Il giro del mondo in 80 giorni". Essendo un'avventura testuale quello che il gioco ci richiede di fare è leggere fiumi di testi e fare delle scelte per modificare il corso degli eventi al fine di completare il giro del mondo prima dello scadere degli 80 giorni. Purtroppo è necessario conoscere bene la lingua inglese dato che non è presente la localizzazione in italiano.

La particolarità del gioco è che potremo effettuare un itinerario completamente diverso da quello compiuto dai 2 protagonisti nel romanzo. Piuttosto che passare dal nord america, il giocatore può scegliere di passare dal sud america, oppure fare anche una visita in australia, o, addirittura, fermarsi qualche giorno sulle calde e soleggiate spiagge di Honolulu. Le opzioni sono molteplici e contribuiscono ad incentivare il giocatore ad intraprendere il viaggio più volte per affrontare ostacoli differenti e trovare l'itinerario più veloce.

E' presente anche un piccola componente gestionale: per compiere ogni viaggio da una città all'altra dovremo pagare un biglietto. La gestione del denaro è quindi essenziale dato che per recuperarne dalla banca, presente in ogni città, dovremo aspettare dei giorni. Ad ogni città, inoltre, ci si può fermare al mercato per comprare o vendere oggetti. Alcuni oggetti hanno il semplice scopo di essere rivenduti ad un prezzo maggiore in determinate località, altri hanno possibili utilizzi per superare ostacoli durante l'avventura, altri ancora permettono di negoziare il prezzo dei biglietti per effettuare i vari viaggi. E' una meccanica interessante, essenziale e poco complessa da comprendere.

Tutta l'avventura è accompagnata anche da una colonna sonora piacevole e da illustrazioni semplici ma efficaci. Tutto è comunque ridotto ai minimi termini in modo da non distogliere troppo l'attenzione dal testo, perno centrale del titolo.
Peccato non sia stato fatto il doppiaggio dei testi, a mio parere sarebbe stata un'aggiunta gradevole che avrebbe potuto rendere ancora più coinvolgente il titolo.

In conclusione, "80 Days" risulta essere un ottimo passatempo per qualche ora, per niente impegnativo, il gioco scorre fluido per tutta la sua durata, senza momenti noiosi. Non è un titolo fondamentale, non ha nulla di estremamente originale, ma se siete appassionati di Jules Verne e di viaggi, un pensierino io ce lo farei, soprattutto se lo trovate in qualche bundle o in sconto qui su Steam.

32146964.review:
"Around the World in Eighty Days" ของ Jules Verne คือหนึ่งในนิยายชื่อดังที่มีน้อยคนจริง ๆ ที่จะไม่รู้จัก แม้เวลาจะล่วงเลยไปเป็นเวลากว่าหนึ่งศตวรรษ แต่เราก็ไม่อาจที่จะปฏิเสธได้ว่าการผจญภัยของ Phileas Fogg และ Jean Passepartout ช่างเป็นการผจญภัยลึกล้ำและน่าหลงใหลเสียจริง ซึ่งเกมที่ชื่อ 80 Days ของเรานี้ก็คือเกมที่ได้รับแรงบันดาลใจมาอย่างเต็มที่มาจากนิยายเรื่องนั้น เพียงแต่การผจญภัยของเรานั้นจะเกิดขึ้นในจักรวาลคู่ขนานแบบ Steampunk ไม่ใช่โลกในศตวรรษที่ 19 ซึ่งเรารู้จักหรือคุ้นเคย

ภายในเกมนี้คุณจะได้รับบทเป็น Passepartout ที่ต้องออกผจญภัยไปพร้อมกับเจ้านายใหม่อย่างคุณ Fogg เพื่อที่จะเดินทางรอบโลกให้ครบกำหนดภายใน 80 วัน คุณจะได้รับโอกาสในการเลือกเส้นทางของตน ค้าขายแลกเปลี่ยนสิ่งของเพื่องบสำหรับเดินทาง และแก้ไขปัญหาต่าง ๆ ที่คุณจะได้พบเจอตลอดเส้นทาง เนื้อหาของเกมทั้งหมดจะถูกเล่าเรื่องในแบบตัวอักษรคล้ายกับหนังสือประเภท Choose your own adventure ดังนั้นถ้าคุณมีทักษะด้านภาษาที่ไม่ค่อยจะดีสักเท่าใดนัก ผมก็แนะนำให้เลี่ยงครับ (กระนั้นศัพท์ก็ไม่ได้ยากมากมาย ถ้าคุณมีทักษะด้านภาษาอังกฤษในระดับพอไหว คุณก็สามารถที่จะสนุกไปกับเกมได้ไม่ยาก)

จุดเด่นที่ยอดเยี่ยมที่สุดของเกมก็คือโลกที่มีฉากหลังเป็น Steampunk การผจญภัยที่คุณจะได้พบนั้นจึงเต็มไปด้วยเรื่องราวที่น่าสนใจไม่ว่าจะเป็นการออกท่องไปบนผืนฟ้าด้วยเรือบิน, รถไฟที่เร็วนรกจนเกือบจะบิน หรือแม้แต่มนุษย์กล 80 Days นับได้เป็นเกมที่มีการเล่าเรื่องที่ยอดเยี่ยมและน่าสนใจที่สุดเกมหนึ่งที่ผมเคยได้พบ ซึ่งถ้าคุณเป็นผู้ที่มีใจรักการอ่าน คุณก็จะหลงรักเกมนี้ได้ไม่ยาก

และถึงแม้ตัวเกมจะให้เวลาถึง 80 Days แต่ถ้าคุณเร็วและโชคดีพอ คุณก็สามารถที่จะจบเกมได้โดยใช้เวลาเพียงแค่ไม่ถึงครึ่งเท่านั้น การพยายามทุบสถิติของตนโดยการออกท่องไปในเส้นทางใหม่ ๆ ส่งผลให้เกมนี้สามารถถูกหยิบกลับมาเล่นได้หลายครั้งเลยทีเดียว

สรุปแล้ว 80 Days นับได้เป็นอีกหนึ่งเกมที่ยอดเยี่ยมที่สุดเกมหนึ่งที่คุณไม่ควรพลาด นี่คืออีกหนึ่งการผจญภัยรอบโลกที่ยากจะลืมได้ลงเอามาก ๆ และผมอยากจะแนะนำให้คุณได้ลองครับ

9 / 10

+ โลกแบบ Steampunk ในศตวรรษที่ 19
+ ทุกการตัดสินใจในเกมล้วนแต่สำคัญ
+ เนื้อหาของเกมที่ถูกบอกเล่าผ่านตัวอักษรได้อย่างยอดเยี่ยม
+ สามารถหยิบกลับมาเล่นใหม่ได้หลายครั้งเพื่อพบเจอกับเส้นทางใหม่ ๆ เพื่อเวลาที่ดีกว่า

32144067.review: This is very good.  There are lots of pieces of story to uncover, and after completing a round-the-world trip in 80 days (which is not overly difficult), I find myself starting up again in order to uncover more story.  If you have other things in your life besides this game, it's nice to know that a trip round the world can be completed in a relaxed evening.  The question after that is whether you want to explore other paths (navigational and narrative) through it.

32140564.review: Are you a fan of choose-your-own-adventure novels? Have any interest in Steampunk? Do you like planned out strategy games with a set goal? If you answered yes to all three and don't have this in your library yet, amend your grievous error, and enjoy yourself!

32139189.review:
80 Days is, simply put, one of the best experiences one can have in gaming. 

The gameplay is addictive - I dislike replaying games all over again (even the likes of Mass Effect), but 80 Days is so well-written that I truly feel like making a new journey, again and again, exploring the world, meeting people I wish Passepartout could meet again.

It's also a book - kind of. One full of humanity, telling stories of romance, intrigue, and war - but also of revenge, everlasting friendship and pure, sheer adventure.

80 Days is all about journeys and goals, and knowing oneself. Mark my words: it's a game you shall never forget.

32135526.review:
80 Days is a narrative focused race against time game where your choices dictate how you progress through the entire game.  You are the butler/man servant of a lord that is on a mission(as he has a bet on it) to go around the world in 80 days or less.  You decide which methods of travel and route are the best to take as well as what items you bring on the journey.  While doing all of this you are managing the clock and your own resources.  

I honestly haven't seen many flaws in the gameplay, the only thing I can present is that if you don't enjoy reading then you won't enjoy this game very much.  Much of the gameplay is exploring the text and narrative the game throws in your direction.  

I would give this a 4/5 or even a 4.5/5, it falls in my mind into a unique category of gameplay that is pleasant and relaxing but has the core gameplay to back it up.  I would highly recommend it at any discount to anyone, and at full price if you are someone who really enjoys narrative.

32125805.review:
I cannot praise this game highly enough. The writing is superb, the visuals are crisp, clean and functional but the gameplay is the thing that is bringing me back playthrough after playthrough. There is so much to discover as you travel about the world in this choose-your-own adventure style game. Even following a similar route leads to different outcomes and since 1 playthrough takes between an hour or two it's easy to pick it up and go for another run.

I love this game and look forward to trying the developer's other games

32122573.review: Didn't think much of this at first, but it's a good challenge and the replay value is pretty good when it comes down to it. The dialogue scenes were pretty fun to interact with when I took the time to get through them. Pretty fun, short game to play every once in a while

32095131.review: Picked up on a whim as part of a Humble Bundle, but I've been very surprised by the excellent quality of this game. 32082485.review:
A wonderful, rip-roaring adventure. Each playthrough is different, and although the game is quite simple, all elements are executed well. The choices really do matter, the options are varied and you can't beat those oh so english quips from the inimitable Mr Fogg. 

Only complaint is the longer journeys can sometimes feel a bit long and tedious. A way of speeding up time would have been a nice touch.

32078870.review:
[i]80 Days[/i] is a choose-your-own-adventure game (CYOAG) based on the Jules Verne novel of the same name. You are Passepartout, French servant of an Englishman named Phileas Fogg, who made a wager to his fellow clubmembers to circumnavigate the world in, well, 80 days or less.

The game has remarkable depth for a CYOAG. Mainly your adventure unfolds based on the cities you choose to travel next, but along the way, you'll engage in interesting conversations. Some lead the story to deep, contemplative moments, while some gives you knowledge to unplanned travel routes or even access to faster, cheaper means of transport. The hundreds of cities to travel in addition to a plethora of conversational options makes it rare to experience the same story on each playthrough.

The success of your circumnavigation depends on two things: money and items. You start off with 4,000 pounds in cash, but you can buy some items in, say, Munich, and sell them for profit in, say, Istanbul. In that note, although there are some basic economic elements to it, it isn't necessarily a trading game. The items you buy makes your trip easier. For example, buying coat furs and mittens help you cope with the Siberian cold should your travel pass through there.

Although it's mainly text-based, the accompanying artwork is beautiful. You'll notice remarkably different atmosphere between cities in every continent. The excellent original soundtrack makes them even more memorable. (The music for the game's finale is my favorite!)

This review barely scratches the surface and I wish I could express my love for this game much, much more than I could in here! There's just so many things to see and experience in this game that makes [i]80 Days[/i] not only enjoyable, but also highly replayable. I'd go as far as saying it's one of the best adventure games of all time with [i]Skyrim[/i] and [i]The Witcher 3[/i]. 

Thanks so much Inkle for making this fun, fun game!

32075795.review: Fun and interesting game, easy to sink time in.

32065726.review: Great game, played few twice now and had completely different stories both times. Very relaxing and something nice to play for about 2 hours each go.

32064374.review: A Jules Verne Simulator and one of the finest indie games I've ever played. Well done Inkle!

32064011.review:
A surprisingly nice little game.

Its based on book idea of going around the world in 80days, sadly having never read the book but seen TV/film adaptations of it, this is seems abit more crazy, with not only boats and trains but also mechanical elephants as means of transport.

Graphics are, on the one hand basic, with a top down view of the world, which you click on different cities to progress through but also, there is lovely art style to the game, showcase in the background of the cities you visit.

There isn’t really alot of gameplay except a few clicks here and there, while reading through a load of text but somehow it makes it one of those types of games where you think, just a little bit longer.
The text that you read, makes up the story of your adventure, so changes depending on what routes you take across the globe. So some stories you may find you follow all the way, some you might lose track of and your left wondering what happened to that person. But this helps add to the feel that your character is travelling the world and on a time schedule. Of course you will meet people on your travel but you will then move on, as is life.
There is also times where you can risk spending an extra couple of days to try and continue that story, say by visiting another city that’s wasn’t exactly on the route you where originally planning.

This can also happen in scripted events, where for some reason the city you where journeying to will, suddenly no longer be your destination, which can sometimes frustrate or delight.
How so, because travelling the world cost money. You start the game with plenty but unless you start doing some wheeling and dealing, you eventually find your funds running out, especially for some of the more expensive but faster journeys. So it’s up to you, to buy items in markets, and then sell them on.
The game tells you where you will receive the most money for selected items, but is it on your route? Do you head that way, just to make money, hoping that you can continue your journey from there?
And you don't have all day to decide, as part from when your reading the clock keeps ticking, and if you spend to long at the market or planning a route across the country, you may find that you've just missed your connection and the next one isn't for 5 days! Do you then choose another way? Wait the days out? Or bribe somebody to lower the amount of days until the next journey?

I've played through it three times now, not once have I stopped midway.
My first attempt, it took me 84 days and I was gutted that I just missed out! My 2nd try, it was 74 days and I was genuinely over the moon, to have made it, and exactly 10 days quicker than my first attempt. And my third attempt before writing this review, it took me 75days.

It isn’t exactly a long game but its got character and a charm about it, which somehow has you glued to your seat from the start of your journey till the end. With the feeling of plenty of time to begin with and then the increase urgency as the game progresses.
And since I got this off Humble for 80p, it was well worth the money.

32049412.review: Great game , the only issue that i found was that the amount of text while exploring and traveling was overwhelming.

32046904.review:
This is a really fun narrative based game that can be a nice way to spend some time.  The game is based on a series of choices that the player gets to make as they step into the shoes of Passapourte, the man servant of the games "main" character, Phileas Fogg.  

It does a great job capturing the magic that that the 19th century people viewed the future with, and the amount of absolutely ludicrous but at the same time simply amazing transportation methods just add to the experience.

Another huge benefit of the choice system is that you dont have to simply take an east-west course, you can travel through America first in some situations, as well as through the arctic or down through africa in the hopes that you find a faster method of travel.  All routes have pros and cons, and one of the downright coolest things is you get to see recent players on your map and guage the speed theyre going with your own.

Some of the limits placed on you really force you to play intelligently, some modes of transport only allow certain amounts of luggage meaning you must dump all that valuable junk youre carrying around, some items are of extreme value in places but on your route there is simply no way you can make the time to go there.  

All things being said, I have about 50 hours in this game logged while connected to the internet, but I am sure that i have quite a bit more than that, and I still haven't really discovered everything there is.  The great thing is that a single playthrough takes about as long as you make it, you can blow through all the text, not talk to people and finish it in under an hour, or you can savor everything talk to everyone and try to find new routes and take well over an hour.

32038873.review: This game was not bad.  It gives you that sense of adventure.  Much like the book you try to traverse the new landscapes to navigate the globe in the quickest time.  But, the problem is you don't know what technology (if any) these new areas have.  This makes it interesting cause it would be boring if it was that easy.  In my first time I completed this in 99 days and enountered three major problems that delayed my first attempt, completing this game in about 7 hours.  There's a lot of reading which is essential so that you can discover new routes to travel.  Sometimes the most direct route isn't the quickest route.  If you like adventure this game is for you.

32024667.review: Görsellerden zaten sadece yazılarla ilerlemeli bir oyun olduğu belli. keşke filmdeki gibi olsa bir kişiyi yönetsekte ilerleseek keşke tabiki diye düşünebilirsiniz ki ben de öyle düşündüm. Fakat oyunda dil desteği olmadan oynanmaz. sürekli çevir çevir çevir oyunun heyecanı kalmıyor.

32023014.review: Very nice game, and has replay value. ^.^  I plan to cherish and play it again many times.  It's like a pick your own adventure book but with many more choices.

32016423.review: Il gioco narra il viaggio nel mondo di un uomo in 80 giorni, come ogni avventura grafica che si rispetti grazie alla nostra interazione avremo la possibilità di modificare e gestire la nostra esperienza di gioco in tantissimi modi. 32015688.review:
L'évolution parfaite du gameplay issu des "livres dont vous êtes le héros", ici appliquée à un voyage de ville en ville autour du monde, et à tout ce qui peut se passer au cours de ce voyage. En plus, il ne s'agit pas juste d'une bête adaptation du bouquin de Jules Verne, mais de sa transposition dans un univers steampunk plutôt réussi!
Grosse grosse rejouabilité si on veut explorer toutes les villes et essayer toutes les possibilités de trajet!

32015455.review: I haven't played "Choose your own Adventure" games since I was a child so it was nice to see how much the genre has progressed since then. The world of 80 Days is interesting, the dialogues very well written and the Art style looks nice. However the game has a few aspects that can be frustratring as well. For example the clock is always ticking down and while this creates a sense of urgency there were points where I wished I could have a closer look at the map to plan my route or go through my biefcases to discard a few things I probably won't need anymore. The other thing that could cause some frustration is that (contrary to the Sorcery! games by the same dev) there is no Undo button and you only have one save which automatically gets overwritten. I'm almost certain both of those things are intentional design decisions and they fit the theme quite nicely but they also make the game more hectic than other "Choose your own Adventure" games.

32010622.review: Sehr schön gemacht mit interessanten Geschichten auch aus der damaligen Zeit. Es wäre nur super,wenn es eine deutsche Übersetzung gäbe, da es doch recht kompliziertes Englisch ist.
