31981050.review:
Ce jeu est une perle. Sérieusement. En bref : l'univers est génial, le jeu a une grande rejouabilité et reste passionnant à la troisième partie (et je dois me mesurer pour ne pas en lancer une quatrième tout de suite), ce jeu est vraiment excellent. Recommandé pour : les amateurs de Jules Verne, de steampunk, de bonnes histoires, de bons personnages.

L'univers d'abord est très intéressant, c'est une reprise intéressante et steampunk (il y a des mechas!) de l'univers de Jules Verne (au delà du seul Tour du Monde en 80 jours, on a aussi des allusions / clins d'oeils par exemple à Vingt Mille Lieues sous les mers et Voyage au centre de la Terre), avec des reprises d'évènements historiques (la Commune de Paris, etc.) et un background très riche qu'on découvre, comme le personnage au fil du voyage.

Ca m'amène aux personnages. On s'identifie très vite à Passepartout, au travers de qui on découvre l'univers. Personnellement, j'ai adoré le jouer très fidèle à Fogg et avec des soupçons de bromance / romance à sens unique (no comment) mais c'est très libre (même s'il me semble qu'on ne coupe pas vraiment au lien avec Fogg, parce que l'un des éléments de gameplay consiste à... Garder Fogg en bonne santé). Et on rencontre énormément de personnages trèèèès intéressants et très cools au fil des voyages (voleur.euse.s, étudiant.e.s, peintres, militant.e.s etc.) dont on découvre une partie en discutant avec eux.

Et toute la diversité de l'univers et des personnages fait qu'on a envie de rejouer encore et encore pour essayer de nouveaux trajets / choix. Parce que tout dans ce jeu est à propos de rencontres, de découvertes, d'aventures. Du moins je l'ai perçu ainsi, et c'est ce que j'ai vraiment adoré dans ce jeu et qui le rend assez difficile à raconter. J'ai très envie de raconter tout ce que j'aime dans ce jeu, mais je n'ai pas envie de spoiler les aventures, les choix ou les embranchements que vous pourriez prendre en jouant.

En somme : jouez-y, sérieux.

Ah oui, et CE JEU EST BEAU PUTAIN! (vraiment, il est très joli, très bonne ambiance, splendide.)

31980772.review:
This game is actually really well done. Lots of replay value with all the different routes you can take with lots of different dialogue. No two runs should ever be the same. 

*WARNING* I actually did not enjoy this game as much as I would have thought. It's a neat little game with a rich story but that is where I had the problem. I was expecting for this to be a quick little game to pick up and go but the amount of dialogue can be VERY overwhelming. Some times it was great. Other times all I wanted to do was get to the next city but I was bogged down with screen upon screen of dialogue and story. Most people might not have an issue with this and will really enjoy it but thought it was a bit much.

To summarize this really does feel way more like an interactive novel than a game and I just feel like they don't make that obvious enough in the descriptions.

Buy this if you are ok with a lot of reading, like read a few pages of story to do almost everything (expect shop) and you want a great story. Don't if you have read one of these articles saying it's easy to pick up and drop because it's not. If you only play for short periods you will forget the story and what you were doing and the constant reading will feel like you never get anywhere.

31966572.review: Tolles Spiel, und für mich eine absolute Überraschung. Ich habe mir dieses Spiel als "Beiwerk" im Humble Bundle bekommen und war zunächst nicht mal überzeugt es zu installieren. Nach 4 Stunden und 1,5 Spiel Durchläufen kann ich sagen: Mir wäre eine Spiele-Perle entgangen. Das Spiel fungiert als eine Art spielbarer Roman, Gameplay Technisch bietet es fast nichts. Was wie ein Nachteil klingt, ist aber eigentlich der Vorteil. Fast jeder kennt Telltale Spiele, welche immer mal wieder "Scheinentscheidungen" vorgaukeln, das ist bei 80 Days genau das Gegeteil. Du als Spieler hast die Freiheit überall hin zu reisen, das mag natürlich auch daran liegen das dieses Spiel ebend sich weder auf Grafik, noch auf Gameplay konzentrieren muss, sondern auf Story Telling. Und das macht das Spiel echt gut. Zur Schwerigkeit kann ich noch nichts genaueres sagen. Den ersten Run habe ich in 79 Tagen geschafft und der zweiter sieht eher nicht aus als würde er es schaffen. Also bisher recht ausgeglichen. Super Spiel und ein absoluter Überraschungs Hit.

31914292.review:
80 days is an amazing game that I reccomend you buy and play.
It is based on the novel '80 Days' and in the game you serve as Monsieur Fogg's servant, Passepartout as you go on an amazing and memorable jouney around the world. But there is one catch. You must do it in 80 days.

The writing is the highlight to 80 days and is very much as premium as an expensive book. 
The 'choose your own adventure' side is amazing as well. Unlike other choose your own adventure games, your choices effect the game a LOT. It's not just a short term effect like other games, but it can be long term and game changing as well.
Just by doing something as simple as asking a pedestrian for navigation to saving someone from drowning can COMPLETELY change the game and it is here which makes the game really shine. The art style is great and there is different art at every city you go to. I really like how this has a visual aspect because most novel type games are just plain and bland.
In my first 5.1 hr playthrough (which I failed to do in 80 days) some of the things I experienced was: Got held at gun point, recruited as an agent to be sent on an espionage mission, stole a car, worked at the circus, went bankrupt, nearly got arrested and other crazy and awesome stories

Verdict
Even if you don't like reading, or aren't into games that are as simple as this, I still highly reccomend you pick this up. 
It's cheap and I got my copy 75% off to make it even more of a bargain. 

Pros:
Cheap
Great writing/story
Art is great
Great strategy involved
Memorable moments and characters
Replayable

Cons:
No sort of system to let you save and see your journey at the end of the game
Occasional grammar/punctuation errors

31547147.review:
1. This plays well on PC but I think one of the mobile versions would be as good if not better if that makes it easier for you to play.

2. This game could actually be converted to a pure text game along the lines of [i]Zork[/i] and it would lose very little process. I say this as a good thing.

3. So I've never read [i]Around the World in 80 Days[/i] but the plot is simple enough to understand: rich man makes a bet he can travel around the world in 80 days. Adventure ensues. The plot of this game is the same. You play as this rich guy's valet, which means you do all the work. He has the money. This is life kids, get used to it.

4. On your journey, you have a few basic tasks: find routs to new destinations, book travel, buy and sell equipment and accessories, manage money and attend to the needs of your rich guy master. 

5. Circumnavigating the globe in 80 days is not terribly difficult. You are graded on how well you did in certain areas but mostly you have to find your own challenge if challenge is what you want. 

6. You can chose to try to go around the world as fast as possible. You can try to visit the most cities. You can find the cheapest routs. You can try to keep your rich guy master as comfortable as possible if you want to do that for some reason. Esp. if you don't care about actually finishing in 80 days, you can do whatever it is you damn well please.

7. Each playthrough of this builds from a different seed but the variations are not that great. If you chose to take the Trans-Siberian express across Asia every time, you are going to run into about the same situations each time. If you want something truly different, you have to take it upon yourself to find it. I think ultimately this is a good thing because, really, if you want to make it your goal to get through as fast as possible, you need some consistency.

8.  Really, the joy here is in finding on how your journey plays out depending on what choices you made. Each city you visit has a bit of a story which you will discover both before, during and after your visit. The people you meet have stories you can learn about or chose to ignore. Things you do early on affect how your journey transpires later. This game is about making a story out of a few simple choices. 

9. You can totally make out w/ both dudes and chicks in this if you got the swagger to pull it off.

10. The writing in this is a pretty impressive feat. Almost every few sentences, there is an opportunity for player input and the writing always goes along seamlessly w/o seeming award or computer generated. I think they must have had a writer or team of writers actually go through and compose these hundreds or thousands of conversations trees. 

11. There are lots of little annoyances while playing but nothing really gamebreaking. It drives me nuts that the clock keeps running at hyper-fast in-game time while you are shopping or reviewing travel options. I get that it takes in-game time to do these things but you can basically lose a day if you get distracted in real life for two minutes. 

12. Rich your guy master in this is kind of a twat. OK, really a twat. If I could offer the developers one improvement on gameplay, you should allow players to kill him and pay off officials to look the other way. 

13. Honestly, during my first playthrough, I got kind of bored by the end of the game which makes it a bit hard to wholeheartedly recommend this . But as I was thinking about it afterward, something happned: I decided that I wanted to play it again. And it was worth it! So, yeah, pick this up if you like stories and also like videogames.

30955634.review:
This game is definitely one I've never seen before. 

The concept of it is basically to travel around the world in 80 days or less with a colleague in order to win a bet. It is in fact a [b]text based[/b] game but does a very good job with it's wording. You will start at one point and be given the freedom to traverse wherever the current location you're at can take you, assuming you can afford it. There are many different places you can visit and they're all different. You can't visit every stop in one sitting so the replay value is extremely high. 

This is the kind of game where you travel point to point managing relationships, money as well as time. Again, you travel with a colleague so you aren't alone and is actually the one person you need to maintain a stable relationship with since you are with him for the entire trip. You will however run into other people in different countries and cities that can either help you or hurt you. Some will give you helpful information such as which route is cheaper, which countries/cities to avoid, or which items sell more in what countries/cities. Where as some will hold you hostage delaying your progress, steal money from you, or even backstab you. Thus, based on the events that happen, you must be able to strategize at any given moment so your trip isn't handicapped anymore than it is. 80 Days is also a game where choices do matter and affect the way the game plays out. You will run into problems no matter where you go and most if not all areas of the world you visit will contain some form of conflict you must address that will affect how you're character is perceived, how your financial status ends up as, as well as how tight your time constraint becomes. Again, time is also passing no matter what you do so time management is a really important asset to consider when playing the game. 

In terms of difficulty, despite what's been said, it definitely is more lenient when you aren't able to make it around in 80 or less days. In that sense I found it quite difficult to circle the planet in 80 days or less but if you were to reach the deadline unsuccessfully, you can still play on. All that happens is that your colleague will just notify you that you and him have failed to reach the 80 day goal and have lost the bet but then says that it isn't a big deal. He then continues to say that the journey is [i]"not complete until we've returned back home!"[/i] and you will still be able to complete the game, regardless of failing to reach the goal. [b](I'm not sure if there is a limit of how many days over 80 you can play for since you can in fact go bankrupt so just beware).[/b]

80 Days is definitely a game for both hardcore and casual gamers, although not very action packed, it is very tense. It is recommended for those who like reading and making decisions that affect the storyline, as well as managing important real life problems such as time, money and relationships. You know, like a responsible adult. 

TL;DR: A text-based travelling game where choices matter with high replay value where the player must be able to manage money, time and maintain relationships.

30777323.review:
Al principio, esperaba una versión videojuego de la famosa novela de Verne, pero poco tardé en darme cuenta que era mucho más que eso. Un mundo interesante, que te hace querer visitar otras ciudades sólo para ver cómo es el lugar, en donde no sólo se debe medir el tiempo, sino el dinero (comprando y vendiendo, o recurriendo a los bancos).

Hay veces en que me he reído, o me que quedado con la boca abierta (y sonriendo) ante los hechos. Aquí se te premia por leer. No sólo el texto del videojuego, sino otras novelas de Verne. Una de las cosas que más valoro en un videojuego es la historia, y Monesvol, que este excede en ese aspecto. Hay referencias a las obras del escritor por todas partes, y se reconocen algunos retoques en la trama que encajan como tuerca y tornillo.

Es divertido, emocionante, intrigante, y no hay dos vueltas al mundo iguales. Primero intenté seguir la ruta del libro. Noventa y pico de días. Luego intenté ir por el polo Norte. El señor Fogg perdió tres dedos de los pies, pero llegó en sesenta y tres días. Luego, me dije que iba a ir por África pero apenas toqué Medio Oriente y, luego de pasar por un naufragio, una ladrona mundial, un capeón de boxeo, un secuestro de piratas y mil cosas más, llegué a Londres vía Islandia en cincuenta y tres días.

Vale la pena, y mucho.

30288409.review:
Ispirato dal celebre romanzo di Jules Verne, 80 Days ripropone l'incredibile avventura di Phileas Fogg e Passepartout, nella folle impresa di circumnavigare il globo terrestre in appena 80 giorni. Il gioco ci metterà nei panni del fido domestico tuttofare, con lo scopo di pianificare gli spostamenti, scoprire nuove rotte, gestire il denaro ed i bagagli, fare periodicamente la barba del signor Fogg per evitare che cada in depressione.
Nonostante l'impostazione da tablet molto semplice, il gioco ha una mole sorprendente di testo scritto da leggere, che descrive minuziosamente le peripezie dei due protagonisti e gli scenari in cui si muovono, dando anche degli ottimi suggerimenti su quale sia il percorso ottimale da intraprendere.
Un titolo rilassante ed impacchettato in maniera deliziosa, un gioco senza pretese ma utile per colmare, senza eccessivi pensieri, i ritagli di tempo.

Cheers...a Passepartout!

30139432.review:
"80 Days" is a game based Jules Verne's novel, you play as Passepartout, Phileas Fogg's valet At first it may look like logic game - you have to find a route around the world while managing your "resources": time, money, inventory and Fogg's health. But after a few moments of playing you can see that it's not only moving on the world map. It's also an adventure. Each city gives you a possibility to explore and discover new routes, sometimes you'll end in different place than you planned, some things will happen during your travel. What really amazes me in this game is the sense of adventure. Your car may be captured by air-pirates, you can find that Transsiberian Railway is more than meets the eye, you may walk the oceans bottom, solve murder cases, travel with world's greatest thief and much more.
The graphics are rather simple, but it's enough for this game. The plot is given through text - so there's a lot of reading and sometimes the game may seem slow. When traveling, you see only a black silhouette of your vehicle, and those are really inventive: steam cars, hovercrafts, mechanical elephants, walking cities, flying cities, submarines, rockets. One moment you are moving with the slow horse-caravan, next moment you are flying in a bird-like airship.
While one gameplay may be completed in about two hours, the number of adventures and places to see is enough many laps around the world. The game gets better with each playthrough.

30131941.review: Fantastic game with great replay value. It's good fun trying to figure out the fastest routes, or just exploring all the different storylines for the achievements. Now I really want to read the book!

30055380.review: Il merito più grande di [i]80 days[/i] non è tanto l'eredità fedele dello spirito del capolavoro di Verne, quanto la sua traduzione in un gameplay gradevole e stimolante, impegnativo ma non complesso. Non ci si può aspettare che un'avventura quasi esclusivamente testuale a scelte multiple conquisti il grande pubblico, complice anche la mancanza di localizzazione, ma dedicare del tempo ad [i]80 days[/i] significa onorare gli sforzi di un team di sviluppo che, una volta tanto, ha investito una cura del dettaglio maniacale su un progetto di nicchia.

30023455.review: A choose-your-own-adventure globe trotting delight set in a late 1800's alternate history steampunk world. Remember those scenes from Indiana Jones movies with the arrow line ping ponging across multiple cities on a world map...gamifiy that, add well executed prose, and you got 80 Days...based on Around the World in 80 Days by Jules Verne. Multiple playthroughs are encouraged as every route you can take offers up new adventures. After playing I can't help but want to sell everything I own and travel the world myself...and get in adventures.

29880576.review:
Bon, il y a longtemps que je souhaitais rédiger une évaluation sur ce jeu. Et, vu que mon colloc' pionce, j'ai le temps, alors je le fais. 

Tout d'abord, une note: 17/20? Quel est le barème, je ne sais pas, ne m'embêtez pas avec ça. Disons que c'est de la capacité de juger dans son état le plus pur. 

Blagues à part: je n'ai pas énormément de temps de jeu enregistré, mais c'est parce que chaque run doit être savouré dans toute la densité qu'il offre.

Alors, c'est une variante inspirée du Tour du monde en 80 jours de Jules Verne -jusqu'ici, on s'en serait douté, l'abruti que vous êtes en train de lire ne vous en apprend pas des masses sur le jeu que vous pourriez être amené à convoiter. Je vais essayer de faire plus intéressant. Le jeu est beau (vravo le beau), mais surtout extrêmement intéressant de par le gameplay qu'il propose. 

Intéressons-nous de plus près au gameplay: c'est une course contre la montre, exactement comme dans le livre, on part de Londres en incarnant ce bon vieux Passepartout, et on prend des décisions d'itinéraire en tâchant de garder son maître, et les finances de ce brave ploutocrate, en bonne forme. Et, exactement comme dans le livre, il faut arriver à faire le tour de la planète en 80 jours ou moins. Jusqu'ici rien que de très banal, me direz-vous: on se balade, on décide par où on se balade, et on essaie de gérer la montre, c'est comme un jeu de course mais en plus ennuyeux. Mais là où tout devient intéressant, c'est dans la littératité du gameplay. Késaco?, je n'en suis pas bien sûr moi-même, mais les concepts ça fait toujours bien. Non, sérieusement, on s'en moque pas mal de faire le tour du monde en 80 jours. On le fait, excellent, on a gagné! On ne le fait pas, tant pis, on doit tout de même rentrer à la maison. Alors on continue. Ce qui est intéressant c'est la génération d'une véritable histoire littéraire que ce jeu propose: les textes interactifs sont formidablement bien écrits -même s'ils demandent une pratique certaine de la langue de Shakespeare pour être correctement appréciés, et présentent de véritables enjeux vidéoludiques de surcroît que demande le peuple qui se prend pour ce qu'il n'est pas?

On se renseigne sur des itinéraires, on les parcourt en évitant quelques petits soucis -ou gros, c'est à voir-, on décide de faire des petites escales (même si le temps est compté) et tout ceci en écrivant littéralement de petites histoires qui ressemblent soit à des phases de dialogue à enjeu dans un RPG, soit à des mini-jeux de l'ère la plus primitive (rien d'insultant dans cet adjectif) du jeu-vidéo. De ces petites histoires, des nouvelles pistes à explorer pour l'histoire principale, ou bien des boni (pardonnez le pluriel latin, on parle littérarité dans un jeu vidéo là, oh!), soit des mali (même bail). Mais au final, rien de bien important, que de l'histoire et la jouissance littéraire certaine que le style de rédaction, très fluide, permet. 

Alors, pourquoi diable aller jouer à ça si on peut se contenter d'ouvrir un livre pour retrouver le même genre de plaisir? Eh bien, parce que c'est assez nouveau, assez inattendu, et, sans que je comprenne très bien pourquoi, c'est prenant! On a envie de jouer à cette chose! Et pas uniquement pour lire. Il y a là un vrai plaisir de découverte, une vraie volonté d'action, et puis tout est fait pour que l'on garde toujours la quête principale à l'esprit et que l'on ne puisse s'empêcher de se scalper quand on apprend qu'un chameau est tombé en panne alors qu'on faisait route vers le Yémen. 

A ceci s'ajoute un vrai effort d'invention de la part de l'équipe artistique -ça n'est clairement pas un jeu de codeur-. Derrière la démarche de "ludicisation" -ça existe? non? alley, osef- de l'univers littéraire de Jules Verne, il y a une réinterprétation de la véritable fascination du XIXéme pour la technologie et le progrès technique. On est donc dans une sorte d'univers, que je qualifierais de steampunkisant, où des machines étranges qui nous permettent de couvrir des distances hallucinantes en en un temps record côtoient des caravanes de chèvres, des animaux qui parlent, enfin bref, toute sorte de moyens de transport indispensables à quiconque adore exhiber son guide du Routard pour draguer l'hôtesse aux serviettes chaudes en first; ohlàlà, je digresse; et ça donne une véritable profondeur au gameplay, en plus d'ajouter un enjeu esthétique certain. 

En conclusion, c'est un très bon et très beau jeu. C'est esthétique, et cette même esthétique forge le gameplay par l'aléatoire et l'appréciation de l'intervalle qui fait la beauté du voyage.
Cependant, je ne le recommanderais pas à tout le monde. Beaucoup le trouveraient chiant. C'est largement compréhensible, moi non plus je n'aime pas les phases de dialogue quand je cherche de l'action. Pour celui qui est au courant qu'il n'y aura pas d'action: vous apprendrez à apprécier l'action que le texte peut contenir. 

Cette évaluation est donc bien plutôt destinée à orienter les intérêts qu'à faire honneur au jeu -et après relecture, je me rend compte que c'est heureux, parce qu'elle n'y arrive définitivement pas.

P.S. : Ah! Pourquoi 17/20 pour cette merveille alors? A lire le babil là, on se dit que ça devrait largement valoir un beau 20, même si c'est chiant, et gnagnagna... Beh, parce que le steampunk, je trouve ça d'une prétention châtiable. (Bah!, qu'il est prétentieux)

29655537.review:
A truly marvelous entertainment for distinguished gentlemen.

The game is all about options. Not only do you have to select your route from a number of onward trips, but each leg of your journey offers a narrative with dozens of choices - while sometimes it's just idle talk, often these choices linger with you on your adventure. You meet people who later help (or hold you back), you receive items that become important later etc. Thus each of your journeys becomes a unique one, and at first the game overwhelms you with this abundance of options. You replay it just to see what could have happened if you made a different choice in some place... and then make a different choice much, much earlier, derailing the adventure to a completely different route.

The narrative itself is excellent in form and content. Lots of micro-plots you encounter in your journeys have unexpected turns and sometimes you find yourself not in the place you intended to reach. The steampunk atmosphere is wonderful, it hits all the tropes of the genre, yet still feeling both genuine and creative. The amount of different contraptions, vehicles and mechanisms you see on your travels is surprising. Also, as you replay the game, you begin to value the political picture of the game's world. The nations are making wars and alliances, different organisations dabble into political affairs, and you start feeling to be a part of this grand scheme.

The main 80-day objective is relatively easy, you will most certainly hit it on your second playthrough. The real challenge, though, is the 40-day achievement, which seems impossible at first. It is much harder to nail and requires familiarising with the game, noting the fast routes and ways to make shortcuts or earn fast money.

I highly recommend this game, it is full of surprises and is quite entertaining at least for a dozen of playthroughs. I've made, like, forty playthroughs and still keep finding fun trips with narrative I haven't seen before.

29308409.review:
Based on the novel [i]Around the World in Eighty Days[/i] by Jules Verne, [i]80 Days[/i] takes place in the year 1872. You play as Frenchman Jean Passepartout, valet to the Englishman Phileas Fogg. Fogg has just made a wager of £20,000 that he can make a journey around the world in eighty days or less, beginning and ending in London. It is up to Passepartout as his valet to plan out this journey and try to win the bet.

This game is a combination of interactive fiction and some strategic management. The planning of the journey itself requires the most strategy in the game. You begin the journey with a set amount of funds and you have to figure out how to use that money for the best purposes. This means deciding what types of transportation to take as different types cost different amounts of money. There is also the aspect of inventory as you can buy items that might be useful to you on your trip or you can engage in some buying and selling to help fund the journey. All along the way, you have to keep an eye on the calendar if you hope to make it back to London on time and pay attention to Fogg's health.

Aside from management, the other major aspect of the game is the storytelling. All along the way, you have the opportunity to meet and talk to many different people from all over the globe and find yourself in different situations. Talking with people comes off as important aspect to your journey as well. Perhaps a stranger knows of certain routes that will make your trip shorter or offer tips on where the best places to sell items are. Although taking place in 1872, the game's story and design contains many steampunk-themed elements. Thus, you have talk of various types of warfare and civil unrest. The steampunk theme is also prevalent in the world such as some rather unconventional types of transportation available. There is the more standard things such as trains and ships, but you also have things like hovercraft and walking cities, all with that steampunk theme. If you like storytelling, there is a lot to enjoy in this game.

I also thought the game's graphics looked pretty good even with its minimalist design. You spend most of the game looking at a simplified map of the globe, but there are stylistic graphics depicting the various forms of transportation you use and destinations you visit.

Each journey you take can probably be completed in around three hours, though I imagine a single journey can take much more time depending on the decisions the player makes. I have only played around four trips so far, so my review is based on that experience.

For me, there are only a couple of negatives. The first is a complete lack of multiple saves. The game autosaves where you left off when you quit, but there is no option to have multiple games. I really fail to see why there is such an annoyance. The other major negative aspect that I came across is that it is possible for your journey to hit a dead-end with no possible way to continue and yet there is no indication in the game that this might happen. It is quite frustrating to play for two or more hours only to have to end the game in such a way.

Overall, while a couple of flaws might be annoying, I generally enjoyed the adventurous nature of this game. If you like interactive fiction with an adventure theme, you will probably enjoy this game.

29260444.review:
Took a chance on this game, not really knowing what to expect. I was pleasantly suprised.

What normally dulls my enthusiasm for adventure games is the lack of real player agency. Most hold you by the hand, tell you a story, and then after a few hours the credits roll. 80 Days avoids this problem with playthroughs that are comparatively short (1-2 hours, depending on how you play), but have plenty of paths to take and choices to make. Some of the routes are more linear, while others will take you in all sorts of unexpected directions, and all of them are impeccably narrated. I've done maybe 10 full playthroughs or so, and while I've seen plenty, there are still cities and stories I haven't discovered yet.

Though even the most open-ended adventure game eventually becomes repetitive. Some of the early and late game events have started to wear on me, so I may not turn over every stone, but by now I definitely feel like the game has given me my money's worth in excitement and entertainment.

The only complaint I have is a bug I have encountered a few times where the game clock would get stuck and I would be forced to restart. I haven't identified a cause or a fix, so it's rather vexing when it strikes while I'm having a good run. Not a dealbreaker, but still a glaring flaw in an otherwise perfect game.

29195197.review:
This game has the distinct feel of a "choose your own adventure" book, but with much more fluidity and variation from playthrough to playthrough. The differences from game to game can be subtle or glaring, ranging between your starting supplies, which cities the Orient Express happens to run through, or whether or not you are granted the opportunity to go on an expidition to the moon! After the 5th or 6th time playing through, I realized that there's an option to go through the North Pole! How's that for a shortcut? (Also, if you can, do that. Some of the game's best writing lies down that path.)

The feel of the game is perfect. Since the clock is always ticking, you feel like you have to weigh careful planning with expediency, which can end up forcing you down paths you might not expect! The differing routes and methods of travel from game to game keep this feeling fresh after multiple runs.

The game captures the feel of 19th century penny dreadfuls perfectly, with swashbuckling adventure and outlandish (if somewhat campy) secrets in pretty much every run. Plus the writing is immensely good. If you like "choose your own adventure" style games at all, this game should be at the top of your wish list.

29161033.review:
Enjoyable interactive fiction.
Graphics, sound and music are not great but they get the job done.

One playthrough takes about 2(ish) hours, and each time you play things will be (slightly) different.
Depending on how much you like the game the full price may be too much for you, but get it on sale and you'll get your money's worth.

Some, rather minor, 'issues' ...

Personally I don't like that game time ticks away in the background (1 second real time equals 1 minute game time).
For example you plan a route, then have to rearrange your luggage ... and the train/whatever departs while you're doing that. Or you're deciding wether you want to converse or ... damn ... too late.

Also it's probably me ... but I didn't know you could advance time until quite late in my first play through.
I can't understand why the fast-forward icon is not visible all te time (it becomes visible when you hover over the clock).
Hiding user interface objects when there's no need to hide them is bad UI design.

Date/time is mentioned in three ways; the day of your journey, weekdays, and 'in X days'. Date/time shown in an open 'depart'-block does not refresh when it should. In short you constantly need to figure out if for example 'in 2 days' means tomorrow (since a day has already passed but the info has not refreshed) or the day after. 
I'd like for date/time to be consistently mentioned as day X, time Y of your journey.

Great adventures await in this steampunk version of "80 days".

Will you be able to go around the world in 80 days? How much will you compromise for it? Or will it be really be what you really wish to do, as Passepartout, once your trip starts with your Master, Monseiur Fogg? All you need is a map, some items in your suitcase, and eagerness to discover the world.

The game is really replayable, since you won't be able to visit most cities until you have completed it several times, and most of them have several histories within, even linked between cities around the world. Expect a lot of text, fast decision making at times (though you can zoom out while in a conversation to check your itinerary if you wish), and to be hooked up.

28780570.review:
Pretty unique game (or at least I haven't played too many this type of games). There is something very cool and charming about this games but there's also few issues.

Pros:
-The journey: It's pretty epic and there's always things waiting to happen you probably can't expect and it keeps you kinda on your toes the whole game. The first playthrough is pretty much for you to understand the purpose of the game and various mechanics and after that you are probably smarter to try again this time actually managing to go from London to London in 80 days.

-Replay Value: Even though the 1 trip from London to London takes maybe 3 to 4 hours depending on how many days it'll  last and how much time you do on planning and thinking the next possible route it still has a lot of replay value. There's 160 (if I remember correctly) cities to visit and (I assume) thousands of options to go across the globe so I can imagine this game to be at least worth of 20 hours of playtime (or 5 to 6 playthroughs).

-Intelligent: This game challenges you to take calculated risks and think few steps forward. It's pretty uncommon these days and I found myself enjoying in this aspect in the first playthrough (even if it took +120 days to get to London). There's always challenges waiting for you that you didn't confront the first playthrough and it even challenges you to do the around the world trip faster than 40 days (steam achievement).

-Jules Verne References: There's many references to Jules Verne's books maybe because "Around the World in 80 Days" is one of those books. I don't want to spoil anything more but all those who are familiar with Verne's novels there will be lots of "fan service".

-Something Fresh and Different: This game truly is something fresh and different and maybe that is the biggest thing I enjoyed it the most.


Cons:
- You need to read a lot: There is lots of reading you need to do through the game. Because there is no voice acting you need to read shit loads of text... I don't know if it's a bad thing or not (though for some it might be). For me it's not a bad thing but I don't like it that much either. I mean it can be a bit exhausting because the pacing of the game is kinda fast.

-It's a mobile game: To be honest that's what it is. I can imagine it's a bit more enjoyable to play with PC but it's still pretty much just a port of a "mobile game". Though this could be pretty good way to spend time on a plane playing this game!

-There's luck (or is there): Sometimes it feels that somethings (specially when playing blind playthrough) are happening because of luck.. 'cause no matter how much you made yourself think your next route it just might shit on your face and the "non logical route choice" were probably better one. And that's sometimes pretty demoralizing. But if you think of it it's the late 1800's so anything could happen in your journey around the world.

I paid 4,99€ on this and I'm pretty happy that I did. It's pretty fresh experience and maybe it's NOT something new but at least it's something different. If you think you might enjoy this I recommend of buying it. Then it surely should be at least worth the 5$/€

28625561.review:
Another amazing game by Inkle - same guys who did the awesome Sorcery! remake for mobile, and quite possibly the best choose-your-own-adventure style game company out there (and deservedly so). 

As a fan of steampunk, history, Jules Verne, Fallen London / Sunless Sea, and text-based adventures this one hit all the right buttons for me. :)

Basically, a re-imagining of the famous 80 Days Around The World classic by Mr. Verne and set in an alternative Steampunk inspired age. You are Passepartout, and your job is to guide the indefatigable Mr. Fogg around the world so that he can win his bet within 80 days.

+ The writing is SUPERB and absolutely on point (enough to rival Failbetter Games imho), and the lore is detailed and well done. 

+ Good replayability, there are a lot of various routes to take all with their own stories to tell. That, and new events and storylines can unlock/appear in future playthroughs. 

+ There are a lot of hidden secrets and stories which add a lot of depth to the story and lore.

+ Achievements are well done here as a lot of them are actually based on discovering and completing storylines - and there are quite a lot of them!

+ Interesting take on the travel mechanics, and yet simple enough to learn - adds a good dose of simple (but tricky) strategy as you need to plan your routes and timing.

+ Simple but gorgeous art and sound. 

- After quite a few playthroughs most of the main locations can become somewhat monotonous. That said, this would only be after you played it several times - and some alternatives do appear to break it up.

All in all, i enjoyed myself immensely. :)

27786139.review:
inkle took their in-house storytelling engine, found a well known early Sci-Fi novel in the public domain and built a branching, highly replayable and engagingly written adventure around the world driven by choice and circumstance. There's a surprising degree of gameplay depth as management of money, time, trade goods and key character items plays an integral role in how each trip takes shape, along with your input as Passepartout influencing everything from inner monologues to personality traits and unforseen story threads to pursue. 

Passing through new destinations, discovering new means of travel and taking in the local flavor text reveals intricate, well researched and fantastical world building that isn't tied to the page yet remains true to the voice of the author. The game has a clean visual look that uses color and static silhouettes effectively but it's a mobile port so set expectations accordingly. A new UI for the PC release would have been nice but the story scope has been expanded over time, and while some repetition is unavoidable after dozens of hours on multiple platforms there's still plenty to uncover.

An exciting approach to literary adaptation for the medium. If Carmen Sandiego and Choose Your Own Adventure books were your jam, this is where it's at.

27560039.review:
[h1] DISCLAIMER: This is a full review, and NOT a first impressions review like all my other reviews, if you want a better full review, then please read better reviews then mine [/h1]

[quote] PLEASE NOTE: This review is being cast as a full review and not a first impressions review because the main bulk of the game is finished, although 80 Days does have a story mode, this review is being cast as full because the main bulk of the game is complete, so please, think before you comment! Enjoy :) [/quote]

80 Days is a game developed by inkle Studios (known for the Sorcery! series) and ported from the original mobile port by Cape Guy Ltd. and is based on Jules Verne's classic: Around the World in 80 Days

After travelling the world once, I literally felt as if I'd experienced an epic trip around the world and I can recall all the craziness and wild adventures as if they were real memories, the game is very immersive

The writing is masterfully done writing and the story (which is based off Jules Verne's book) is really good, and just feels incredibly immersive and a great balance of strategy and story-telling with lots of classic literature easter eggs to be found

The gameplay consists of you playing a servant in 1872 but with a steampunk twist. You are the servant of Phileas Fogg as he takes a bet that he can travel the world in 80 days or less, you make text-based decisions about how you want to interact with people and situations and where you want to go. 80 Days also has heavy strategy elements because a large part of your success depends on how you plan out your route around the world. There is also an economy element of balancing your funds through buying and selling items, among other things

However, 80 Days has ;ots of reading and is not for the impatient, thankfully you can change the text speed from slower to faster. Originally, 80 Days was built for mobile, but enough has been added/tweaked to merit the more expensive Steam purchase

80 Days takes Jules Verne's Around the World in 80 Days and makes it into an interactive wild ride!

[h1] RECOMMENDED :) [/h1]

26584044.review:
This is one of those 'neutral' reviews which we can not make on Steam, though because my feelings tend to be more negative than the other way around, I'm going with the red thumbs down.

80 days looks pretty groovy, the UI and grahpics which might not be AAA still struck a chord with me. As did the fact that this is one of those 'story telling games' where your decisions determine the path you're going to take, and thus how the story continues.

However the problem arises when the decisions you make, aren't actually all that interesting. As opposed to making the player wonder how their decision pans out, it gives you an uninteresting outcome. Which then makes you not really care about any forthcoming decision making. As mentioned in another review, this game is very wordy. I don't really see that as a problem, however it is when it isn't captivating me with those words. And that's what's happening in 80 days, throughout the game.

The only time I felt my decisions gave me a satisfying outcome, was when at the end of my game I was faced with starting a mutiny on a boat. The mutiny failed, however that was the only time where I felt the story I was 'creating' was grabbing me. And that was well at the end of the 80 days time period. So everything before that: meh.

Which brings me to a complaint that was brough up by another reviewer. This isn't a game you're supposed to finish in 1 playthrough. You're supposed to do things differently and learn from prior games, to be able to make that 80th day deadline. However the only time where I learned to do something differently in a next game, was again with the mutiny scenario. And I wasn't going to make it even if it had succeeded. There's no real learning point, as you don't really know what you did wrong, other than try a different path. And there are loads of those.

But then we're back at the game's scenarios and decisions not really being engaging, and after 1 play through I didn't feel like doing it all over again. I can see 80 days being a good game to other people, as it's not really 'bad'. However I personally wouldn't recommend it to everybody. Hence the neutral/negative conclusion.

26126643.review:
So, this was recommended to me after enjoying the four parts of Peter Jackson's Sorcery!. However, unlike Sorcery! I did not enjoy this one as much. I am sure there is a plethora and depth to this game that I barely scratched with my 5 hours of playthrough, but I was not satisfied with the story telling or gameplay. 

I went through one playthrough, made it 61 days through the north pole which I felt confident afterwards that may have been one of the easier runs perhaps since much of it was standing still waiting for something to happen with little decision or choices to make. There was some cool story telling at times, but the dialogue as an American player felt like I was trying to understand European culture or at least UK English to understand certain "ways of life." There were quite a few words that I never use or have rarely seen in my lifetime and I don't account that for a lack of education, but just not understanding the certain style of the European language used to make the game.

To top it off, right as I got to day 30ish and into the artic the game started to eat away at my CPU taking 98%-100% power at a time. Noteworthy, I never ran into the issue in any Sorcery! game and this is a 5k desktop computer; I run much more demanding games than this title. I tried to google a fix, but found nothing besides restarting; which I begrudging was worried that the game wouldn't save so I just slogged through it which probably added another 20-30 mins.

The difference I feel with Sorcery! and 80 Days is two things. The story telling and the mechanics. For the story telling it is lightly flavored text and only mixed with some small story based on where you travel; like the artic had a short arc as well as each city if you stayed there, but after all was said and done, that was it. You are here or traveling there for a bit and you move on to the next location; nothing felt meaningful. There were light dialogue options to choose from, but not all of them felt like they had weight; sure, some helped "us" live in the artic, but I think I could have easily done it without any item or any dialogue assistance. (Maybe the medicine was the only choice that was key for survival. Not sure though).

And the mechanics, like the story telling, is also very light. There are small interactions with inventory and money management, but I never used the bank once. I sold one item for about 8k and came back with 4k (and the 20k prize). I never felt short on cash. I also could never tell what the Figg/Fogg guy thought of me really. I tried to look for a stat screen but was unable to find one that incorporated it.

Overall, it’s a quick adventure and that’s it. I am sure there are optimal routes and other cool short stories to read, but Sorcery! was built on the foundation of Peter Jackson's novels. They only thing that Inkle had to do was to build a foundation of a game with playable mechanics that would match the novels. This game showed a difference in focus where half was for story and the other for mechanics. And it turns out to be a light adventure game set in a steam punk 1800s worlds. But this isn't the game for me and can't recommend the title like I can for Sorcery!

26122026.review: Basically a choose your own adventure type story. The interest entirely comes from the really fascinating setting and the stories that get told through it. There are so many different paths, cities, items, people, so many different ways to play through it. Because of the map there are a few "bottlenecks" that you're going to see most games but most of the game you have a ton of different choices. Random events and your own choices mean there's often new stories even in places you've been through multiple times before. There's the occassional annoyance (eg getting given items in events that don't fit in your luggage, iirc it means other stuff gets chucked) but it's best not to worry and just focus on the story, which is really well written and really gives a lot of room for your own interpretations and thinking through the implications of it without leaving things out or being mysterious. Really great game.

oh where do i start. this game is a masterpiece. i played this on ipad first and since i spent a good half of my childhood reading jules vernes books this was an instant buy for me. this is the kind of game you open up on a cold rainy winter night and do a full playtrough as you sink into the epic stories put in. this is the kind of game you play to relax and take everything in. the soundtrack the story all the interactions just... i cant even talk about it without getting chills

25965151.review:
80 Days, basato su "Il giro del mondo in 80 giorni" di Verne, rappresenta una delle migliori avventure testuali degli ultimi anni. Estremamente complesso e profondo nelle meccaniche, consente al giocatore di creare il proprio viaggio attorno al globo, passando per centinaia e centinaia di città e possibilità, per fare ritorno a Londra entro il tempo limite.

Il titolo è solo apparentemente banale e semplice, in quanto bisogna dosare molto bene risorse e tempo a disposizione nelle varie città, per ottenere un passaggio con un determinato mezzo. Inoltre vi consiglio di comprare il gioco solo se si conosce l'inglese molto, molto, molto bene, dato che il titolo è costituito solo da dialoghi, talvolta anche con termini arcaici, e una scelta sbagliata può inficiare del tutto un viaggio.

Notevole anche il comparto grafico, molto pulito ed elegante nella sua semplicità, con ottime caratterizzazioni di città e personaggi. E' dunque un titolo imperdibile per gli amanti del genere e per chi mastichi alla perfezione l'inglese; per gli amanti delle sfide poi, cercare di toccare ogni singolo luogo del pianeta potrebbe garantire decine e decine di ore di gioco.

25785657.review:
80 Days feels like a mixture of a boardgame, a choose-your-own-adventure book and interactive fiction. It has atmosphere in spades, and a huge replayability value. It's not for the impatient, as there's a lot of reading to be done. It's not just an interactive story, however, as there is plenty of strategy involved: picking your route, managing your funds and inventory,  deciding what to do in each location and so on, and so on.

As in the Verne stories, Fogg makes a wager and attemps an around the world trip with Passepartout, his valet. There are a lot of added elements that make Verne's world into a steampunkish alternate reality dreamscape, that's occasionally hilarious and sometimes very dark. The writing is of very high quality, and even re-doing the same segments in multiple playthroughs doesn't feel like a chore, partially because there are multiple ways to deal with nearly everything.

The game also makes good use of Steam's achievement system. There are lots of achievements for finding various events found in the game, and dealing with them properly. It really helps keep the game alive, and getting 100% will keep one occupied for a long time.

80 Days is a masterpiece and a steal at this price (10€ at the time of writing).

25734925.review:
80 days - To travel around the world, west to east from London to London. In what is a story based game about adventuring, route optimization, wondrous stories and relaxing rides through an alternate 1872 as the valet to a well known gentleman who has made a wager.
Along the way you will need to manage funding, items, packing, and selecting the routes to follow. It sounds simple, but it is complex enough to keep you busy.

To get it out of the way, yes, this is phone game. Do not let that scare you off, all it truly means for you as a PC gamer is that even your most outdated toaster can run it, the controls are simple and they do not need to be any more complex to do what you need to do. Game mechanics themselves do not suffer either, with a great majority of your options being simple choices in dialogue. Choices that actually do matter many times, with stories to tell you that I found surprisingly pleasant and interesting to read. 

You can embark on an adventure and enjoy a richly filled world while balancing your own interest at exploration and your task as valet to keep monsieur Fogg in good condition and comfortable, on track to win his wager. It is not difficult to make it in 80 days if you try and plan things out in advance, but often there will be opportunities and potential rewards just a little off your chosen path. A lot of tempting things can drag you out to somewhere you didn't intend and it can both be a great boon to your funds and travel time or a disaster. With every city and most travel lines in the game having their own or connected stories, you will need multiple playthroughs to see them all. And even then it may not be likely unless you actively try. 
Losing is alright as well. The wager won't bankrupt you, and you will be able to just try again. After all, why bet only once? A playthrough will take about an hour, perhaps a bit more or less depending on how much of a rush you are in.

But then there are some things that you should probably not get very hyped about either. Racing other people? Live multiplayer feed? Unless you actively go looking on the map for them, you likely won't find others except near the start. Even then, there is no interactions with them and I have yet to notice any sort of multiplayer feed. At best there are some icons on the map of where others went before you, and some things you aren't told and have to find out the hard way(Leaving a train at a midway stop when you have a ticket to the final destination of the train voids your ticket. You aren't allowed to get back on with the next train passing by. Some routes don't let you resume at all if you buy only a partway ticket, and so on)
The game is surprisingly easy to break as well, crashing or freezing if you try to do too much at once. A good autosave system helps with this, so you likely won't have issues- Just start it back up and you're back to where you were.
But in the end, these are small issues that don't actually hold it back. 

80 days is a great game that tells you a story, while giving you full control over the story it tells, with excellently fitting graphics and amazingly done mood setting. Its flaws are few and easily forgivable, with a very competitive price to make it definitely a worthwhile buy.

25731076.review:
When I grew up I believe I managed to read every book by Jules Verne that was available at the local library, including mostly forgotten titles such as The Purchase of the North Pole and Dr. Ox’s Experiment, but the favourite one was Around the World in Eighty Days. Hence, I felt great excitement when I had a chance to play the game 80 Days which is based on that book. The game started with a spinning globe with a number of cities marked, but I noticed immediately that it is spinning in the wrong direction. I saw that as a bad sign, that maybe the game lacked attention to details (such as having the sun rising in the west), but apart from that bad mistake I found 80 Days to be extremely enjoyable.

The story starts very abrupt. You play as Passepartout, the valet of a certain Phileas Fogg who has just made a wager to travel around the world in 80 days, and you have to pack a bag in a hurry in order to get on the evening train to Paris before you even know how to play the game. Already on this first train it is clear that the 1872 in this game is much more steam-punk than the real version of 1872. The world is rapidly changing thanks to fantastic machines and strong empires are growing everywhere around the world. This makes the journey difficult to plan since you do not really know which routes are more convenient than others. The first time I played the game I actually managed to return to London in the afternoon on the 80th day, so I beat the game immediately. However, there were so many adventures and encounters along the way that I wanted to follow up on, and so many more wonderous places in the world I wanted to explore, so I needed to play the game again, and again, and again.

80 Days is more an interactive story than a game, but since there are so many choices available it does not feel restricted. The writing is excellent. It is condensed, but still it manages to be both detailed and evocative. The characterisations of the multitude of characters encountered are made with finesse, and the adventures along the jorney often takes unexpected turns. In fact, the writing is actually the only really good thing in this game, but it is so good that it defines the game. I really enjoy 80 Days.

The majority of my time put into 80 Days has been spread out over a long period of time because its the only one of these games where I know for a fact its going to be something completely different than before. And not just because the guns and maps are randomized like FTL, but because I will choose to play differently. The brilliant thing about this game is that you don't have to go crazy out of your way to have a completely different experience. You choose one route you haven't gone on before, and all of a sudden you're in a rocket ship bound for the ♥♥♥♥in MOON, or in a walking city a la the spider from Wild Wild West. I mean come on. Even achievement hunting is natural because you want to see all the different parts of this quirky little world for yourself and they act as a little guide to all the places you haven't been yet. So buy this game if you like having fun and don't mind a little light reading. Cause books are for suckers.

25461720.review:
80 Days is a pretty enjoyable game overall. There is a lot of flexibility with regards to the routes the player can choose to get across the world (some of which I would even call cheating when it comes to circumnavigating the globe. I mean, the north pole? really?)

You control Phileas Fogg's valet, Passepartout, and you have to keep your master happy during the journey, which means buying warm clothes for winter conditions, booking hotels, providing entertainment, and scouting out information from locals.

The interactions can often be really interesting, and there are plenty of fun easter eggs in the game, many of which I've not yet found. The vast range of Steam achievements I still need will keep me coming back to 80 Days to try out new routes and to try and beat my globetrotting record.

25396885.review: A most charming game, whose stories demand repeat adventures and whose gameplay allows replayability.

25395407.review:
80 Days presents a simple but unique premise for a game: to make an interactive variant of Jules Vernes' "Around the World in Eighty Days".
Players take on the role of Passerpartout, assuming his roles of planning out each leg of the journey, managing finances, and making sure that Master Fogg is in good spirits. Choices are a crucial part of the gameplay, as the player's actions not only effect the immediate consequences, but also add up across their journey as a whole, making no two playthroughs exactly the same. This alone adds a great deal of replay value, but the large amounts of text and minimal graphics might not appeal to everyone, and some may only be satisfied just finishing the game once.

I quite enjoyed making many trips around the world in this game, but truthfully, I can only seriously recommend it to those with interests in geography or classical literature.

FINAL GRADE: B+

25383323.review:
The Read-A-Game genre is already too full. This is a fact in evidence. That being said, this game is good enough to push a whole shelf of Hatoful Boyfriends and Cinderses into a circular file for. Subtle to the point of obtuseness, its core purpose hides like a cat, leaping out to swat at you and leaping back in before you can really get a handle on it. To fully understand the setting's meaning and your place within it, or even the full breadth of your own character, you'll be many playthroughs in, but to simply have wonders to gape at a few hours will give plenty to see.

One thing worth noting, though, is that actually winning the wager is meaninglessly easy. The only way to lose is to intentionally wander off; any course that points vaguely eastward will get you there in 70 days or less. There is no challenge to be had whatsoever unless you go for the 50- and 60-day achievements, and those who come in looking for a game about finding a way to get Around the World In, say, 80 Days will find themselves disappointed.

25300043.review:
While rather basic in gameplay, I find myself very much wanting to recommend this game for various reasons including its storyline and its immersive steampunk napoleonic setting. If you are in any way a fan of "around the world in 80 days" or if you are intrigued by the thought of travelling the world in an 1800's steampunk world, then I strongly recommend this game to you as you will find a lot to enjoy.

When it comes to gameplay, there is an aspect of money management which involves buying low and selling high in different places, and then choosing an appropriate mode of travel between each location (fast, comfortable and expensive, or slow, uncomfortable and cheap), You have to keep your master happy but also remain responsible with his/your funds throughout the journey. Despite this, the games primary focus is the text-based character interactions and the thoughts and descriptions of the player character when visiting new cities and travelling in different interesting vehicles. The game also features several dialogue choice segments which can influence what other people think of you and your masters opinion of you.

While I have not yet made it all the way around the world in either of my playthroughs (It takes probably a good 3 hours to do so), I find myself frequently wanting to come back to it but rarely end up gettting around to it, hense my fairly low play time. This game is a delight to play if you are in a lazy mood and want a chilled out but entertaining experience that will last an hour or two until you put it aside for next time. Furthermore, this game has a fair amount of replay value as you are able to choose your own journey (you will not get to visit every city / country in one playthrough due to your 80 day / turn time constraint). All in all, as far as casual games go. i give this an 8/10.

25266866.review: Huge replay value, amazing storytelling-gameplay convergence, brilliant writing, and you can probably pick it up in a sale for less than £4. No reason not to buy this.

25263081.review: I was quite pleasantly surprised by this.  I expected to pick it up for a half an hour or so and maybe come back to it later, but I did a complete run instead.  It sets out to capture the spirit of adventure and sheer character of the novel, and I think it succeeds very well.  The writing and pathing of the different routes and decisions is great. The art is simple but effective and unobtrusive.  I found myself becoming really invested in what I was doing and how I was planning the next day or week of the journey.  Also, the incorporation of more sci-fi elements into the world of the game made the adventure that much more fun for me.  I don't know if I'll change my tune after another pass around, but for now I'd have to say that this game is great.  Had a blast.

24940632.review:
The "choose your own adventure" genre is really interesting: in its original form (printed on a book, that is), it was fun for the first few tries, but you could get tired of the lack of interactivity, even though it offered more than one path to follow, which was already more than traditional books.
As a game genre, you can introduce more elements to the story and add a layer of gameplay to make your choices matter even more and really immerse you in the adventure.
In 80 days, you play as Passepartout, Phileas Fogg's valet, in an adaptation of Jules Verne's classic novel.
How much does the story differ from the original one? Well, I won't go into details because this is a spoler-free review, but the world is completely different from the one in the book (and from real life history at the time). The main theme is steampunk, as you will encounter various wondrous machines, contraptions and robots throughout your adventures.
The writing is witty and immediate, with a focus on the character's thoughts (he is, supposedly, writing on his diary), so it never gets too heavy or boring but doesn't skim over important parts of the plot and adds nice details to make the world come alive.
The art style can be described as "inky", with a focus on blacks and shadows. My only issue with the visuals is the fact that the 3D globe is a little too shiny, and sometimes you can even confuse the land with the sea because of the lack of clear, defined lines. It would be nice to have a way to change the color of the land and the sea to better suit the player's needs. The game runs absolutely fine, and it will do so on pretty much all machines.
The sound is limited to ambient sounds and some background music, but it does help you focus on what's going on in the story.
Gameplay wise, apart from the multiple choices, you also have to manage your budget, plan your trip to the next city, buy and sell items (some of which help you during challenging weather conditions), keep Fogg alive and, of course, make it back to London within 80 days (although the game does not end if you fail to do so, you always make it there eventually).
80 Days is not too difficult (as far as I've seen there's no true failure state), but it does offer a challenge in the form of indirect multiplayer with other Passepartous around the world.
The game is both turn-based and real-time: the hours of the day pass by as you wait, but you have to take some set routes from one city to the other.
Overall, I really enjoyed this game and I'm probably going to buy anything Inkle makes if the quality remains this high.
Sorcery, their other narrative-driven game series, is also really good, so if you enjoyed 80 days you'll most likely love that one as well.

24804914.review:
80 Days is bar none the most sublime video game reinterpretation of classic literature I'm aware of. It's a travel game/choose your own adventure version of Jules Verne's [i]Around the World in Eighty Days[/i] with writing that's not only engaging for the player, but [url=http://www.pcgamer.com/the-case-for-giving-players-less-control-and-npcs-more]actively flouts player agency at times[/url], and in the process does a very good job of presenting a larger living world beyond the player's reach. It's only fitting: you are after all just the valet of a man whose mere whim has you both traveling around the world, where you are in turn subjected to much larger twists of fate.

It's heavy on the reading of course, but rather light as a game, and there's generally no reloading saves if you click a choice you didn't mean to. For a globe-trotting game, its graphics toe the line between stylishly minimal and plain austere. I still highly recommend it for literary and adventurous types.

24684382.review:
As someone who has not read the book, this game has given me a profound appreciation for it. This game, though not terribly long, instills that age-old feeling of seeing the world and experiencing new things. I was expecting a slog, I was expecting it to be terribly boring as it seemed like a text game, but I found myself enamoured with it completely. 
I had several moments I legitimately regretted not being able to do, from the jewel trades of the orient to trying to rekindle the romance of the woman from Mongolia, to the mutiny of San Francisco. The world was fashionable and entertaining and retained that incredibly important feeling of adventure.
I found glee in both being a good valet, and a bad valet, I found myself both sympathetic to forign governments with their armies of machine men and to the revolution in the heart of a woman found in the snow, nearly dying. 
You get to have really divisive moments where you can choose to show your humanity or retain the steely veneer of a professional Valet. 
This is a game I would let my kid play to not only allow them an understanding of geography & risk-taking but to give them an understanding of the scope of our world. This is a great, game, maybe not Game of the Year, but a damn good game to sit down and feel the wind in your hair and rekindle the sense of passion one would feel from travel.

A very interactive and engaging spin on the visual novel genre, 80 Days brings a lot of replayability into the mix through the sheer number of possible routes and events you can take in this reimagining of Jules Verne's classic Around the World in 80 Days.

You play as Passepartout, the valet and are charged with planning the journey and scrounging up funds through smart buying and selling of various items across the world. The setting is sort of an alternate history full of steampunk influences and creative vehicle designs. 24345454.review:
Pretty solid visual novel/text adventure-type game with time & money management mixed in. Better suited/designed for mobile/handheld but works fine on PC.

You start in London and then slowly make your way east through a variety of cities. It seems like each of the many cities are uniquely described and you often meet interesting personalities who can hinder or help your progress.

There is a steampunk aspect to it (a lot of mechanical contraptions, robots/androids, artificers' guilds) and alternate history type of things that clearly distinguish this world from the real history. So the most education you'll get is geography (learning where cities are located), the rest is flavored/inspired by the real world but not something you should take seriously.

My favorite part of the game was finding and dealing with the events that occurred. Sometimes events can have different outcomes when you bring items from previous locations (like the Artificer's Medallion).

You have four options in most (but not all) cities: Market, Bank, Explore, and Sleep/Depart. The Market is where you buy and sell items. The Bank is where you can withdraw money after waiting a period of time. Explore is used to find routes out of the city. Sleep/Depart is to move to the next day or view routes out of the city.

Items come in four varieties: Travel items to keep Fogg in good shape while travelling under certain conditions, Conversation items that allow you to ask more questions about routes, Commodity items that sell well in certain cities, and Route Maps that show available routes in a region.

You have three options that can appear during travel: News/Wait, Converse, and Attend. News brings up a one-line headline on world events that usually doesn't affect travel. Converse is where you talk to learn about routes and destinations and use Conversation items. Attend raises Fogg's satisfaction with your service and his health by a few points.

Some other notes:[list][*]Travelling uses only city names (no country/region) so you might want to have wikipedia/google open to refer to unfamiliar cities.
[*]Feels nice to see your route and spin the globe around at the end.[/list]

Worth a look if you enjoy VNs/text-based adventure games.

As a word to the wise: pick a route and stick with it.  Sometimes being impatient over a day's wait can cost you more time than simply waiting it out.  I made choices based solely on alacrity ... and finished instead to the tune of a 110 day trip!  Suffice it to say there is greater depth to the game than you would expect a choose-your-own-adventure to have.

24209750.review:
When I picked this game up in a Humble Bundle, I really didn't expect it to be so addictive! I was anticipating mildly interesting interactive fiction, and what I got was a smart, funny reimagining of Verne's novel, packed with interesting characters and seemingly infinite possibilities. I love the steampunk elements - they feel true to the spirit of the original, if not to the letter of it - and the development of Passepartout as a character is excellent. The writing is very rich, and there are some truly affecting moments. 

Thanks to the ever-ticking clock you can't explore everything in one game, but every playthrough offers glimpses of possible adventures that you can seek out next time. Every time I finish a journey I want to start again and see what happens if I do something a bit differently - explore a new route, build different relationships, pursue a new achievement.  I've got so involved with this game that I still haven't got round to installing the game I actually bought the Humble Bundle to acquire...

24122455.review:
80 Days
Or, more aptly, "Around the World in 80 Days".

This game is fun. Set in a steampunk 1700s (?) world, in which the artificers guild has amazing contraptions that can help you get around the world, you play Passeporteau (spelling?), the French serving man to a wealthy English gentleman. He made a twenty-thousand pound bet that he could get around the world in 80 days, and it's you're job to accomplish that.

You can go just about any way you like, through just about any cities you desire, in your attempt to race around the globe. You have to manage your money, and your Monseur's health, in order to complete the trip. Buy and sell goods to keep the income flowing, or visit a bank, and never look back. The artwork is fantastic and the music is simple and charming.

The one thing I really didn't like about this game was the... what's the word. Dialogue? Monologue? Thought processes?
I don't know what to label it. The game is told past tense, through the Diary of Passeporteau. By selecting his conversation options/choices in the diary, you tell the story that is told in the Diary. A very interesting and fun mechanic. However, You play as the servant and only the servant, and you directly make all the decisions in the game, yet there are several points in the game where it directly contradicts this. For example, if attempting to go to the North Pole, you'll ask your Monseur why he wants to go there, and he'll say that that was the plan all along. Despite the fact that YOU (as Passeporteau) made the decision to go north.

Overall, though, it does not detract from the enjoyment of the game.

9/10 - Would play again (already have played 4 times.)

Will your master enjoy a sea voyage on a freight liner?  Will you make new friends...or enemies?  You better hurry and find out!

23999060.review:
[h1] Kurze Zusammenfassung [/h1]

80 Days ist ein Visual Novel das sich an Jule Vernes 80 Tage um die Welt - Geschichte lehnt. Wir befinden uns dabei in der Rolle des treuen Begleiters des Protagonisten Mr. Fogg - der nach einer Wette 80 Tage Zeit hat die Welt zu erkunden. 


[+]
■ man könnte das Spiel wieder und wieder spielen, ohne das es den selben Verlauf bekäme, es ist jedes Mal anders
■ sehr viel Story
■ englischsprachig 
■ du kannst zumindest Items kaufen/verkaufen und je nach Gebiet ändert sich die Höhe der Summe für dieses Item
■ je nach Tageszeit kann man entscheiden wohin die Reise gehen soll
■ auch stehen einem verschiedene Gesprächsoptionen zur Verfügung auch wenn nicht jede Unterhaltung einen Sinn ergibt oder uns näher ans Ziel bringt
■ man kann das Spiel jederzeit beenden und ist beim erneuten spielen noch genau an der Stelle, bei der man das Spiel zu letzt verlassen hat

[-]
■ Visuell hat es nicht sehr viel zu bieten
■ es ist demotivierend sich ständig um Mr. Fogg zu kümmern - ist unser Charakter ein hauseigener Sklave?!
■ die Städte haben alle zwar andere Hintergrundbilder aber ansonsten passiert optisch nicht viel. Es ist halt wirklich mehr zum lesen gedacht~


[h1] Fazit [/h1]

Zum ab und an lesen kann das Spiel ganz interessant sein, aber so stundenlanges lesen kann dann auch irgendwann ermüdent werden. Trotzdem ist es nicht schlecht und man hat viele Entscheidungsmöglichkeiten, dafür einen Daumen hoch!

23907223.review:
Jak na grę narracyjną, wiele tu rozgrywki i to niezwykle przyjemnej. Poza naprawdę ładną grafiką oraz muzyką dane nam jest przeżyć setki różnych przygód, zależnie od wybranego przez nas miejsca i reakcji na sytuację. Możliwości są niezliczone. Co zaskakuje, w tę grę chce się grać kilkakrotnie, nie ma się chęci pominięcia danych fragmentów, bo, poza samouczkiem, nieczęsto się one powtarzają.
Postacie są zapamiętywalne, choć jedynie dwie z nich jest nam dane poznać bliżej – protagonistę, którego losami kierujemy i Phileasa Fogga, któremu usługujemy jako lokaj. Łącząca ich relacja, choć zmieniać się może na wiele sposobów, za każdym razem jest bardzo swoista i nieschematyczna.
Grę dostałam w Budle'u i nie spodziewałam się, że spodoba mi się bardziej niż ta, dla której owego Bundle'a kupiłam, ale powiem jedno:
Zupełnie warto!

The game did crash on me a couple times, and while it was annoying to have to restart the game, it was definitely helpful that the game auto-saves itself so frequently; upon each restart, I was immediately back to the exact point where I had been cut off.
