23738580.review:
Frustrating. The idea is you are playing through Jules Verne's book Around the World in 80 Days, but as Phineas Fogg's valet, which is an odd choice but not bad. You choose routes from city to city, hopping or crawling your way across the various continents. If you make it back in 80 days, well, I don't know because I didn't make it either time. If you don't, the game rather lamely laments and starts you over again. 

The first playthrough was fine. I made obvious mistakes, but did well on money. I narrowly missed the 80 day mark (arriving in around 86 days), but I saw it coming and understood based on some of the circuitous routes I ended up taking in pursuit of good market deals. The narrative was fine, and I was kidnapped and narrowly escaped cholera and packed all sorts of guns across America. 

The second playthrough was aggravating to the extreme. I remedied the errors of routing I had made before, and so made excellent time across Asia. Then I was stopped at the Pacific coast, as each city I came to gave me routes only to other Asian cities, effectively halting any progress westward. I went from Vladistok to Yukohama to Pyongyang to Manila, finally losing a week for a bank withdrawal (having lost my money idly wandering), another week to cholera, and then finally managed to get to Honolulu, broke and nearly dead. 

I recovered in America, made good sales, recouped my money, made good time to Chicago, then suddenly had the same problem. No routes across the Atlantic. Chicago to Atlanta to MIami to Port Royal to Port-Au-Prince, and tere stopped, broke and in cities without banks, so my only option was to return to Washington. I had lost nearly 40 of my 80 days with unavoidable game circumstances, making what should otherwise have been a sure thing impossible. Frustrated and finished, I closed the game and uninstalled it. 

If it were a game of better money balancing vs. route planning, I would support it more. But bad luck or dead-end routes have little appeal. Also, I would prefer if the rather tiresome interruptions would serve to give more real histories, rather than the fantasy stories it presents. 

5/10

23735076.review:
I'm not surprised at how much I enjoyed this game. It's a "Choose-your-own-adevnture" style game that is largely told through the story. You do have a limited inventory that you have to manage, but other than that it plays almost more like reading a book. There is some strategy, of course, and I can see myself playing through this again. After an initial failure of getting stuck in Russia, not being able to afford my way out, I figured out what I was doing, and made the trip in 74 days in about two hours playtime.

Aside from the adventure and story telling that make this game enjoyable, I really appreciated the decision-making process. In many instances you have to move quickly because you have a choice of taking the fastest route out of the city or exploring to find more options but possibly costing yourself more than a day. In some ways this game reminded me of the board game "Tales of Arabian Nights" as you often make decisions that seem like they will have one outcome, but something entirely different (for better or for worse) happens!

I also loved how you could see the progress of other adventurers traveling at the same time as you; this really helped it feel more like a race.

23732240.review:
I came across this game by pure chance, but being a fan of Jules Verne and a travel lover, it didn't take long to give it a go. 

After my first playthrough, here I am finding that the game was absolutely fascinating!

The ever evolving story is the main key for the fun factor, but I also enjoyed planning itineraries, and the buying and selling factor, along with how long, how expensive, and how tiresome is each trip.

I reckon that the game was low-budgeted, I would only wish a bit more detail in the graphics (the art was ok) and a narrator.

Highly recommended for people who love travelling and reading.

23712085.review:
God this game is SO MUCH FUN! I was very sceptical to be honest, I love well written and well told stories, I'm a huge fan of visual novels, but as games I often find them boring or not catchy enough.

80 days is different. There are no(!) huge walls of text, the steampunk element is simply charming and very well integrated into this classic story, characters are awesome and fun, and well, I just love it.

Somehow it actually made me feel like I was travelling the world. You really have to try to find the best route, keeping in mind the time it takes to travel, where it wil, take you, how you will be able to continue from the next point, costs, luggage, etc. There are several little side-stories (which I mostly missed so far becaue I was a very well-behaved british gentleman and in a great hurry!) but from the hints I got I can already tell they side-stories are awesome as well.

Despite a looot of time spent on trains and airships I did not get bored. There were no long waiting times and I always found something to do and interesting tidbits of information that were more or less helpful for the journey. The Cholera outbreak in Manila scared me, as I was stuck there for a few days, but alas, Mr Fogg escaped unharmed. And me too.
Uhm. Yes. Where was I. Anyway. 

Let's make this a bit more organized:

PROS:
- Fantastic adaptation of the story
- Beautiful graphics
- unexpectedly interactive
- very well balanced game elements
- lovely steampunk elements

CONS:
- none that I could name right now.

If I had one wish, i would ask for more detailed and more varied graphics for the different cities one visits on this journey. But they are already nice.

I finished the game once, and I already can't wait to play it again. I will never forget the romance I had in Dallas, but there is so much more to see!
I want to take the route through northern Africa, and I simply have to see South America, and there is something going on in Vladivostok that I have to discover, and so much more. The sheer amount of content in this game is amazing.

Again, it is not a hard game, it is not very difficult and demanding, but it is so beautiful and so much fun.
80/80 wonderful days of travelling.

23703349.review:

23671302.review:
I'm still chewing on all of the cool game design stuff in 80 Days! This game manages to keep the major strengths of good interactive fiction, while making design decisions that circumvent many of the elements of the genera that I find irritating. On top of that, the writing is just wonderful (first-person narrative! so many games do crappy second-person to "get you into the character"). It's fun, clear, and regularly surprising. 

There are some rough edges to 80 Days -- I'm thinking about en-route NPC dialog in particular -- but all the cool innovations more than make up for the flaws. I'm excited to see what Inkle does next!

23664957.review:
[h1]Pretty good game, though not great.  The music and art style left much to be desired.  The story narratives are largely  pointless.  Outside of travel plans, the choices your character makes are inconsequential.  The game would have benefited had it stuck to travel more strictly, much in the same way Oregon Trail succeeded on an Apple II.  It's still a good game even if it stops far short of great.[/h1]

[b]Pros:[/b]
[list][*]Engaging, fun, and challenging, but not frustrating
[*]Good save system, you can start/stop any time
[*]Very replayable, and encouraging to do so[/list]

[b]Cons:[/b]
[list][*]The art style is very plain.  Look, if you want to put very little effort into the graphics, 8-bit is probably going to look better.  Just look at the boring color palette, the black silhouette vehicles, the shake-a-sprite-up-and-down animations.  It's all smooth, but also low-budget and completely uninformative.  
[*]The dialogue can be painfully boring and pointless, having nothing to do with your journey. 
[*]The two main characters system is useless.  The whole premise of the game as a valet (think butler from Downton Abbey) caring for an imbecile of a master is unnecessary.  So stupid is the master that his health deteriorates if he has to ride on a fishing boat.  So you must care for your master, slowing you down.  What's the point of this?  There isn't one, the game should just focus on one character with his own health/energy stat(s).

23658579.review:
All on a bet and in just 80 days I:

-Was teleported to another city by a mad scientist
-Lost my Master and, with no money to my poor Valet name, became a man masquerading as a French bearded lady in a circus in Japan
-Traversed the underbelly of a moving city
-Captured Jessie James
-Was accused of, and solved, a murder

This game is a fantastic Choose You Own Adventure with amazing replay value. You will want to visit every possible city on the map all the while juggling your Master's health, money, and luggage. Will you stow away for a free ride on the Trans-Siberian railway due to lack of funds? Will you decide to shine shoes and bribe merchants? The multitude of achievements not only make you want to play the game again but it will force you to think of routes you wouldn't have thought to take the first time around. It is also very helpful that the map will keep trac of all the paths that you have taken on a previous run so that you do not have to repeat yourself if you do not wish to. I will definitely be playing this again.

23639563.review:
Conocí a La Muerte en un bar de Nueva Orleans.

Me invitó a una copa. Empezamos a hablar del pasado, y de que la libertad determinaría nuestro futuro. Llegó la noche, y decidimos dar un paseo por la ciudad. Acabamos apoyados en un puente, contemplando el reflejo de la luz de la luna en el agua.

La Muerte me besó en un puente de Nueva Orleans.

Después se fue. Y yo continué con mi viaje. Pero a pesar de que el atlántico se interpondría entre nosotros, tenía la sensación de que en algún momento nos volveríamos a encontrar. Al fin y al cabo, todos moriremos algún día, ¿Verdad?

23611158.review:
Questo gioco, sin dalle prime recensioni che avevo letto, mi aveva sempre intrigato e trovarlo in un bundle su Humble Bundle mi ha portato a giocarlo e finirlo tre volte in un paio di giorni.
Il gioco ripercorre l'impresa compiuta da Phileas Fogg nel romanzo di Jules Verne che credo tutti noi conosciamo bene. Nel gioco rappresenteremo il maggiordomo Passepartout, con l'obiettivo di riuscire a compiere il tragitto in meno dei fatidici 80 giorni della scommessa. Dovremo gestire il denaro e cercare di non finire a secco, grazie a piccole compravendite o prestiti ottenuti dalle banche. Il tempo scorre sempre e dovremo quindi pensare alle tratte migliori, ma che non costino troppo, valutare quando fermarci, se dormire in albergo o sotto le stelle, se aspettare l'apertura del mercato o il prossimo treno, piuttosto che partire prima con una carovana di nomadi mongoli. Un'altra caratteristica da tenere sempre sotto controllo è la salute del nostro Phileas Fogg, che patirà parecchio le tratte pesanti e potrebbe ammalarsi o addirittura (ma molto difficilmente) morire.
La componente molto interessante del gioco è data dalla narrazione e dai numerosissimi eventi che possono succedere nelle partite, in base alle decisioni compiute nelle tappe precedenti. Nella mia prima partita, per esempio, sono stato rapito da una setta in India, per poi precipitare con un dirigibile al largo di Singapore e sconfiggere un pugile in un match a New Orleans nella seconda run, invece, ho incontrato una principessa mongola sulla transiberiana, per poi ritrovarla in Mongolia, quindi essere arrestato alle Hawaii e partecipare ad un viaggio fotografico tra Perù e Brasile, concludendo poi a Londra, dove ho ritrovato la principessa mongola con tanto di proposta di matrimonio. L'ultimo viaggio che ho fatto però è stato il più fantasioso: mi sono ritrovato invischiato in un viaggio verso il Polo Nord, durante il quale purtroppo Phileas Fogg è morto e l'avventura ha preso tutta un'altra direzione.
Come potete vedere si tratta di un gioco davvero sempre differente, in base a piccole decisioni prese durante le tappe, questo garantisce anche una buona rigiocabilità, nell'intenzione di scoprire nuove città, percorrere nuovi tragitti, incontrare nuove persone. I numerosi achievement sono spesso collegati ad alcuni eventi che possono succedere durante il viaggio, non esistono quasi per nulla guide su internet, quindi riuscire a sbloccarli è una vera e propria avventura a sé.
L'unica pecca è che il gioco è in inglese e, data la presenza di numerosissimi brani scritti di narrazione, se non lo conoscete bene, perde tutto il suo fascino.

23510089.review: 80 Days est intéressant, mais un peu trop orienté sur le texte. Évidemment, il faut s'y attendre, puisque c'est dérivé du Tour du monde de Jules Vernes. Ça reste un bon jeu, mais qui s'épuise vite. Après avori fait le tour du monde 1 fois, on peut recommencer, mais on se retrouve vite à cliquer vite sans lire tout le texte pour avancer plus rapidement, et c'est dommage, puisque c'est le texte qui fait le "zeste" du jeu. 23505244.review:
Voto:  6/10

80 days is a game incentrato interamente sulla storia ed è palesemente ispirato al romanzo di Giulio Verne. Sembra un gioco "choose your own adventure". Leggi dei paragrafi e poi scegli come continua la storia o cosa farà il tuo personaggio. E' scritto abbastanza bene ed è interessante. 

A volte è un po' strano, quando viaggi e i dialoghi sono un po' sterili, perché hanno l'unico scopo di trovare nuove rotte... oppure semplicemente danno questa sensazione di futilità. A volte è solo una sensazione, perché capitano cose interessanti un po' ovunque. 

L'errore che ho fatto è stato che ho sentito lo stress della situazione di non avere abbastanza denaro, di avere problemi di salute o di essere in ritardo con la gara. In realtà "vincere" non è difficile...

La parte migliore è infatti il viaggio in sé e quello che scopri e potresti fare durante. Ho letto negli achievement che ci sono un sacco di possibilità... e mi chiedo come possano realizzarsi! 

Il gioco sarebbe da 7 se non ci fosse la componente "stressante" del tempo e del denaro, quindi lo consiglio a tutti coloro che possono apprezzare i giochi in questo stile "libro game"

+ Molte scelte
+ Scritto ok
+ Storia interessante
+ Buona rigiocabilità

- Mi sono sentito un po' stressato a volte
- Gli effetti sonori e la musica è scadente
- Una grafica migliore e una interfaccia più pratica sarebbe stato d'aiuto

23504649.review: Extraordinarily dense and fun, although a little buggy from time to time. My first trip around the world took about 129 days... so, um, I've really gotta work on my navigation skills.

23503328.review:
Un juego muy bien acabado basado en "La vuelta al mundo en 80 días" con ambientación Steampunk en el que encarnamos a Passepartout, el ayudante de Phileas Fogg.

La mecánica es muy similar al Oregon Trail, aunque menos implacable, y con el añadido de que escogemos qué ruta seguir: Algunas serán más rápidas pero más caras, otras pueden ser problemáticas, otras dan mucho rodeo...

Durante el viaje entablaremos conversación con otros viajeros para obtener información sobre nuevas rutas y pistas sobre la situación política de las ciudades, o qué artículos se pueden vender a buen precio para poder seguir adquiriendo billetes en el camino.

La presión del tiempo está siempre ahí, y es difícil saber con seguridad si es preferible esperar a recibir fondos en el banco o seguir adelante por una ruta más lenta/barata, pero en general el juego no me ha resultado especialmente difícil.

Me preocupa un poco la rejugabilidad, ya que hay muchos eventos scripteados que no creo que cambien de una partida a otra. Para dos o tres sesiones sí que debería dar al menos, intentando seguir una ruta alternativa.

En cualquier caso, es un juego recomendable para jugar al menos una vez.

23485523.review: A wonderful adventure. Kind of like Carmen Sandiego, but the clock is ticking.

23477907.review: I got this game in a humble bundle deal. I bought the bundle mostly for the game broken age but was very pleasantly surprised by this title. What I like most about it is it's replayability. It is designed with so many routes to get around the world, so many ways to obtain or lose money, as well as time, that no two journeys will be exactly alike. Very fun and addictive, but I do enjoy journeys and reading so this game may not be everyone's cup of tea. If you are they type of person that only plays call of duty and doesn't like reading than you will most likely hate this game. But, if you are the kind of person that likes reading, and being carried away in the story of adventure, then you will probably find this game very fun and addicting. 23450926.review:
Call me a cheapskate but even though I'd been looking to get 80 Days for more than a year now, it took the Humble Narrative Bundle to cut the price down to a level that I'm willing to pay. 

But it was worth the wait. All the hype in the reviews I'd read wasn't enough to cover how much I love this game. What can I say that hasn't already been said? Awesome storyline with near-infinite variations and forking paths? Check. Scrupulous faithfulness to historical accuracy and cultural sensitivity? Check. Surreal steampunk aesthetic that makes the game new even for hardcore fans of Jules Verne (which I'm not, but still)? Check.

If there ever was an example of storytelling in games par excellence, 80 Days is it. Every class on narrative design should force its students to buy this game at full price as a compulsory course material. It'll be worth every buck.

23388638.review:
Much like many of the recent views, I purchased this game via the Humble Narrative Bundle. As the Bundle's title suggests, I purchased six story based games (my favorite type of games). I had always seen advertisements for this game both on Steam and on the App Store. I decided to forego reading any reviews until at first experiencing the game. 3.1 hours in and I completed my first 80 days, I must say this is probably one of the most replayable games I have played. I am eager to try out many different scenarios, including attempting traveling the globe beginning east, as opposed to the west. I want to give out as little as possible, as this game must be experienced, however the objective of the game is to go around the world in 80 Days (beginning in London) with your master Monsieur Fogg. After this, everything is up to you!

After my first playthrough, I already miss the characters Monsieur Fogg and Passepartout. The writing is intelligent and there are always twists and turns happening in the game to keep one engaged. There are so many cities to visit! You have the option to visit over 200 cities, and the time crunch to get back to London was thrilling. Another option is try to go around the world visiting the least amount of cities. There are so many hidden gems in this game I have yet to explore but cannot wait to! I am absolutely loving this game so far and would've gladly paid full price. It is a fun adventure with superb writing and multiple enthralling twists and turns.

23384068.review:
At the time of writing this review, I have done a single trip around the world which took me about 2.7 hours.

I'm VERY glad I didn't read a single review of this game but saw it rated very positively here which prompted me to get it in the latest Humble Bundle because most of the reviews are blatantly spoiling one of the best twists in the early stages of this game which blew my mind and which make this game VERY different from the Jules Verne affair which was fantastic in it's own right. This game does take heavy inspiration from the Jules Verne novel but adds it's own unique twist and spins a narrative around your actions that is VERY compelling.

You start as Passepartout, the valet of Phineas Fogg who has just made a wager where he must travel around the world in 80 days. As the valet, you must plan your travels across the major cities on the globe and ensure you meet the goal and win the bet for your master. You must decide upon your mode of transport from one city to the next, manage your finances, go to markets and buy and sell goods which will fetch you some profit with which to pay for passage to the next city. You will face many situations and forced to make choices along the way which shape the narrative of the game.

What sets this game apart is it's one of the first games I have played which is narratively focused where your actions will ACTUALLY AFFECT THE OUTCOME. As enjoyable as the Walking Dead series by Telltale games is I never feel as if any of my choices leading up to the end ever mattered leaving me only with a binary choice of some meager description. This game is so refreshing in it's beautifully written world which changes as you make choices along the journey and in the cities you visit. The way you interact with people you talk to, the decisions you make, the items you buy, the paths you take, every single one of them shapes how your journey goes and whether you actually return to London, the city from where you begin this epic tale, on time to win the wager for Phineas. There are also so many references to the original which are done brilliantly yet subtly which I absolutely loved.

For all the praises I have been singing about this game, truly there is but one, though enormous, demerit to this game. One that would almost make me not recommend the game. For all this amazing story-telling along the way, what they give you at the end of the journey as a "journal" of your travels is so pathetically sparse and idiotic in it's presentation that I almost don't feel like playing it again. What happened to the grand tales of my fight on a train, my almost missing a boat, my meeting the owner of a freight company and other such amazing little stories? All they show you are logs of what happened and the date AND THAT'S IT!

If it weren't for the pure joy of seeing your journey unfold before your very eyes and the amazing number of branched paths that are possible and events that you may face which I very much look forward to finding, I would have completely stopped playing yet I find myself wanting more. I want to experience that thrill of exploring and finding people, nooks and crannies that show me new things along the way. And grudgingly, I will go through the game many more times and will surely forget the issues along the way because this game truly is a joy to play.

23365431.review:
80 Days is a charming game where you must plan your journey to cross the world in 80 days (or less!), which is a lot harder than it might sound. You must juggle departure times, funds, and your luggagge if you hope to make it back to London in time to win the wager, and even when you think you've got the perfect route, accidents can happen occur along the way.

I bought 80 Days as part of the Narrative Humble Bundle, so I didn't pay full price for it, but I think it's probably worth its retail price--there's a lot of replayability in this game, as you're never going to be able to visit every city AND make it back to London in time, so you have to prioritise different tasks in different playthroughs. But I think there's more than enough content, particularly as you get to choose different responses and thus provoke different outcomes to the situations you and Fogg find yourselves in.

My only complaint, really, is that the game will show you other players' progress as you're playing, which isn't particularly obtrusive but I found it kind of distracting, and I can't find a way to turn this off in the game settings.

Nonetheless, I fully recommend 80 Days! It's a lot of fun if you like choose-your-own adventure-style text games, and it's a lovely new take on Jules Verne's original novel, with a whole host of secondary characters. The game also feels very progressive in the right places--a lot of female characters, particularly women of colour, play prominent roles within the side stories in positions of power or academia, and there is at least one storyline where you, as a male character, can kiss another man.

23361709.review:
This game is one of my top recommendations to people. If you want a game that will tell you amazing stories, this is it. It also does a fantastic job of making you feel like you're on a journey as you only see snipets of characters' lives before you are whisked away. The writing is superb and the simple presentation encourages your imagination to run wild.

Gameplay-wise it's very simple. It's most like a visual novel with some very simple time, inventory, and money management to push you along.

Representation-wise this game is also fantastic. The world is a crazy steampunk Victorian era. Half the drivers, captains, and pilots as well as incidental characters are women. The racial diversity is also plentiful, as one would hope of a game about traveling around the world. Additionally, half the romance options are female and half are male.
If you're turned off by all this SJW crap, you should play the game anyway. It all works in service of building a unique and varied world that's not just entirely populated by white men with brown hair and giving you a sense of the rich tapestry of people that inhabit the entire world.

Overall, you should absolutely pick this game up. It can get a bit repetitive as you repeat travel routes and stories multiple times, but it's not so much that it's a deal breaker. The game is also available on mobile devices, which perfectly suits the traveling nature of the game. I highly recommend you try it.

23339368.review:
I sat up all night playing this game. I didn't mean too, Having just installed it, I'd planned a quick look before I went to bed, then I started my journey...

For a game that is mostly just text, with a smattering of route planning and luggage management, it conjures up a wealth of vivid images in my head. Just like a good book in fact, only it's you (in the guise of Passepartout) in the book. It is a completely unique experience, I'd never come across a game that engaged me in that way before. At no point in the journey did I want to stop, even though a part of my brain began nagging at me that dawn was breaking.

I nearly died twice, once in an airship crash and then again when I had a bit of a run in with some slavers.

Then there was the incident at the market in Lisbon. In some ways I don't like to mention it. It was a heart-stopping moment of my adventure. Less than 24 hours from London and my literally world collapsed. I found myself back on the desktop, the game had crashed! Were my 78 days of travelling going to end so ignominously? With a shaking hand I at last found the courage to click on the button that would bring things back to life. Perhaps, just perhaps, there'd be an autosave that meant I'd only have lost a day or two of my trip. In all my excitement it had certainly never occured to me to make any form of manual bookmark.

I needn't have worried, the creators in their wisdom had tracked my progress right down to the moment I'd made the ill-advised visit to the market. I was back at the hotel, all my bags were where they should be and my master was waiting for me. In my relief, I abandoned any thought of making a last-minute deal in the markets of Lisbon and hurried aboard that last airship to London.

Somehow I (or maybe that should be we) made it, with almost two days to spare and money in our pockets at that!

23042161.review:
I love this game. It's way more substantial than I expected going in, meaty in terms of story but also fanciful and whimsical at times. Plus, on my first playthrough I released an Indian rebel from British forces.  I also met a mechanical dragon, flew on the back of a giant eagle-mech, spent some ghastly time in a Russian jail, and got delayed on a ship where I led a failed mutiny.  

I definitely lost some time in the beginning due to not understanding the mechanics at first (time passes while you are trading in market, etc.), but just barely made it around the world in 80 days, with the kind of nail-biting, edge of your seat decision-making that feels like a great accomplishment in the end.

There is only one save file, similar to the Banner Saga, which auto-saves after events.  It is not as lenient as Banner Saga, and does not allow manual saves.

Players need to manage money, and can turn a tidy profit through trading.  Players must also manage the health of the English gentlemen who they serve as a valet, and can roleplay either a friendly or hostile relationship with him.

Recommended for readers of Jules Verne, Italo Calvino, and fans of the Banner Saga series.

23032774.review:
This interactive narrative of the steampunk variety encompases the adventure of Passepartout, a french valet who provides service for his master, Phileas Fogg - of whom has wagered £20,000 that he can travel around the world in 80 Days. This immensely dialogue rich game immerses the player in a world (with a little imagination) not too dissimilar from our own. Set in the 1872 it explores not only the geological but plunges into the philosophical and ethical as you converse with people around the world in every country. 

While the visual aspect of this game belies it's touch-screen origins it did not detract from the overall aesthetics as the vector heavy, high contrast, less-is-more approach to the graphic content more than made up for this very slight shortfall. 9/10

The audio is palatable for a few hours as it assists in immersing the player into the world it offers, however, depending on your sensibilities, it may take a single playthrough to notice the looped tracks. Personally I played through twice before switching to my own playlist. I can appreciate the attention to detail of the composition of these tracks and how they seem to draw the player ever along on their global trek changing slightly to befit the corresponding country. 6/10

This game has a ridiculously high replay value and I relished the opportunity to play through again and again as not only did I want to explore and discover the seemingly limitless paths spurring me on to London but also to follow in my footprints yet again to uncover a conversation I had missed or a city I had passed on a rail journey of which we did not disembark to explore. 9/10

Regarding gameplay I cannot speak highly enough. It was refreshing to play a character that you could flirt with two young ladies leaving France for a holiday, or have a romantic interlude with the muscular captain of an ice-walker. The dialogue and response options were also a breath of fresh air, this character could have shortcomings or may have a grandiose personality, or a penchant for mischief. Being able to choose your character's personality as you go really made it a giddy experience and a reminder that even if you try your hardest you can still fail; which is just another one of the positive aspects of this game. While I did found the audio a little repetitive, the immersiveness, replay value and relaxing aesthetics make this a game I shall continue to enjoy for many more hours to come. 10/10

Overall I love this game for many reasons. From the simple and elegant visuals, the rich story, the depth of the dialogue through to the gameplay and replay value. 9/10

TL;DR: 
Audio 6/10
Graphics 9/10
Replay Value 9/10
Gameplay 10/10
Overall 9/10 - would happily repack luggage again and again and again...

22094136.review:
I agree with most of the positive reviews but, as someone who likes to explore a game's story, '80 Days' deeply frustrated me.

By force quitting the game prior to ending a conversation, it is possible to replay the most recent conversation. But with no save system, you cannot explore the "What ifs?" of your current story.

Plot hooks and conversational links are so obscure that you'll either need hundreds of playthroughs or a walkthrough guide. If at any point you fail to go to the right city, or choose the right conversational option, your fascinating story comes to an abrupt halt. Too bad, play again.

How could you not realise that to finish the Mongolian plot you needed to travel between two particular cities in South America, in order to meet someone who'd never previously been mentioned? And that's far from the worst example.

I've found other subplots which I'm fairly sure have a deeper storyline... but no walkthrough mentions them, not all start seeds have them, and there's no hint of how to bring the tale to the surface.

If it was a hardcore action game I could deal with an abrupt story end.

But '80 Days' ends up feeling like you were halfway through a book, when suddenly someone ripped up the last 3 chapters.

If you don't like story driven games, you won't like '80 Days'.
And if you do like story driven games, you better be prepared for countless replays.

概念很新颖，但是玩法太单一。
这款游戏只有从打开到走到东欧的部分让人激动，玩半小时之后就发现，游戏过程就是简单的点击对话、做做买卖、计划行程。尤其是对话部分，作为一个基本没有画面的“纯文字”游戏，全靠对话剧情撑起来了，而这部分特别无聊冗长。玩到最后时间所剩不多的时候，我甚至觉得这个游戏如果没有对话、完全只是规划线路的话，或许还会更好玩点。
细说一下剧情为什么糟糕吧。首先，我不喜欢蒸汽朋克的世界观，觉得这种设定很突兀、不知所云。别问我为什么不喜欢这种世界观还要买，我买它是为了“重走长征路”，而事实上这个游戏的主要目的我感觉并不是这样。其次，虽然每段对话你都有很多不同的回答方式，但是其中大部分并没有什么用。啰哩啰嗦说了一大堆，最后你该怎么走还是怎么走，顶多能提供一点路线信息。最后，剧情本身也不精彩。途中会遇到各式各样的人，但是和他们的关系没有一种“贯穿始终”的感觉。比如说在船上遇到一个女人，她对我好想有意思。有意思怎么样呢？点击对话，她跟我聊天。点击对话，她约我明天再见面。点击对话，她爸爸不喜欢我。点击对话——哦，好不容易这段冗长的对话没了，我和这个女人的故事也就结束了。发现了吗？这个游戏就是无休无止的、并没有什么X用的、无聊的对话。
三十六块钱我觉得吃个汉堡带来的快乐大得多。强烈不推荐。

21854911.review:
I bought it on sale along with a bunch of other games, didn't get around to it for a couple of months. I was curious and wanted to try it, but the screenshots made me a little reluctant. Honestly going into it, I thought it was going to be a linear, pre-plotted course. I thought the decisions would be in the dialogue, where occasionally you might give advice regarding the next destination.

I was pleasantly surprised. You get to choose the course entirely, also each time you play (or at least every time I've played) the seed changes. I'm not even sure what all that changes, all I know is I've plotted a different course every time I played and each time offered quite a different journey. This game is a lot of fun and really rich with adventure. I did not expect the replayability to be so high, but it truly is great. I've gone on four runs, so far.

On my first run, I was still familiarizing myself with the game and made some poor decisions. We were late, and made it back to London in 90 days (I got stuck in Africa, my only way out was an airship full of people mad at me for riding in on a slaver ship, I had to spend a week and a half begging for money to afford the venture). I was pleased to discover that even once you pass the 80 day mark, you still plot your way home as normal, there's no instant YOU LOSE screen or anything.

On my second run, armed with my new knowledge of how the game works, I pulled off a round-the-world trip in only 60 days! Huzzah!

On my third run, I believe was my trip north, I made it in 50 days. That was quite adventurous.

My most recent run I did not break my record or anything, it was 60-70 days and I took over a ship, beat a champion boxer, and came home with $10,000, and my peak during our trip was $17,000. No banks.

21252144.review:
80 Days is a video game based on Jules Verne's Around The World In Eighty Days. It tells the story of Phileas Fogg, who takes a bet to circle the world in 80 days, starting from London in October of 1872. You play as Passepartout, Fogg's new valet, who assists him on his journey. That is where the similarities end, though. The story takes place in an alternate history 1872, in a world full of fantastical technology such as automatons, underwater trains, flying machines, and even mechanical camels, but it's also very aware of contemporary political and cultural struggles.

The game part of this game comes in planning out your journey, trying to find the quickest path, managing your funds, and negotiating for lower ticket prices, seats on trains or zeppelins or submarines. BUT ALSO, you talk to people in the cities you travel to, witnessing or becoming part of the stories. For example, one path gets you involved in an Agatha Christie style murder mystery that you can try to solve. In my first game, I got arrested, organized a mutiny, accidentally blew up a boat, and lost a boxing match and still managed to get back to London JUST UNDER the time limit at 78 days.

The writing in this game is fantastic. It's a wonderful adventure, full of surprises and thrills and even heartbreak. Everywhere I went, I encountered people who touched the character's heart in unexpected ways. But I had to leave them behind, because the game is focused on the challenge. You're always moving forward, leaving things behind.

And the game also explores themes of anti-colonialism, unique cultures and how varied the cultures of the world are, as well as celebrating a diverse cast of adventurers, inventors, and even criminals (in my game, I had a romantic tryst with a woman who was an internationally wanted thief and cardsharp). All manner of people are represented and from my admittedly white perspective, it represents the world cultures in a way that is not exoticized.

The world is realized so well. The beautiful art is simple and evocative. The historical events represented are all affected by the game's fantastic steampunk-ish world, and your characters are not the focus of the world, just participants in it.

At it's core, it's an incredibly complex choose-your-own-adventure story, with hundreds of branching paths and possible narratives. There are 170 cities in the world you can visit, and in a single playthrough, you might visit 20, and depending on your choices, you might only see one possible part of the stories present in that city. Discussing this game with my girlfriend, my mind began spiraling from the possibilities of this story. And all of these possibilities are elegantly tied together with the focus on your goal and your relationship with Fogg as you go on this journey together.

This is a wonderful, beautiful game, and I'm certainly not the first person to see this; it won Time Magazine's Game Of The Year in 2014, and it was even nominated for 4 BAFTA awards. I highly recommend it to anyone.

21095733.review:
A charming little game set in an alternate late 1800's timeline. I'm hesitant to use the word steampunk, but the tech definitely seems to follow some of those tropes. Not to say that the tech is the focus; the game does a wonderful job of painting exotic locales around the world that are made all the more fantastic by this amazingly advanced technology akin to magic.

Based off of Around the World in 80 days, you play as the valet to a rich man who has taken a wager to travel the globe in 80 days. To do this you must not only plan your route using major cities as little event nodes in which small, choose your own adventure vignettes take place, but also must keep your prim and proper master in immaculate condition.

Or not. It is a choose your own adventure game after all! Your valet can be anywhere from a Batman-esque Alfred super butler to a brusque racist who cares little for these exotic cultures and even less for your pompous master (although if your master's condition drops too low I'm assuming you lose the game; I wouldn't know, I had to much fun being an Alfred type).

The game has loads of replayability as not only can you see your past routes but also the routes of other players. However, I did feel it was a bit short, and the events in each city node don't seem to have much variation, so once you explore them all, which will take a while, you wont have much left to do except try to speedrun the game and maximize your effeciency.

The atmosphere carries this game. If it didnt have such amazing and unique setting it'd probably be a completely meh game. As it is, I'd have to say the game is easily an 8/10 if you care about world-building or settings.

20714401.review:
Several years ago I lived in a big house with a great number of people. I worked nights and the bustle and noise of so many people under one roof made sleeping during the day difficult. I remember coming home in predawn hours however, and brewing a cup of tea. I would take a fine leather bound volume of Jules Verne stories from the bookshelf on the mantle, and sit down to lose myself in strange places and wondrous adventures. I would quite often disappear from the phenomenal world and regain my footing in sublime places. 

     Playing inkle.Ltd’s spectacular [i][b]80 Days[/b][/i] has taken me back to those days. The game mechanically is a grandiose, “choose your own adventure” tale of a man becoming a man of the world. Though minimal in execution, the game’s presentation is perfect for what it is. My first playthrough was a 3 hour time flash which, I swear, only lasted 30 minutes. 

     In these days of jagged and blocky 8 bit dark silhouette characters jumping around in pixelated indie games with nary a storyline at all, it’s refreshing to find a game replete with such an incredible amount of imagination put into it. 

    Playing Phileas Fogg’s ever loyal servant plucked right from the pages of Jules Verne’s novel, [i][b]Around the World in Eighty Days[/b][/i], I got us both kidnapped by cultists in Calcutta. I delivered a baby in the South Pacific while sailing to Manila, and in Manila I contracted cholera. I flattened myself against an alley wall in Dallas, Texas as hooded members of the Ku Klux Klan walked past me, torches in hand. And in New Orleans, Death sat at my table in a bar, bought me a drink and kissed my hand. 

     No. I didn’t win the race, nor did I complete my world tour in 80 days. But I had (mis)adventures of a lifetime that made winning an around the world race (and the wager involved) pale dim. When the roads freeze and the wintry snow buries your front door, fix a mug of hot chocolate, indulge yourself in this wonderful game filled with beautifully crafted prose. You’re welcome.

20676068.review:
Análisis publicado en http://arsgaming.com/80-days-analisis

Inkle vuelve a sorprender con una maravillosa adaptación interactiva de La vuelta al mundo en 80 días. Con multitud de rutas y opciones posibles los desarrolladores nos ponen bajo la piel de Passepartout, el criado de la célebre obra de Julio Verne que tendrá que cuidar de su señor y viajar en todo tipo de extravagantes aparatos.

80 days cuenta desde los últimos meses del pasado año con versión en PC, además de Android e iOS. Esto marca una clara línea de expansión que van a seguir otros títulos y que pretende dar a conocer al gran público las interesantes propuestas de esta desarrolladora indie.

El título es lo más parecido a vivir dentro de una novela pero con una particularidad que lo hace aún más interesante: la posibilidad de elegir y dirigir nuestro propio destino. Las elecciones que llevemos a cabo con Passepartout van desde la ruta a seguir a los comportamientos que adoptemos, los cuales definirán nuestra personalidad a lo largo del juego.

80 days tiene unas mecánicas de juego muy sencillas, asumibles para cualquier tipo de jugador, y un objetivo claro, viajar lo más rápido posible. El manejo se limita a seleccionar opciones y rutas disponibles, que vamos descubriendo a lo largo de nuestro viaje.

En cada ciudad hay varios elementos comunes que se repiten: la posibilidad de pasar la noche en un hotel, invertir horas en la exploración, acudir al banco o comprar y vender cosas en el mercado. Aunque el objetivo para completar el juego está muy claro y no hay un gran elenco de opciones para llevar a cabo en las ciudades, decidir en qué invertir el tiempo es una cuestión primordial y más difícil de gestionar de lo que puede parecer en un principio.

También tenemos que tener en cuenta los fondos de los que disponemos, que pueden ser ampliados de diferentes formas: sacándolos del banco pero perdiendo uno o varios días en este proceso, o bien a través de la compraventa de mercancías, la opción más rentable y para la que necesitaremos conocer y planificar nuestra ruta. Esta última opción se basa en conocer en qué ciudades podemos vender mercancías a un precio mayor, a través de lo cual se puede conseguir una buena cantidad de dinero.

Ligado a los fondos está la gestión del inventario, fundamental para viajar de forma eficiente y sin realizar demasiados gastos. Además de servirnos para transportar bienes, en los maletines podemos almacenar algunos objetos que harán nuestro viaje más placentero y menos dañino a la salud, o que nos permitan ganar ventajas como la de adelantar la salida de algunos medios de transporte sin coste adicional.

A lo largo de nuestros viajes sucederán una serie de eventos en los que tendremos que elegir entre diferentes opciones. Estos, como ya hemos dicho, definirán nuestra personalidad, pero también influirán en el propio viaje. Una determinada elección puede provocar que nuestro viaje se atrase o adelante, que descubramos información interesante sobre ciudades y rutas que las unen, compromisos con otros personajes o daños para el Monsieur Fogg.
La salud de Fogg es otro de los aspectos de los que tendremos que estar pendientes, ya que si descuidamos este aspecto puede llegar a morir. Nuestro señor perderá salud con los viajes (hay algunas formas, con determinados objetos, de mitigar el daño recibido) y tendremos que recuperarla descansando, afeitándolo y aseándolo.

El tono literario y narrativo lo convierten en un reclamo importante para aquellos que disfrutan con un buen relato, por lo que aunque estrictamente no se trate de un RPG, es idóneo para aquellos que disfrutan con este género. No obstante su vertiente literaria tiene un hándicap, la ausencia de una traducción al castellano. Esto provoca que incluso usuarios con un cierto nivel de inglés tengan que detenerse para llegar a comprender el significado de algunas palabras.

La ambientación también dota al relato de originalidad. Además de aparecer algunos de los inventos que relata Verne, aparecen otros muchos, con un estilo steampunk. Hay una gran variedad de inventos, en los que nos montaremos y disfrutaremos del magnífico trabajo artístico del que goza el juego. La ambientación gráfica se ve acompañada de una magnífica banda sonora que hará todavía más entretenida la experiencia de viajar alrededor del mundo.

En definitiva, 80 days aporta frescura a todo el género de los videojuegos. Al igual que hizo en Android e iOS, ahora con su expansión al mundo del PC Inkle gana un público potencial mucho mayor. 80 days nos ofrece disfrutar de una adaptación libre y plagada de elecciones de un clásico de la literatura.

20599391.review:
This is an absolute gem of a game.

It is perhaps best described as an interactive novel set in an alternate steampunk 1872, warped around the writings of Jules Verne, in particular his novel 'Around the World in 80 Days'. You play the trusty valet/sidekick Passpartout, charged with getting your gentleman master Phileas Fogg safely around the planet on time and on budget, no matter what the world throws at you in terms of surprises. That said, some of the greatest adventures are not along the more direct or traditional Foggish route, and there are loads of little encounters with historical figures of the era as well, be they inventors, poets or adventurers. It can take a while to sort of the real people from the fictious ones.

The writing in this game is superb, and the many potential paths - some of which take a while to unlock or riddle out - offer great replay value. Going the [i]same[/i] route won't likely be as appealing, as the story of each city or travel path is largely identical with each gameplay (there are factors that alter dialogue options, such as items in your inventory, past choices, and Passpartout's valeting skill) - but with the possible exception of Paris, you'll still have so much choice of where to go that this potential repeat has little consequence in your first few dozen playthroughs.

The only negative thing I can say about the game is that you cannot pause the clock (if it's running - it stops whenever there is something to read). This can make you miss vital connections because you suddenly realize you have too many bags of luggage when you attempt to depart, and by the time you've thrown surplus items away, the ship has sailed without you. Quite vexing, if you paid the captain thousands of pounds the night before to sail a few days early. :-p

You do not want to be a packrat in this game; travel light - the world is large and is begging to be explored. If you enjoy a good read and adventure, 80 Days will not disappoint - be it this game or the novel it is based on.

20571669.review:
I find this game very engaging. Although it has a simple format, no flash graphics,it really works.  Sound (on PC) adds great atmosphere and the single image for each town or journey are well crafted. I'm learning plenty of geography too.  I've played through at least 8 journeys, each one different from the previous.  Lots of different branches in the story, and puzzles to solve. A different choice of response can take you down a totally different path, opening and closing story options.

My only caution is, your character, Passepartout, has opportunities for romance with various people you meet along the way,  both male and female, which may be confronting for some people. You need to be flirtatious to open these storylines, so don't let this put you off an excellent game. But thinking of some of my friends with young children, they would not thank me for my recommendation without this caution.

20510574.review: I've very much enjoyed this game/book.  What I've been most satisfied with is replay value, it takes about 2 hours or so to go around the world, so far I've done the trip 7 times, well.... attempted the trip 7 times!  Well worth your hard earned dollars.

I get that it's meant to be an experience, not about the objective of 80 days, but the experience wasn't particularly rewarding for me personally. Non vedo l'ora di ricominciare provando nuove rotte, aspettandomi altre sorprese!

20278695.review:
Based on the novel by Jules Verne "Around the World in 80 Days" and updated to a steam punk world.  Play as Passepartout and get your gentleman, Phileas Fogg around the world by any means necessary: air ship, train, car, steamboat, submarine.  Visit exotic locations as far away Machu Picchu and Siberia.  Be amazed at the intrigue, calamities, politics, and places of the world (most not even tourist attractions).  

Time management, strategy game with all the twists of an interactive visual novel.

Hundreds of ways around the world, which journey will you chose?

20242888.review: This game is extremely fun, with tons of replayability, and a deep script that keeps things frensh. I could not recommend it more highly.

20240303.review: It's easy to fall into the trap of thinking that 80 Days is just a game about getting around the world as fast as possible, but if you do that you probably won't have very much fun at all. The fun of this game comes from exploring the world instead of racing past it, and going different routes (like travelling directly north instead of easy) can lead you into a number of different stories. It is a bit expensive for what it is, and it's fairly easy to miss any interesting events even if you look for them, but it's still a pretty fun story game to pass the time with.

20228710.review:
Ich liebe Jules Verne, also habe ich nicht lange gezögert dieses Spiel zu kaufen. Anfangs war ich nicht begeistert von den vielen Texten, normalerweise mag ich keine narrativen Spiele wie dieses. ABER!!! hier ist einfach alles anders. 
80 days entführt den Spieler auf mehrfache Weltreisen (man kann immer andere Routen nehmen und es wird nie langweilig!) und gibt einem neuen Stoff zu träumen.
Ich habe sehr viel Fernweh bekommen beim Spielen, ich bin neugierig geworden auf neue Orte und gleichzeitig mochte ich die Athmosphäre der Reisenden im späten 19. Jahrhundert. Steampunk-Fans kommen ebenso auf ihre Kosten, die Fortbewegungsmittel sind geprägt von den Ideen und der Technik der Dampfmaschinen.

Das Spiel ist sehr menschlich, denn es geht um die Austausch von Kulturen und immer wieder darum, Entscheidungen zu treffen und somit auch die einzelnen Schicksale zu beeinflussen. So ist es manchmal romantisch, manchmal auch sehr brutal —immer jedoch sehr emotional.

Das Spiel ist sehr ansprechend minimalistisch gestaltet und den Soundtrack könnte ich stundenlang hören.
Ich habe dieses Spiel jetzt 4-5 Mal durchgespielt und keine Stelle glich der anderen. Wenn man sich auf alle Spielereien und Dialoge einlässt und sich nicht auf 80 Tage festlegen will, der kann sich durchaus mal für 5-6 Stunden an einer Reise fesseln.

20228013.review:
Greetings fellow gamers! This is Gamer Guy (In a Suit) from the Echo Army YouTube channel! Today I am bringing you a review of the Indie Adventure/CYOA 80 Days. 80 Days was released on Steam on September 28, 2015 by Developer Cape Guy ltd. and Developer/Publisher Inkle Ltd. 

(NOTE: This game was NOT reviewed using a key provided by the Developer and/or Publisher, it was a game I purchased for my own account)

Video Review: 

https://youtu.be/IPMhq2I5ReU

The "Too Long, Didn't Watch" Review:

Around the world in 80 Days, the novel. Fully playable, very Steampunk.
5/5 DO NOT MISS THIS ONE!

The "Meat & Potatoes" Review:

80 Days is, simply put, an absolute treat! This has easily become one of my favorite games as of late. WHat it is is a re-imagining of sorts of Jules Vene's classic "Around the World in 80 Days". Your master, upon accpetance of a wager, intends on circling the globe in under 80 days. You are his Valet and are in charge of not only caring for you masters well being, but planning his route. Along your journey you will engage in buying and selling goods from various markets to balance your funds (and to make your journey easier at times!). Another key component to the gameplay is the conversations. You must explore and converse as much as possible in order to find and open up new routes to facilitate your journey. Then, you must pick and choose carefully which of these routes you will take. The entire game is built around the CYOA mechanic, as you read through the incredibly well written dialogue you must make choices as to which direction the story takes as well. All in all, the writing is superb and the art and sounds are very, very beautiful. It is no wonder that Time Magazine gave it Game of the Year status for 2014. THis is also available on mobile devices, but the Steam version is well worth it. 5/5 and easily worth $10.

Happy Gaming!

I sought little solace in the mutterings of fellow travellers, indeed, much of my time was spent dedicating myself to my Master's wishes. The glory would be his after all, myself being no more than the accompanying valet.

Thus, with ruthless dedication bordering on obsessive, we arrived in London, slightly dishevelled to put it mildly, but within a period not exceeeding 65 days. 

A handsome profit was to be had from my Master's wager and I for one feel satisfied that my role was performed admirably and I gave myself a resounding, albeit discreet cheer.

20132635.review:
To start off 80 Days is an interactive fiction game, so if you don’t like lots of reading, steer clear.  The game is an adaption of the classic Jules Verne novel about consummate British gentleman Phileas Fogg and his wager to circumnavigate the world in 80 Days, and does its own spin on it by adding steampunk. Now steampunk is usually squandered into just being greasy nerds covering themselves in gears and talking in bad British accents instead of actually exploring the punk part of the term, but 80 Days uses the trappings very effectively, adding on to the feelings of wonder and adventure as well as actually exploring the social and economic impact of such inventions like dealing with how they interact with the ills of the Victorian Era, but also the hope for a brighter future such innovations could bring as well. The world of 80 Days is also an interesting a mix of real history such as France still recovering from their humiliating defeat in the Franco-Prussian War that led to the unification of Germany and alt history such as the Zulu being a rising world power that successfully repelled British invasion. You play as Fogg’s valet, Jean Passepartout, and gameplay is strategizing your money and supplies as well as making choices to learn more about possible routes, win people to your side, and improve relations with Fogg, among other things. This game is dense as hell and there are so many places to go and people to meet on your journey that you will definitely miss out on a lot in just one playthrough.

Overall it’s a really engaging experience and to just give a more detailed example, in my first playthrough I took a northern route cutting through the Baltic and going overland through Russia. Hijinks along the way included getting caught in a battle between Communist rebels and the Czar’s mech-pilot soldiers in St. Petersburg, getting chucked off the Siberian Express in the ass-end of Siberia after inadvertently deep sixing a young romance, getting waylaid to Beijing and seeing a Chinese opera performed by robots, delivering the captain’s baby on a boat from Honolulu to San Fran and running into a gang of Chicago hooligans that lifted houses off their foundations with their machines if they didn’t get paid protection money. With less than a week left and finding myself in New York, I sold all our stuff to take a rocket sub to Iceland, and after that finally made the worldwide journey back to London…82 days later.
 
But in the end it didn’t feel like a failure, it kind of felt like a fitting ending. Fogg and Passepartout didn’t make it, but close enough to still make it impressive, and their whole journey was a grand adventure and the two became close friends by the end of it. My two subsequent playthroughs were much more successful and were unique adventures of their own, such as solving a murder and going down the Amazon. And that’s what 80 Days really succeeds at and deserves the praise it’s gotten, really making you feel you went on an adventure. In conclusion, 80 Days is a fantastic adventure game and a must play.

20048965.review:
This is really a great game, and far more unforgiving than I'd have guessed initially.  You are the servant of a wealthy man who bet that he can make it around the world in 80 days, as the title suggests.

And this world is really something.  The whole place is this incredibly realized steampunk alternate future where horses have been replaced by metal horses, and where pirates use airships to plunder over land.  I don't want to give anymore away, those are two early examples of the game's incredibly cool atmosphere.  Some if it is incredibly inventive, at least as someone who doesn't know much steampunk stuff.

And the game is, as I said, quite punishing in a fair way.  You can miss an entire day just by missing the departure of your chosen method of travel.  If 3 different methods of transport leave at 1:00 PM and you're still clicking the option to get an extra bag on-board at 12:59, you'll miss the train/ship/car/railroad etc.  It's both frustrating and realistic, seeing as they won't wait around for you all day.

The game is about managing the options for your travel amid various circumstances which present themselves in the game's choose your own adventure texts.  You go through multiple stages of dialog which can improve your relationship with your master, or with strangers, and perhaps net you items or new information on how to travel to another destination.  

You have to be wary of your master's health, which decreases over arduous journeys, or he'll die.  You can buy gear which aids traveling over the stressful paths, like desert clothes or storm gear for oceanliners.  Be sure to get items from various cities to sell elsewhere, too, so you can afford transport costs.  There's lots of really funny, interesting things that happen and I've only gotten to day 70 on my first try (I had to restart because I screwed up).  There's an entire northern half of Europe, both North and South America which I've yet to even step foot in.

You really should get this game, and hopefully many more games like this come about in the future.  It's got great music, the writing is easy to read and not overly wordy (unlike lots of games which bombard you with text and then claim to have "great writing," such as something like Pillars of Eternity).  Even the globe of the game has a color scheme which reinforces the theme.  All the art is very pretty to look at also.

Just an absolute joy to play the game.  The myriad of choice supports multiple playthroughs, though you will doubtless run into some scenarios twice.  You can handle these differently to see what the outcome is though.  The game also reacts to your path and the number of days you have left in a way which seems really impressive; my master was not pleased when I decided to go west after heading northeast because it went against our progress, even though it meant we'd be able to do this quest and get tons of money while boarding the trains more to the south.

Definitely get this game if you like choose your own adventure style games, and this is a really cool introduction to the genre for people who don't normally play this kind of thing.

80 Days is simply a very superb game. I punched Jesse James into the face, joined a circus after an Opium binge and so far sailed the world twice. I haven't met the goal yet and it doesn't matter. This game tells a wonderful story of two people trying to win the race around the world - while getting to know each other, meeting new cultures and interesting people on all continents. And the story of Verne fits great into the Steampunk setting. 
It is a lot of reading for people who might not like it, but it's worth. No matter what you choose, the game gives new story parts and in the end you write your own. It feels less than a race for a wager, but more your own adventure. It's a written, virtual vacation, where you encounter strange vehicles, strange people and visit the most beautiful places on earth. The writing supports your own imagination to explore the world, which shows how good it is. And it makes a huge replay value.

19981909.review:
I often find that I miss a sense of mystery and discovery in contemporary gaming. This game is quite the exception! 80 Days is a charming "choose your own story" type of game in which you take the role of a faithful valet in service to Phineas Fogg, an English gentleman. Fogg has taken a bet, in now so have you! Your goal is to circumnavigate the globe of an alternate history late 19th century world filled with steampunk creations in 80 days or less. I found discovering unique modes of transportation to be an ingenius plot advancement device and I never knew what might come at the next stop. I'd like nothing more than to describe just a few of these fictional vehicles, yet to do so would ruin that sense of discovery that I've enjoyed so far.

So, aside from managing your master and deciding on your route, you must also balance your books and ensure you have funds to spare. Much of this is done by buying and selling for profit. This is all quite transparent and easy to understand. That is a boon to this title! Simplicity and ease is one of the greatest selling points of 80 Days and I would even recommend it to those who don't regularly play PC games. 

I highly recommend this title to just about anyone. Whether it is the exploration, excellent writing and plot or the challenge of the unknown and a strict timetable, this title will not disappoint. That being said, do not expect to win on the first play through. This is a game that is highly replayable, and I would even say that it is a necessity. Safe travels!

19843402.review:
Really nice and creative game. Having completed a trip a few times on Android I wanted to give it a go on Windows for the achievements and the comfort of a bigger screen and a mouse. 

80 Days follows the story of the wealthy Phileas Fogg and his valet Passepartout. In the game you have to try to travel the world in eighty days (what a surprise!). How you do it is up to the player: will you try and brave the deserts of Arabi or take the long railway through the cold Russian lands? You can make a lot of decisions which make for a unique travel each time you play the game. 

When you find yourself in cities, you have multiple options to pass the time: find banks to transfer money from London, visit markets to buy and sell items to help funding the trip or to ease the harsh travelconditions. You can also explore each city to find new travel methods and interesting stories about the city you're in. Each city has a nice story, some longer than the others, which can really add something to the experience or the trip.

When travelling stories will present themselves in which you can make choices what to do and what to say. These choices can really matter, so be careful what you choose. You can fall in love, get your airship boarded by pirates, strand at sea with no escape left; there's a lot to explore, discover and experience.

The world itself is very interesting. It's a futuristic steampunkish world with its own morals and codes. It's a world Jules Verne (the game is based upon his novel) has created and it's really amazing. The developers did a great way to shape the content to be a hommage to Verne.


Is this game something for you? If you like cool storylines with a great interactive touch this is something for you. It has a little bit of strategic management into it with the markets and the items you can find there, but also how you will travel and if you can persuade people to help you in your endeavor to travel the world in eighty days.

19457463.review:
Keep in mind that I almost never go for choose-your-own-path adventure games, which are essentially interactive books. [b]While [i]80 Days[/i] is in that realm, there is something really magical about it.[/b] After finishing a run, I literally felt as if I'd experienced an epic trip around the world - I can recall all the craziness and wild adventures as if they were real memories. [b]Its hard to explain, but the game is very immersive. [/b]

Essentially, the gameplay consists of role-playing a servant, and you make text-based decisions about how you want to interact with people and situations. [i]80 Days[/i] also has heavy strategy elements because a large part of your success depends on how you plan out your route around the world. There is also an economy element of balancing your funds through buying-low-selling-high, among other things. 

[b]Pros:[/b]
+The writing is front-and-center here. Masterfully done writing. Some of the vocab even had me looking up words (in a good way).
+The story is really good, and just feels incredibly immersive.
+Great balance of strategy and story-telling.
+Lots of classic literature easter eggs to be found :)

[b]Cons:[/b]
-Lots of reading - not for the impatient. [b]'The journey is the reward' - is truly applicable here.[/b]
-It was built for mobile, but enough has been added/tweaked to merit the more expensive Steam purchase IMO.
-Sometimes I wish I had better control over the map. I mean its fine, but I wish I could look at it on hardcopy.

[b]This was recognized by [i]Time[/i] magazine, among many many other awards. When video games gather the attention of outside media, you generally know its something great (ie. [i]Minecraft[/i]).[/b] This is a real gem, IMO.

19395277.review:
Doesn't look like much of a game, does it?, and I'd never have even noticed it if I'd not seen another glowing review, but this is really good fun for well under a tenner, even if you only play through a couple of times. 

It can be best described as an interactive novel of Around The World In 80 Days ... albeit on a steampunk Jules Verne version of Earth ... rather like the old Choose Your Own Adventure books in many ways. I think you will need to enjoy the reading aspect, at least to a light degree; if you don't and just want to skim-read the story or click through randomly, then you may miss the point (and your way), as the real charm of this game is in it's "dynamic writing", and how these literary adventures tie in with your race against the clock. 

One thing I was particularly dubious about before playing was mention of the steampunk aspects, such as walking cities, as I thought these may destroy the immersion ... however the steampunk is not an odd distraction but rather a fundamental and fully integrated component of this Jules Verne version of Earth, and as such plays a full and refreshing role in each story, that could otherwise I think have felt rather stale.

This is a nice little game, no more, no less. So you get to play Passpartout, Phileas Fogg's valet, in a somehow rivisited version of Jules Verne's Around The World in 80 days. 
You get to choose traveling routes, managing money and equipment and you goal is to make it back to London in, as it says, 80 days.
Worth playing if you want something different yet quite easy to kill a couple of hours.

PROS

CONS

- There is not much to do other than managing your funds, trying to scrape a profit by reselling stuff you purchase and scheduling your trips

So overall it's a yes, just manage your expectactions: moderately fun, quite short, replayable.

What an amazing game. A literary classic told through fitting music, charming art that while simple never becomes boring and surprisingly deep and involving game mechanics. I was physically unable to stop my journey once it had first begun, and though much of it was played relatively safe there was still plenty of close shaves and action which made the entire experience one of the best adventures I've had in a game in recent memory. Sadly, I did not make the first trip in 80 days, in part due to poor planning but also from being marooned on a small island in the middle of the pacific ocean where Mr. Fogg almost left his senses. I am already excited to start my next playthrough, with so much of the world left to discover I believe it won't be the last one, either.

If I had to have one complaint, only one, it is that I felt like I experienced an abnormally high amount of female characters compared to male ones. From my start in London, over Paris, Copenhagen, into Russia and across the middle east, East-Asia to New Zealand and into the dark heart of Africa and back into Europe, the amount of male characters I encountered could be counted on one hand (and left me wondering where they all were. Replaced by automatons?). On one hand it was humours, given the game takes places in an (albeit fictional) period of time where women were not often seen in these very male-centric professions, on the other the almost total lack of male characters (and the game at one point describing a grizzled boiler-room engineer as a petite Indian women in a beautiful sari) took a little away from the overall immersion, and I had to wonder if it was intentional or if my route just happened to let me encounter every possible pilot, captain and engineer of the feminine persuasion. Either way, I guess I'll see if this changes on my further adventures.

19316942.review:
Charming, intelligent, and moving; a steampunk-flavoured choose-your-own adventure brought to life by spare but lovely visuals.  The writers and programmers have created a rich and beautiful world burgeoning with fantastical mechanical conveyances and automata, burgeoning with old traditions and fomenting revolutions.  You play as one Monsieur Passepartout, loyal French valet to the phlegmatic and inscrutable Phileas Fogg, gentleman explorer and Englishman's Englishman, encountering men and women of all nationalities, political persuasions and walks of life.  

As the player, you are never told what to think or believe, and you may shape your own character to be as sceptical or open-minded, as cynical or trusting, as you wish, although, as in real-life travel, the greatest rewards come from openness, curiosity, and acts of kindness.  The interface and inventory is simple but effective, presenting the player with choices in dialogue, traveling routes, and buying and selling of items, with the constraints of time and money encouraging resourcefulness and essential tradeoffs.  Will you attend to your master's wishes, or pursue your own romance?  Go whale-hunting, or play it safe?  Help out the revolutionaries, or the local colonial government?  Cannot recommend this one highly enough.

19257638.review:
80 Days is essentially a choose your own adventure story inspired by the Jules Verne novel [i]Around the World in 80 Days[/i], set in a steampunk Victorian world with mechanical automatons, airships, a walking city, and further fantastical marvels. The game places you in its narrative as the valet of Phileas Fogg, a gentleman adventurer propelled onward by a wager to circumnavigate the globe within the titular 80 day period. On this journey you will explore the world's cities as you chart your own course to make it back to London before the clock runs out, balancing Fogg's health and your monetary funds as you plot and trade your way across the world.

As 80 Days is essentially a text-based game (though it is dressed up quite a bit with an attractive interface and travel graphics reminiscent of the [i]Indiana Jones[/i] movies), its success lives or dies on the quality of its writing - and it manages to live quite large. The story woven in your character's journal is superbly written, and you find yourself heavily engaged as you decide the course your character will take and the way they react to events while exploring the game's cities and interacting with some of its characters. 

It is a short game - easily playable in just a couple of hours depending on how well you do -, but features fantastic replayability. Though I'm not usually one to revisit a game like this, I'll certainly be going on another journey soon, as there's just so many different cities to visit, and you could easily play the game many different times before repeating a single step of your journey. Adding to this is that the game's parameters change as you play through on different starting seeds (there are 8, which you advance through in order with each subsequent playthrough), each slightly altering items available for trade, available travel routes and departure times, as well as introducing new elements to the game's story.

It's a cute little game that I thoroughly enjoyed - well worth the low price of its $10 entry.

19234361.review:
