A tutorial would be helpful at first, however, I got the grip on the game mechanics during the first fifteen minutes or so, so that should not be a big problem for anybody.
Overall, 8/10.

19203809.review:
Let's clear a few things up from the beginning:
-This is not a difficult game - I was able to make it around the world in less than 60 days my first playthrough without so much as discomfiting Mr. Fogg.  Although it is possible to "lose", winning and losing are not really what this is about.
-This is not a particularly "fun" game.  The pacing and story-bound nature of this title don't really lend themselves to instant gratification.  It is far more contemplative than that.
-This isn't really a "game" at all.  As other have mentioned, it is much more a choose-your-own adventure book, heavily steeped in a strange alternate reality that we might call steampunkish, but which is really a close modern approximation of what Jules Verne's imagination produced.  If you don't enjoy reading, steer clear of this one.

With all that out of the way, I really enjoyed my first play through, and look forward to completing several more.  I think the format of the game lends itself well to multiple replays, as there are numerous routes and methods at your disposal to get from one place to the next, and the time requirement makes visiting more than a handful of locations during a single playthrough difficult. How replayable it is after more than a handful of playthroughs is debatable.  I'd guess that after about 4 or 5 circuits (about 8-10 hours) you'd have exhausted many of the locations and dialogue, and it might start to get a bit stale.  

My only real gripes are that the interface is slightly wonky for keyboard and mouse, as it was designed for iOS.  I had a hard time figuring out how to get from "planning" back to where you could go to the bank, etc while in a city.  Turns out you have to click on the city you're currently in to go back.  Also, it should be noted that on PC this title is 10 bucks, whereas on iOS, it is 5.  I think the experience lends itself better to a tablet as well.  So there's that.  

Overall, if you enjoy books and reading, and especially if you are a Verne fan, you'll likely love this.  If you dislike reading and are looking for action and excitement, you'll probably hate it.  If you have an iPad, consider getting it on there vice PC.

19166575.review:
[h1][b]This review was written for [url=http://freedomcgc.com/80-days-review/]FREEDOM Community Gaming Collective[/url].[/b][/h1]

“I have entered into the service of a new gentleman. It would seem he is a gambling man.” Orchestral music with a sense of urgency starts up as the globe begins to turn around its axis. Right off the bat, 80 Days gives out an intriguing vibe. The journey begins in London and, as everyone knows, follows the adventures of Phileas Fogg as he attempts to circumnavigate the world in 80 days. In this take of the Jules Verne classic novel Around the World in Eighty Days, Fogg takes a backseat to his French servant Passepartout. Players assume the role of the valet who is in charge of picking the route, handling the funds, baggage, and taking care of Fogg himself.

The game distances itself from its inspiration even further thanks to its setting. It is still set in the second half of the 19th century, but 80 Days boldly embraces a steampunk theme and an alternate take on history, which simply makes perfect sense. As you travel the world, you will discover strange means of transportation, automatons, and a mysterious guild of creators called the Artificers. There is something interesting to learn about each city, sometimes without ever even going there.

80 Days is designed as a roguelike and it is intended to be played over and over again, discovering new routes, visiting new places, and experiencing a new story. 80 Days is quite an undertaking regarding the storytelling. There are massive amounts of text here with choices at every turn. Even though the choices primarily impact your experience, sometimes they also have more tangible repercussions. For example, your actions might get you imprisoned in Russia or your intended route might get drastically altered after a scuffle in the middle of the ocean. The most remarkable thing about this game is that each playthrough is totally unique thanks to this emergent method of storytelling. You never know what is going to happen next and where you will ultimately end up, which truly contributes so much to the game’s sense of discovery and wonder.

The writing is interesting and strong throughout. Each part of the trip consist of these lovely mini-stories with unusual and fascinating characters. However, there are also these separate conversations that you can engage in while travelling from point to point and they feel completely different. They are very poorly written and they simply feel completely unnatural. The main purpose of these conversations is to determine new routes and find out information regarding valuable items and trades.

Outside of storyline choices, the gameplay revolves around managing all aspects of the voyage. As Passepartout, you will need to choose the best possible route, taking in mind the price and conditions of each trip. A cheap trip in a run down car or a shanty boat will take its toll on Fogg, lowering his health. He won’t die if his health gets depleted, but he won’t be able to travel any further until he recovers. You can tend to him during travels, or buy items that you can use in order to increase his health points. You can also buy outfit sets. Some sets will nullify negative health points while travelling by train, others will provide bonuses when riding on horseback. Outfits can also help negotiate faster departure times, so that you don’t have to be stuck somewhere for two or more days. Sleeping in hotels instead of the streets with homeless people and dogs will also help keep Fogg’s health up.

Going around the world costs money. There are several ways of earning enough of it to arrive in London on time. You can take out a loan in a bank, but you will have to wait for the money up to a week – depending on how much you want to withdraw. A more efficient way is to buy items along the way and then sell them in cities where they are worth much more. However, this approach may take you off your desired route. But it is actually this kind of unpredictability that is most appealing about 80 Days. It should be noted that you don’t really have to make it back to London in 80 days. You can just explore and go wherever you want. My first playthrough took over 100 days. You can play the game in any way you like. You can race the clock and try to beat your best time, or you can simply unwind and just take in the sights.

Even though the game actually gets more interesting on repeated playthroughs as some additional routes and storylines open up, I have also experienced moments of boredom. Certain stretches just feel a bit laborious and dull. I also have to say that the interface is somewhat clunky, especially when you want to do several things in a hurry (visit the market, check your luggage) before your transport departs.

The game sports a clean art style that is pleasing to the eye. The music is also good, but there is not a lot of variety there. Overall, the production values provide a sufficient amount of atmosphere, but I was left with the impression that more could have been done to give each location a stronger sense of place. For a game that is all about travel and discovery, locations could have had more of an awe-inspiring impact from an audiovisual standpoint.

80 Days is a unique and imaginative game that serves as an apt and worthy homage to its inspiration. It manages to bring so much of its own regarding the storytelling and world-building, and it competently mixes multiple styles of gameplay. This is one grand voyage you should not miss out on.

[h1][b]7 OUT OF 10 (VERY GOOD)[/b][/h1]

18674951.review:
Bottom line up front!

Pros:

+Takes less than two hours for a full playthrough.
+Tons of replayability
+Great visuals; it reminds me very much of a well-designed board game.  The conveyances in particular are well rendered, which you may see in the screenshots.  The map itself is very nice.
+Good ambient sound and music
+It's a piece of interactive fiction with a story to tell.  There aren't "wrong" choices, just different ones.
+The Phineas Fogg health mechanic is EXCELLENT!  Instead of managing your character's health, you are charged as Mr. Fogg's valet.  You may abuse him or care for him as your whim dictates.
+The system is relatively intuitive and operates very much as though you had a globe and touch-menu available in your room.  They ported it from iOS or whatever very well.
+The game autosaves often, which offers an easy way to treat this as a casual game.  I did not mind that I couldn't manually save given the relatively short amount of time it took to play a journey.

Cons:

-Every journey (so far for me) starts from London to Paris.
-Playing through a journey sort of wears out the fun.  Each journey builds toward the triumphant return to London (if you make it!), so for me starting a new trip right after completing one felt more like a burden than a truly new adventure
-Each city, conveyance, and character has its own art, but really the only striking art was the conveyance.  The characters are very much colored cameo/silhouettes, while cities are a bit forgettable.
-No tutorial or other instruction is readily apparent.  It took me half an hour to figure out that it was easier to use the arrow keys to switch between possible routes and an hour to figure out that my character needed particular equipment in order to negotiate quicker passage with the available conveyances.

In all, if you're even considering getting this game then I recommend it.  It's a nice way to while away the time on a lazy afternoon or quiet evening, offering a bit of adventure to contemplate.  The script author is an excellent writer, and I very much enjoyed seeing what she came up with.  I think it's a good bargain at $10.  That's how much I would spend on a two hour movie and I expect to get quite a bit more time out of this game than that.

18668171.review:
I recieved a code for this game in order to review it, but I was not paid for my review.

Considering this game takes its inspiration directly from my favorite novel by Jules Verne, whether or not to play this game was a no-brainer for me. This game is a great example of an interactive novel. You are Passepartout, Phileas Fogg's valet, and it your job to plan the route that will take you Around the World in 80 Days ( I couldn't resist). As you plan your route, you have to manage the finances which involves purchasing gear that will help speed up travel or be more comfortable, or purchase artifacts or luxury items to sell in other parts of the world. The routes you can take depend on what maps you have, and who you talk to. There are so many ways to travel around the world, and so many side stories to be discovered. Expect multiple playthroughs to discover them all. The only potential drawback with this game is that you have to read everything. There are nice backgrounds to each place you go but the game relies on the players imagination to visualize a great bulk of the action. Overall, this is a very fun game with loads of replayability. 

UPDATE: I just want to say that knowing what I now know about this game, I would have paid full price for this game.

18666425.review:
In 80 Days, you play the role of a dutiful servant on a journey around a strange, but familiar world where airships, underwater trains, and giant flying birds exist. Your task is simple: help your master win a wager by organizing every facet of the journey from London and back. Along the way, you have opportunities to discover the lore of this world to learn more about its secrets and to occasionally unravel alternative travel routes. You can also leverage your inventory space in order to carry equipment that can make your journey easier, or instead carry valuables that fetch a higher price in a different city. 

80 Days is a game about balance. Balancing your budget with modes of transportation. Balancing your curiosity with the need to get moving. And balancing risk with reward. Danger is very real, whether its from mutinous crewmembers, pick pockets, or a nun on a mission to destroy all automatons, you’ll often have your hands full keeping distractions at bay.

A worthy little game that comes with plenty of replay value, I highly recommend it to anyone who favors excellent storytelling wrapped in a neat, efficient gameplay package.

Скажем "нет" безлимитному инвентарю!).

p.s.: Руссифицированной версии пока нет. Если знания английского тоже нет, лучше даже не пробовать играть! Простое прокликивание между вариантами диалогов не принесёт никакого удовольствия от путешествия!

9/10

18495622.review:
80 Days is a text based adventure game which takes you all over the globe travelling in an array of contraptions. It is set in the 19th Century and loosely follows the Jules Verne classic 'Around the World in Eighty Days'. You play the valet to Phileas Fogg and you try to navigate across the globe whichever way you see fit. You make the choices as to which cities to visit, which people to converse with, and also how to get yourself into and out of helpful/tricky situations.

A must have game for adventure enthusiasts who like geography, steam punk themes and competition. I am yet to get back in 80 days (82 was a close call in my second outing). I have gone via the North and due East but always get into trouble somewhere. I suggest you give the game a go, even if you don't make it back the first time in 80 days, the game has plenty of routes for you to discover in your next tries. Good Luck All!

Rating: 7/10

18490646.review:
A very enjoyable game for me personally. You play as Passepartout, a valet of his master Fogg. The master waged a bet that he could travel the globe in 80 days or less, so off you go, travelling from city to city in a steampunk world, discovering new routes along the way and trying to figure out the most effecient route while managing your finances and hoping you won't get any obstacles on your way - which you surelly will get!

In the beginning I had the urge to finish my trip as quickly as possible - which is obviously the intention - but because of that I was more focussed on moving along and thus missed out on some exploration/background story in various cities which might have resulted in discovering better routes or learning more things. Luckily this game has a high replayability value since the world is randomly generated and has a lot of cities to visit and many routes to use. So my advice, don't go for a record run on the first try but rather enjoy the world a bit more, play relaxed and you'll gain more satisfaction from playing.

[b]The pro's:[/b]
[list][*] Story rich world
[*] High replayability
[*] You can see how other players did on their journey compared to you and which route they followed while you're travelling. It gives a positive sense of competition because you can see how far in front or behind you are from others by seeing the amounts of days travelled so far.
[*] Nice art which suites the setting of the world[/list]

[b]The Con's:[/b]
[list][*] Sometimes background music doesn't loop fluently.
[*] When in conversation with characters while traveling/'on the road', their answers to some of your questions seem odd to me[/list]

[h1]My first travel summarised[/h1]
I did my first run in 82 days which took me about 2.5h playtime. Knowing the replayability you can get your money out of this game easily. Started in london, took mainly the train through central Europe towards Moscow to then take the Siberian Express. I planned on using the train till Vladivostok but I heard only Military personnel was allowed there so I got off early. Encountered a group of Mongols and traveled through the mountains on horseback which wasn't really comfortable for master Fogg. Once arrived in a city in Central Asia I mainly took aireal rides in mechanical birds towards Japan to end up somewhere in the Pacific. There I took a titanic-like looking ship (which also had the posibility to submerge) towards the US. Due to a storm the ship had to divert to central America. We attempted a munity to regain control on that trip but failed miserably. From Central America we crossed through the Amazon on a large digging machine to the east coast. From there on we took an air ride towards Africa to then travel north back to London. Despite not succeeding in the 80 day deadline I was satisfied with the various little adventures that made up the big one.

18404329.review:
First impressions video:

https://youtu.be/6T6qpa3-8Dc

80 days is a text based adventure game where you, the butler of a fine English gentleman, must accompany said man on a journey around the world. It is based off of the famous novel [i] Around the World in 80 Days [/i] by Jules Verne. The game consists of travelling between cities and dealing with events that occurboth within the cities and between them.

Most of the game occurs in a text based setting. You read a description of were you are, maybe a bit of dialogue, and you choose from one or more choices. Admittedly a one option choice isn't really a thing, but that's just nitpicking. The writing is clever and works well for the style. I highly recommend using accents for the people (especially if you don't know who they are yet. Gruff, English women are always good fun).

The game is procedurally created each time you play. That means a good amount of replay value. 

The art style is simple and vivid. It isn't so elaborate that it pulls the eye away from the reading, while still having a good amount of character to it.

Overall, this game is worthy of a recommendation for the price of $10. Go circumnavigate the world you crazy explorers.

18384042.review:
An amazing and relaxing text-base game!

You, the valet Passepartout, embark with your master to win a wager: Travel Around the World in Eighty Days!
The dynamic story is different every time you play: based on the cities you decide to visit or the people you happen to meet. The world is beautifully described and you will even catch a glimpse of the politic affairs playing in the steampunky world you live in. The game allows for multiple playthroughs, because of the huge amount of different cities to visit, the randomized seeds for the world and ofcourse the urge to beat your friends or your previous records!

My personal record is 75 days, and during this particular journey I walked the ocean floor, was kidnapped by dangerous pirates, traveled both with a walking AND a floating city, crashed a hot air baloon in the ocean, only to be saved by a handful of fishermen.
I came across a lot more of interesting stories, but I won't spoil them all, they're for you to discover!

The game is based on the 1872 novel "Le tour du monde en quatre-vingts jours" by Jules Verne and the story viewed from Passepartouts perspective, just like Jules Verne's book.

The only improvable annoyance I found in this game is the 'conversation'-option you'll get during travels. It is a good way to learn a bit more about the possible roads you can take but it feels like more like some random generated lines than an actual conversation. However, the backstory of the vehicles you use are superb.

Easily worth the 10 bucks in my opinion. A perfect game to play on a relaxing night, it feels like you're reading a different version of Jules Verne's novel.

18382262.review: Wonderful gem. I discovered true love in the frozen north <3

18378605.review:
[b]80 Days 5/5:[/b]: "[i]We are all connected by a hundred untaken journeys.[/i]" To oč se neúspěšně snažil v našich luzích a hájích Ondřej Neff s jeho sérií „aktualizací verneovek pro dnešního čtenáře“. Akorát ve zdařilé podobě, nápaditě využitém steampunkovém hávu a s přímou účastí čtenáře… Ehm, hráče. Videoherní gamebook, který krom častých a zcela zásadních možností volby doslova na každém kroku přidává i jiné herní prvky (práce s inventářem, obchodování, time management, neustálá dilemata s hledáním nejrychlejší/nejlevnější/nejméně únavné cesty, RPG, adventuření apod.) čili to není pouze o pasivním čtení a klikání na možnosti, které v důsledku nemají valný dopad na průběh. V důsledku čehož je to sympatický počin vhodný skutečně pro každého a ne jen pro úzký okruh hráčů tohoto typu her.

 Alfou i omegou veškerých podobných titulů je především to, jak je to napsáno. A nešlo to pro účely hry napsat lépe. Veškeré texty jdou vždy přímo k jádru pudla čili zahlcení stěnami textu nehrozí, ale zároveň to nepůsobí jen jako strohý soupis situace. Naopak, text překypuje atmosférou, budováním napětí, nadsázkou, "šestákovostí" i očividnou láskou k předloze (samozřejmě dojde i na vtípek s "nepřetočenými" hodinkami). K tomu sedne i výtvarný styl, který atmosféru skvostně dotváří, ale prim za všech okolností i tak hraje především představivost podněcovaná oním výtečným textem.

 Že jde „pouze“ o port z přenosných zařízení lze poznat jedině z toho, že je to přeci jen titul, který je i navzdory chytlavosti určen spíše k častému hraní po krátkých úsecích než na nějaké souvislé hraní na jeden zátah. Jinak je to bezchybný port šitý na míru PC a nikoli narychlo spíchnutý hybrid. 

 Každopádně titul s větší „znovuhratelností/znovučitelností“ nenaleznete. Jedna cesta kolem světa zabere nějaké dvě až tři hodiny a navštívíte při ní méně než desetinu lokací v nichž díky svým rozhodnutím, neustálému časovému presu a nejrůznějším proměnným zažijete sotva zlomek toho, co se v každé z nich dá vidět. Dle autorů co průchod hrou, to nějaká tři procenta textu z celkových několika set tisíc slov. Ostatně pro představu - předloha má cca 60 000 slov. Garantuji vám, že se nenajde mnoho gentlemanů, kteří by zůstali pouze u jedné cesty kolem světa, protože vždy je co objevovat a navíc jsou tu díky achievementům mnohé tuhé výzvy, které je radost pokořovat (zkuste to ne za osmdesát, ale čtyřicet dní, byť jádro tkví v cestě samotné a nikoli její rychlosti). Ve výsledku tedy není žádná náhoda, že se tento titul stal loni mnohonásobnou hrou roku nejen v rámci her určených pro mobilních zařízení. A myslím, že letos bude černým koněm na titul roku i pro mnoho PC hráčů… Ehm, čtenářů.

18344743.review:
There's something to be said for the increasing number of remasters on the market these days. I'm not a particularly big fan of them, but if they are being made, they must be selling. It's quite peculiar, though, to see a video game straddle different forms of media, to re-tell Jules Verne's classic tale of Phileas Fogg and his 80 day trip around the globe, and in a choose-your-own visual novel, no less! True, it isn't a direct re-telling, in fact it's almost entirely original material, bar the initial bet that sees Fogg traipse across the planet. But if 80 Days can rekindle my love for the written word, then I'm all for it.

If you've previously read Around The World in Eighty Days, you can pretty much forget everything you thought you knew about Fogg and his valet, Passepartout's, journey around the globe. While Fogg is still a stuffy, well to do type, and Passepartout attends to his every whim, the world around them is drastically different. The age of steam, gears and machinery has taken hold, and it's up to Fogg and Co to take advantage of it to arrive back in London before their 80 day deadline is up. A fortune awaits them if they can make it back in time, with bitter defeat and ridicule being the only other option - a fate worse than death!

Setting off from London, they can travel to any of a large number of cities, all across the globe. There's very little in the way of restrictions to stop Fogg and Passepartout,well, aside from their bank balance.

Their journey is set against a beautifully-rendered interactive globe, with sprawling travel routes running like a circulatory system across the planet. Each city they visit has its own story, people, market and events. So whether you're in Paris sipping coffee in a cafe, or stealing heavy machinery with a mining crew in South America, each location feels unique, and most importantly, authentic - no mean feat considering the truly monumental scale of the game.

Being men of the world, Fogg and Passepartout bump into all kinds of characters. Sometimes, you'll get a great tip about places to visit or faster travel routes, other times, you might end up comatose in an opium den, only to end up on an airship going in the wrong direction. Mon Dieu!

Traveling across the world isn't cheap, and whilst Fogg is a wealthy man, you'll still need to watch your expenses. Fortunately, you won't be shy of an opportunity to earn some coin. Marketplaces are a great spot to pick up trinkets, travel-appropriate clothing, and items that might be worth a bob or two in other parts of the world. Failing that, Passepartout can always dress up as a bearded lady in the circus.

Money affords Fogg and Passepartout comfort and luxury, but some routes may not be so accommodating, meaning traveling can impact their health. If you've managed to collect appropriate clothing sets for your journey, like scarves and hats, you can lessen the damage done., but some times you will be left with no option than to rest. You can keep Fogg in tip top shape by attending to his needs whilst you travel. It's amazing what a cup of tea and a tidy moustache can do! Just don't drink the local water.

Make no mistake about it, 80 Days is a gorgeously detailed book, rich in detail, and with more than a few laughs thrown in for good measure. Developer, Inkle, has crafted a gamebook so lavish with descriptive language that its easy to become engrossed. It doesn't matter if you win the bet or not, so long as you enjoy the journey, and trust me, you will.

80 Days is a wonderful re-imagination of Jules Verne's classic book "Around The World in 80 Days"

http://criticalindiegamer.com/2015/10/around-the-world-in-80-days-or-so/

18326930.review:
While not for everyone, I found 80 Days to be a fun and unique experience. 

80 Days has three main mechanics. First you need to plan routes around the world in order to complete you journey within 80 days. This is an interesting mechanic since you need to carefully plan your route but not take too long or you can arrive too late for your preferred form of transportation and have to wait losing precious time. You also need to handle your inventory buying and selling goods that will help you on your journey and help fund your travels. 

The biggest mechanic in the game is the story itself. Most of the game revolves around interacting with the people and events you encounter on your journey. This requires a lot of text reading with the occasional option to decide how the story plays out. This is main reason why I said that the game will not be for everyone. If this doesn't appeal to you, you won't like 80 Days. If you like a good story though I think you can really enjoy 80 Days. 

If you like the idea behind the game and like a good story that requires quite a bit of reading you should really enjoy 80 Days since it is a truly original engaging experience. 

Note: I received a free review copy from the developer.

I got everything I expected and more from this game.

80 Days is a fantastic story telling adventure that sees you travelling around the world making quick decisions every where you go.
I started off heading eastward to Paris before visiting many, many other cities and each and every one of them has a story to tell and depending on what you decide within the stories you could end up one way or another.

The first time I tried going around the world I made it JUST in 78 days!! After a few unfortunate mishaps and decisions I could have made better! 

But what I love even more about 80 Days is the fact that once you finish your around the world trip the next time you play it, everything is different you get different items to start with in London and instead of heading South why not even head North? Before I knew it on my second time around I found myself journeying towards the North Pole before eventually crashing and left for dead but miracles happen and we found our way out and were bound for Canada before we knew it, a train across Canda before making another rather stupid decision seeing us thrown off the train and left fending our own way back to London. Then we happen to come across a pilot going to Reyjavik on only day 50!
Though rather out of pocket we had to wait an agonozing 5 days in Iceland waiting for bank funds to come in before paying for the last leg of our Journey back to London! (Thinking about it we could have gone to the bank in Toronto and gotten the same funds the next day).

80 Days is a real gem and you can spend hours on end plotting your way across the world, YOU are in control and it's up to you to decide how best to arrive back in London!
I highly reccomend the game to anyone who's ever been a fan of 80 Days around the world or interested in travelling in general, there is so much fun to be had!

18260777.review:
Though I generally approach mobile ports with a certain scepticism, I found it impossible not to like this game.

Being designed for touch-controlled devices rather than for PC the gameplay would probably suffer if it wasn't for the fact that there is practically no gameplay.
Assuming the role of trusty [i]Passepartout[/i], you simply click your way through the interactive texts as you plan ahead for your journey around the world, manage your budget and attend to your duties as [i]Phileas Fogg's[/i] loyal valet. Be it inquiring fellow travellers about possible routes, preparing Fogg's shaving water or just making conversation to improve his mood and constitution.

However, the game is obviously based on Jules Verne's famous novel and if you've read it, you already know that travelling won't be a walk in the park. There await countless random events; technical malfunctions, robbery, mutiny - even death.
But fear not, for you will also encounter various characters with the most interesting backgrounds whose friendship (and sometimes even love) you can win and who will often aid you on your voyage.

The story feels surprisingly thorough and responsive, considering it used to be "one of those pesky mobile games".
In pretty much every situation you have 2 or 3 different (text) options to choose from and alter the progress of the overall journey.
They managed to create and maintain a perfect balance between wanting to make haste in order to win the bet (circumnavigate the world in less than 80 days) and wanting to explore foreign culture. A perfect balance between "I can't wait to continue on my way because I'm keen to visit new cities and countries" and "But I also want to explore this city some more and learn about its recent history and its people".
I think this is probably the greatest plus of the game and the reason it feels so incredibly vivid, almost as vivid as the actual novel.

Throughout the adventure Passepartout will also develop in a certain way, depending on the choices you make. So it's entirely up to you if you want to be the exquisite Monseigneur or a sly daredevil - or maybe it's for the best of your gutless character to stay out of trouble and keep quiet?

Concluding my impressions after almost 3 hours into the game I can promise you that if you are a fan of Verne's works, there is no risk at all in buying this. I can also wholeheartedly recommend it to historically interested people, since you get to learn quite a lot about the time the game is set in.
Just make sure to keep in mind that it's more of a strategical exploration game with lots of text.

Ultimately, if you're still not sure whether to buy or not, just do it. The limit of 2 hours for the Steam refunds is more than enough time to get a good impression of the game.

18258253.review:
If you're the sort of refined lady or gentleman that enjoys a good text-based adventure this game comes highly recomended. 
Having just concluded my first voyage I am already eager to set out again. In my first adventure I was kidnapped in an opium den and forced to join the circus to earn some money as a was left pennyless in Yokohama. A failed mutiny attemt left me stranded in Honolulu for 3 days, and then I accidentaly got involved in the slave-trade, wich left both myself and  my character rather horrified. 
The whole trip took 96 days and was thus a failiure. Long story short - don't go to Hong Kong. No good can come of it.

18258163.review: Fantastic, fun game if you enjoy geography, travel, choose-your-own-adventure stories or clean, crisp design and attention to detail. Strongly recommend.

18257067.review:
This game is as much about the journey as it is about the destination. A playthrough may only take as much as an hour and a half, but with the sheer number of locations you can visit and perils or intriguing events you might experience on your way, the game not only encourages but almost demands multiple playthroughs to fully experience all the intricate details that can be found if you are willing to look for them.

Although the game can feel sterile and cold on the surface, its polished exterior soon reveals a world inhabited by multitudes of interesting characters. Who is the mysterious stranger aboard the train? Perhaps they require you to deliver an important item to a distant location. Perhaps they can offer you information about faraway routes and trade opportunities.

People might seek your help or attention, but will you risk getting involved in the matters of their lives, or will you ignore them as you set your sights on completing your journey faster than anyone might have imagined?

If you like a good story and don't mind a bit of reading, this game is full of excellent adventures for your choosing.

18256007.review: This is a decent port of a game that was already super fun on mobile, with a crapload of new content. One thing I REALLY don't like, however, is how much of my CPU it takes up! A game that's primarily text based should NOT be eating 96.6% of my CPU at any given moment.

18255310.review:
A French and British man go on a steampunk roadtrip and are beset by adversities and weird happenings. On a wager to circumnavigate the Earth in 80 days you are the one to manage the Englishman's travel itinerary.

The health and bank account of your employer, and of course the time, are your only resources in this choose your own adventure.

Though I've experienced a few bugs, such as a blank conversation box appearing after a "weird event" and the graphical duplication of the luggage, two trips have been completed. Each so far, even taking the same cities at one leg of the journey, have been different with separate events. Replayability and character are the bread and butter of "80 Days" and  I recommend the title.

18251687.review:
Played this one for a while on iOS and I can only recommend this one to all adventurous people around this world.

It will appreciate especially people who played games like FTL (but without the fight - but even fight you can there).

World is set in a steampunk theme based on Jules Verne famous book series like 80 days around the world or Journey to the Center of Earth or 20 000 miles beneath the sea or Journey to the Moon.

It is great feeling when you start your journey and take care for your master Mr. Fogg. You care about his money, health and all around pleasure.

Game it self is based strongly on text reading and once you finish the game its like you red some little novel made by you.

So if you love strong narrative and good old gentlemen era, this game is made for you! :)

18251216.review:
[h1]发布了IOS和安卓版后，80 Days, 终于出PC了！[/h1]

这是时代周刊评选的2014年度游戏 ——根据凡尔纳的小说改编，又在小说的基础上扩充了很多内容，相比原著，也有了更多的城市可以去，没必要十分严格地完全按照原著的路线跑一遍，多开几个周目，多去几个城市，会更好玩的——世界那么大，主角和先生应该去看看！

附：[url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2014/12/04/80-days-review]80 Days IGN详评[/url]

[b]剧情：[/b]你扮演的主角不是跟别人打赌去环游世界的先生，而是他的仆人，一个法国小伙~每一个城市都有自己的事件，根据不同的选择会导致不同的结果，而且会造成别的影响，比如影响先生的生命值（其实应该是体力值），还有主角和先生的好感度之类的……至于详细的剧情，就先不剧透了~有一部分是原著里面已经有的，但是更大的一部分是原创的。自己的英语水平嘛……四级考了540左右，[spoiler]（六级压根就没过啊QAQ）[/spoiler]玩这个游戏感觉不算轻松，但是也不是很吃力，不认识的单词都可以猜啊~不同于原著的一点就是，这个游戏的剧情带着些蒸汽朋克的风格~

[b]游戏：[/b]这个游戏要你在80天内环游世界，游戏内也确实有一个计时器，时刻不停地走动着，探索的时候，住店的时候，逛商店的时候，看大地图的时候……基本上只有看剧情的时候，它才会暂停一会——时间在流逝，要抓紧啦！但是计时器的设定会让人在开始玩的时候感到有些忙乱，不知道接下来该干什么比较好……至于金钱，旅行会耗费金钱，不过幸好我们可以从事倒买倒卖的活计！从这座城市买了特产，到另一个城市卖掉，往往能给你带来一笔外快~游戏里也贴心地在物品说明上写着，这个物品在哪里能卖一个好价钱……此外，主角还可以去银行取钱，但是需要等待一段时间，才可以把钱拿到手。这段时间内不能离开城市，所以好好规划行程，就显得十分重要了：）

[b]自己：[/b]虽然这里的时长有点短，但是冬天的时候抱着个安卓老爷机，已经打了一周目，明明80天就可以搞定的旅途，被我生生拖到了100+天，到最后直接就是不在意天数，到处瞎逛了……OTZ。然后第二周目学聪明了，44天到了檀香山，基本上一路都是在赶时间，像原著里说的一样，船一靠岸就抓紧去赶火车，搞得基本没时间取钱，全靠倒买倒卖才撑下来~

[b]总结：[/b]是一个很有意思的剧情向游戏，感觉值得全价入手——全价不是很贵，而且光是文本量，基本上就可以值回票价了！

18250385.review:
Traveled around the world in 71 days in which I raised and led a mutiny against the captain of the ship carrying me and monsieur Fogg across the Pacific. Competed in a race with some children, and ran away from a bandit trying to rob me in America and nearly being caught by him on the train outta town. 

I think I'll go the other direction my next play through instead of through Russia, but of course there are bunch of different routes to take.

18249399.review: Not much to say. I'm just a bit disappointed by the fact that this game doesn't offer much more than the mobile version, but it's still a great game even if fairly easy.

18249052.review:
One of the best pieces of interactive fiction available. While the character choices are similar to Tell Tale's games in that they effect the tone of the narrative rather than its content there is still mechanically siginifcant enough changes that 80 Days remains engorssing over multiple re-plays and routes. 

HINT: The most interesting stories are always slightly out of your way.

18248415.review: PC port of the mobile game based around the classic story by Jules Verne. A very fun, replayable game. First playthrough took around 2 hours and made it around in 74 days in where I was held captive in Russia, had a Steamboat explode on the Mississippi river and fought and captured Jesse James while traveling across the US. A great steampunk world with plenty of routes and cities to visit. Highly recommended in combination with a glass of scotch and a relaxing evening.
